review_title: Continuous acquisitions, losses, re-orgs and layoffs.
pros: Some of the policies and benefits are good. You can make use of them only, if you are in a good team and under supportive manager, which is rare.
cons: No focus on building long-term sustainable business. Too many re-orgs & lay offs. Too much of control given to first-level managers. No concept of peer-reviews for performance. Individual feedbacks are hardly considered. Observed the work overloading on Contractors and Visa-holders in majority of the teams, as they always struggle to secure their jobs, agree to do whatever the low-profile work assigned to them by managers. Most managers knowingly do this, that benefits some lazy full time employees with poor performance and too many personal priorities during the work hours, who doesn't have visa limitations. No value for the talent & hard work. Lay off lists are prepared as per the convenience of the managers and HR, to secure their jobs with less or no efforts on identifying the bottom performers who are surviving in the company for decades with high salaries.

pros: Executive leadership team is good, says the right things, sometimes even do the right things. I like that there is a big sense of family when there are personal challenges of employees. The People Deal, and the focus on employees is very good, and highly appreciated.
cons: A behemoth of a company where collaboration could be optimized so much more, although it is better than it was 10 years ago. Career movements should be much easier for internal candidates than it is, of course there are job movements but should be more supported. Each team has its own employee experience based upon the leader, and of course you can expect this but it is difficult to get around this or through this if you find yourself on a team that doesn't quite gel with you. There are teams that have a fantastic, warm culture, while other teams play favorites, politics and there is no accountability. Lastly, every year we are expected to cut x% from the budget, so it became an uninspiring place to work if you value innovation, large transformation, or you care about the customer experience.

review_title: Superior Work Life Balance, Frustrating Bureaucracy
pros: Cisco has always had female leadership presence and because of that, the company takes work life balance very seriously. Also, because they invented telecommuting, that lifestyle is built into their DNA. Almost everyone I worked with was excellent. When we got our red tape out of the way, we did a lot of cool stuff.
cons: The company is gigantic. This primarily manifests itself in 2 ways: Layoffs and Bureaucratic Slowdown. Cisco pretty much has a standard policy of cutting 10% of the workforce every, single, year. A lot times the layoffs make ZERO sense at all, and people often get rehired at higher salaries. It's almost a Silicon Valley tradition to be laid off off from Cisco at some point in your career. From a software/Data Science perspective, the red tape primarily shows itself in data access. Finding the right data steward and actually completing data permissions is a frustrating and circuitous process. But, on the other hand, red tape slows things down so much it's pretty rare to get overwhelmed.

pros: - A lot of great people that are open, willing to help and brilliant. - Work from home (even before covid)
cons: I always wanted to work for Cisco, but over the past several years I've seen a decline in culture and quality. - Complicated products! Look at how complicated SDA is, look at how complex our "multi-domain" strategy is. - Awful product quality. It's sad that we have to vet out our products for our customers in order to avoid trainwrecks (e.g. When FTD was released, SDA right now, ISA before 2.0) - Silo'd. We talk about how we offer an end-to-end solution, but when it comes to sales, deployment, and even post-sales support everything is extremely silo'd. Have a multi-architectures solution? Good luck! - No career growth opportunities unless you move. Extremely difficult to get a grade bump or raise. - Pay is no longer competitive compared to other big vendors. - YEARLY layoffs! Sometimes twice a year.

review_title: Great experience that sadly fell apart
pros: Cisco was great because I joined a team that was highly motivated and out to build something new. I worked out of the Meraki office and really liked all of my co-workers in the building and the culture that was built there. We initially had really good dynamic, and for a period of time I really enjoyed my day to day. Over time, we had a series of leadership changes, acquisitions, and after nearly a dozen manager changes in a few short years and an exodus of talent, my team became a shell of what it formerly was. I had great experiences finding other ways to involve myself in the Cisco community that led to a lot of amazing new connections and opportunities that I will forever be grateful for. Cisco has abundant opportunities outside of your immediate org if you are motivated and ask to be involved. There were a lot of amazing upsides to Cisco, but my immediate BU was horribly mismanaged.
cons: Unreasonable amounts of pager duty (I was a SWE and on PD 12h a day for over 100 days of the year) Poor upper level management of the BU caused an exodus of talent Too many manager changes in too short of time

review_title: Great Spot to Start Your Career
pros: -The rotational aspect of the program is great in that you can experience 4 very different roles over the course of 2 years, which is great for trying to understand a company as large as Cisco. The variety of roles is clearly a plus as you are able to preference which areas interest you as you move throughout your time in the program. -Generally, the expectations from your teams are within reason but provide a challenge at least in my experience. Learning is encouraged and mistakes are seen as an opportunity to grow rather than a reason for criticism. -The program itself feels like a family of sorts that you can relate with people in the same boat as yourself early in career. This makes for a great support system and provides an automatic resource for general questions.
cons: -Sometimes timing of role responsibilities and additional program expectations can overlap which can create a challenge; however, these are chances to exercise time management. -Transitions can be a little tricky to manage due to turnover of roles (some new ones can be added and others) so some processes aren't as clearly defined. Generally business partners are understanding though and there's always help to get you up to speed.

review_title: Great People, Great Products, Great Company, but still a large corporation...
pros: PROS: -- Positive Work environment / Corporate Culture. --
cons:
ant Exposure to New Technology. -- Endless opportunities to develop existing skills, learn new skills on the job, and change roles. -- Leadership is dedicated to making the company feel like one large "team" or "family" where everyone is there to help everyone else (not always practiced of course). -- An extremely well organized and streamlined company. -- Company culture heavily promotes internal-innovation and is very open to hearing about (and trying out) ideas of employees if they are innovative, reasonable, doable, and the employee is willing to make them a reality. -- Technical ability and breadth of technical knowledge are prized commodities company-wide, even among non-technical roles, and often go hand-in-hand with opportunities for personal development and advancement. -- Positive attitudes are well rewarded and those with a consistently negative outlook often find themselves a victim of the Annual "limited restructuring" events. -- The annual layoffs do not usually impact technical workers (and their supporting coworkers) that are focused on growing / profitable technologies and products. -- In contrast to media speculation and Lamentations following layoffs on web forums, these layoffs are almost entirely avoidable. With the deluge of resources to learn new technologies and skills within Cisco, workers who find themselves layed off when their area of focus is no longer relevant (profitable) almost always passed up many opportunities to reskill, move into growing tech, etc. And the writing is always on the wall well before the axe falls. NOTE: there ARE exceptions to this like when huge portions of staff at one of the Cisco sites is let go for heartless business reasons -- such as when jobs are moved overseas to save money (or when jobs are moved back because customers prefer to "speak to someone in "). -- Cisco gives you a choice of several nice notebook models to use (including the current year MacBook Pro 15") as well as quality monitors and computer peripherals for your daily use. This is a nice perk if you're a bit of a nerd, which many employees are.
Cons
CONS: -- The (very) regular restructuring / layoff events. There really MUST be a less heartless and less disheartening way of aligning human resources with ever-changing corporate goals and fluctuations in stock prices. The current method of mass purges every year can't really be called anything other than lazy and uninspired leadership with a near-sighted view of success. For a company that so prizes innovation this practice sticks out like a sore thumb. -- Oftentimes employees are dramatically underpaid for their work. Sadly, since many of these workers started with the company fresh out of college as interns, after 10+ years they will often find themselves making half of what an employee at another company with identical skills and experience makes. Since Cisco does not really ever give employees more than a few percent pay increase per year, many of these seasoned workers are trapped in a low paying position with no real hope of receiving a fair wage without leaving the company, accepting a (much) higher position at another company, and reapplying at Cisco a year or so later, at which point Cisco will match (or offer a slightly higher) wage than the worker is currently being paid. Situations like this really show that at the end of the day, a giant corporation that genuinely cares about its workers well-being, is still a giant corporation. -- The Annual layoffs -- Even when an employee is paid something close to fair market value for a specific role, the pay is typically lower than what the vast majority of other organizations will pay, and the benefits (once amazing beyond compare!) are very middle of the road. -- The annual layoffs -- Unless a candidate is truly an industry leader or posseses unique skills Cisco cannot find elsewhere, there is no real room for negotiating pay / an employment contract. If the candidate attempts to negotiate after an offer has been made and rejects the initial offer, that's the end of the ball game. The hiring manager will go on down the list of the fifty other perfectly qualified candidates and offer the job to one of them. This regular practice has cost many candidates a job when they were simply following normal, acceptable job-seeker etiquette. The unstated (but commonly understood) idea behind this behaviour is that working for a great company like Cisco is a highly valuable reward in itself, and the difference in pay is accounting for that "fact" -- I have never heard of anyone telling this to a candidate but I have heard managers on a number of occasion allude to this. -- The annual layoffs -- The company was founded in Californis and has always been based in California. For those who do not know, this region of the US known is known for its very strong progressive and left-leaning social and political beliefs. And while almost always a good thing, the imprint the area in which Cisco is located oftentimes makes leadership announcements, company initiatives, etc. a little bit preachy and "holier-than-thou" -- looking down on those who do not always agree with Cisco's political or social stances on certain topics. -- The annual layoffs. I am taking to YOU, CHUCK ROBBINS, please fix this for the sake of your loyal employees, you're so much better than this.

pros: The Leaders in Finance and Technology (LIFT) Program is a 2-year rotational program for recent college grads. Not only does Cisco provide several networking, volunteering, diversity & inclusion, and career development opportunities within the program, but after the program as well. There are plenty of job swap opportunities throughout your entire career at Cisco. Typically, employees try to rotate to grow their skillsets about every 2-4 years. Also, because Cisco is such a large company, no role is the same. You have plenty of opportunities to learn something new and develop in new areas both personally and professionally.
cons: Definitely depends on the specific team you are on, but work-life balance isn't always the best for roles that are more demanding. Personally, out of the 4 teams I have worked with, 2 of them have required long hours outside of your normal 9am-5pm. Cisco as a company promotes time off, it's just that certain teams are busier than others.

review_title: Rewarding work, Good coworkers, Ridiculous upper management churn
pros: The work was technically challenging and my coworkers were a great group to work. The benefits were decent and bonus was nice. I was provided the tools needed.
cons: There is a ridiculous amount of churn at the SVP level . Had 4 SVP leaders in 32 months. Churn just below them the same. One VP lasted 2 months. No on the same page but the big bonus's stay the same. They also contradict each other. Our SVP said to focus on quality and a group meeting. The next week the group VP said focus on time to market not quality, the exact opposite. You tend to get siloed and management does not seem able to figure out get workers access to the numerous training programs or worse this lack of access is intentional. Tell your manager to figure out how to get access to "Chuck" bucks for training. Intergroup working relationships can be difficult probably due to the Cisco HR stacked ranking mechanism. People do not want to help out when integrating different products/functionality together. Definite ageism in labor reduction practices. Buy other companies then start killing the product even when still achieving 20% growth. I'm sure the tier 1 telco's are going to be happy about that.

In the LIFT Program, I am able to develop my career in a wide range of areas with rotations within finance and accounting. review_title: LIFT Program - Exceptional Leadership Development and Finance Training
pros: Cisco's LIFT program provides exceptional training and development opportunities in the program. Because you rotate to a new role every 6 months, you create a large network of highly skilled professionals over the two years in the program. The managers in the program are invested in your development and put in a significant amount of time to accelerate your career. In addition there is frequent exposure to executive leadership and several opportunities to lead initiatives and events. Cisco's culture is also very inclusive and gives back generously to the community. Benefits package is also great.
cons: Pay is average and you are hired into the LIFT program a grade below other entry level Financial Analysts at Cisco. LIFT program director controls compensation & bonus. Performance evaluations in the LIFT program are heavily weighted on presentation skills and training test scores from a 1 week training, and only partially on your role performance. If you score average in the training, you will receive an average bonus even if you have high ratings on your role performance.

pros: Work Life balance Smart People Very Respectful Culture

People are great and a lot of humble & genuine people to work with in such a massive corporate environment.
cons: Overall benefits (except insurance) is not the best of what other competitors or typical top IT companies are offering, surprisingly behind. Adapting IT industry trends can be slower than others as it is still very hardware driven. Too big organization, hard to navigate people you need to connect with sometimes,

cons: 1) Bad company to work for freshers. Have seen some freshers, folks from good colleges hired as Software Engineer, doing support jobs. 2) Managers in India are Narcissist, who has fall behind to upgrade themselves with software engineering and technology. 3) Hard work or innovation is not appreciated by managers if the work doesn't give them visibility. 4) Mostly Team Leads are in pockets of managers in hope of better appraisal. No matter how good or hardworking you are, your appraisal will not be good. It has been so in my past two teams. review_title: Great culture and teamwork with improvement for employee retention
pros: Always has a group of senior IT engineers and architects to ask questions to. They were always easy to approach and happy to answer questions and provide guidance (not sure if this is luck of the draw with their personalities, or if it is company/organization culture quite honestly). Most of the managers are great people who provide guidance and try to help you determine your career path and put you on projects you would enjoy and your skills align to (there is always a "bad apple" manager, but this is the exception).
cons: The IT side in particular seems to be following what I consider a negative trend in the industry of hiring contractors for specific projects with the skills needed, rather than training the full time employees they already have who have gotten the company to the successful state they are in. You won't get the best talent using primarily contractors and they will leave eventually. Then the company will lose their experience and knowledge after the project ends, when they could provide guidance towards a future project.

review_title: Technical adoption in a young part of the organization
pros: A Customer Success Specialist (CSS) is a technical person, who is given the task of acting as a technical consultant for customers, in the post-sales stage. The goal is helping customer with product adoption. The daily job is a mix of studying/practicing with the technology, on one side, and engaging with customers in meetings and workshop, on the other: so, it's a very interesting mix between technical and "soft" skills. It's particularly indicated for technical people who have a passion for explaining, helping, engaging with people. It's the ideal position for people with a strong technical background, who wish to move a little bit towards the business and the communications side of the IT work. The Customer Success organization in Cisco is still very young, which gives an opportunity to stay in an enthusiastic environment and to shape the organization, because many processes still need to be finalized. At the same time, it's a growing part of the company, because Cisco's vision is to focus more and more on recurrent revenues, and therefore on subscription renewal, and therefore on adoption. Being a post-sales role, there is not excessive pressure, because CSSs are not measured in relation to a sales quota. This gives time to learn, and to establish a good life/work balance.
cons: The cons are exactly the other side of the coin, if compared to the pros. E.g.: Since Customer Success is a young organization, things are changing very often: the management is changing ideas and adjusting the strategy very frequently. This is not ideal for people who like to stay on a solid ground, or to be constantly told what to do. Another example: since the role is post-sales and not bound to sales quotas, as a result the compensation and the incentives won't be so high as in a sales role. But, in turn, you get lower pressure and stress.

review_title: A place to unleash the power of the employee with some challenges
pros: Cisco is a great company,with lots of flexibility , they appreciate your dedication and hard work , it empowers and give employees the freedom to deliver to their full potential. It is a company that is constantly looking for excellence. It is a great diverse place. Great work life balance. We work on the newest technologies, with modern processes that help Cisco (and us as employees) to stay ahead of the curve! Great environment and atmosphere to work. They appreciate the change and willing to listen to any ideas. Dealing with customers is always facilitated. Working for customer adoption is one of the unique and amazing experience. Cisco is always looking forward to deliver the best experience and technologies for its customers. Cisco is always coping with the new management and new organizational architectures.
cons: Most of the teams are dispersed over large geographical regions and you feel some how that you have weak connections even within your team. There is no clear instructions to follow for your onboarding ,also there is no clear path for self or technical development. It is very hard to fully comprehend all the teams and specializations as it is so many with lots of functions. Technical labs is some how hard to find and setup and different labs is found for different teams. Lots of information scattered all over the internal pages , community , spaces with no single source of truth and no a standard way to organize these materials and data. No clear goals nor appraisal criteria. Layoffs Due to economy are difficult.

pros: Lets us build better post solution deployment affinity with the customers. We can see their challenges from their lens and help them overcome the technology adoption barriers. This speeds up the technology usage and adoption and helps the customer to love Cisco solutions.
cons: Sometimes the lack of telemetry data becomes a hurdle in assessing health of solution at customer premises but Cisco is striving hard to overcome this gap by building cloud links of solution to collect proactive telemetry data.

review_title: Great company to work and grow
pros: Cisco Systems is one of the top companies in the industry and hence it's a company where you can develop a successful and stable career. In Cisco you are always challenged to grow and improve, you have plenty of opportunities to develop yourself as well as opportunities to move internally between different positions. And when doing so, you'll normally get the full support of your manager. In cisco everyone is approachable: it is not uncommon that you can take a coffee with one of the executives and hjave an open conversation and share what you think about the company and about your role: they actually like to receive such feedback and information. But also at lower level, your voice is always heard and your feedback taken into consideration. It's also a company you can feel proud of, thanks to all the initiatives the employees and the company work on to give back to the society, and that are supported and encouraged by the executives in the company, starting from the CEO: giving back, corporate social responsibility, fairness and equal treatment, work-life balance, ... Finally, compensation in the company is really good, and there are plenty of benefits you can enjoy that add on top of your salary.
cons: As mentioned, there are plenty of opportunities to promote in Cisco, but you have to pursue them by yourself: just doing your job will not grant you a promotion to a higher position, and career path is not pre-established...if you want to move to a higher position you have to apply and demonstrate you are the best candidate for it. That can also be a benefit, as there is not a minimum time you have to be in a position to promote. Being a multinational company also means that your manager might not be in your same country, which can make the promotion even harder. Also, your workmates can be spread around the globe too. And sometimes due tom frequent restructuring, your manager can change often. Finally, most position at Cisco are goal-driven, what means that you may end-up working extra hours very easily. Hence, very good time management and organisation skills are needed, as well as the ability to disconnect from work when the day is over, even when working from home.

review_title: Great place to start and end your career
pros: Pay is decent but not as high as other tech companies around the area. 401k matching, fairly good health benefits, WFH and working remotely are available to most employees, but it depends on your team and manager. Its a great place to start your career but most early in career people leave to other tech companies after 2-3 years. Cisco doesn't do a good job of retaining some of their top talent. This is a perfect company for those with a family and like a lot flexibility. Most departments are pretty relaxed and hardly ever hit 40 hours of work a week
cons: Overall there aren't too many cons. The two biggest issues I see is a lack of merit increase each year. Some people can stay at their same salary for 5 years. Promotions are fairly hard to get if you don't play politics. Saw a lot great talent leave when they didn't get recognized. The only other major con is upper management. There are too many directors and senior leaders that care more about their bonus and don't focus on the bigger picture of doing whats best for the company.

review_title: Decent experience, first large tech company I worked for
pros: It seemed like there were lots of benefits, to the point of it being difficult to be aware of or manage them all.
cons: Cisco is a large company, and old for the tech industry, and I feel like both of those showed in the negatives. Lots of policies, lots of old corporate systems and processes that we were theoretically supposed to know how to use, and a feeling of detachment, of being several levels down in a 70,000+ node tree. Some things hadn't changed in years or decades, but there were also (from my perspective) unnecessary and disruptive changes while I was there; big changes in both health and retirement benefits providers within one year. The experience of being an employee at Cisco seemed to involve a lot of complexity that had more to do with the company's size and age than with my work or what I wanted from a job, and I would have preferred a simpler employee experience where I could focus on getting actual work done.

pros: Great management that encourages you to take your PTO, lots of independence
cons: Nothing bad to say about Cisco

lting Engineer in Bangalore
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
I have been working for Cisco for more than 2 years now. I joined Cisco straight out of college. I will forever be grateful to Cisco for helping me build myself from scratch. Even though I am here on Glassdoor looking for a job switch now, I am amused to see how high my standards have become, all because the way I am treated here at Cisco. They might not be paying me as much as I want but they sure are treating me well. > Best work culture ever. Saying this based on what I hear from friends working in other companies. > You will know they actually care about you and Cisco will go out of its way to show it to you. > Excellent leadership team, their ideas and visions flow through the entire company and keep us all on the right path. > Got to learn a lot in the past 2 years, all thanks to the management and teammates. > Satisfactory compensation.
Cons
The role that I am in is customer-facing and with a support role, comes its own challenges. Everyone knows Cisco TAC and appreciates it for the work we do. At the same time, being a TAC engineer can get exhausting for the following reasons. 1. We are supposed to work 8 hours a day but the amount of work can never be wrapped up in that time. Even though we hand off after our shifts, you will always have work pending on you. 2. Escalations may exhaust you now and then. 3. In the past 2 years that I have spent here, I have only heard of cost-cutting measures taken to save the business and keep it growing. Although I understand the decisions taken from a business point of view, but they still need to make promotions more frequent and rewarding. 4. The sheer amount of talent present in Cisco makes it very hard for you to get promoted. Doing your day-to-day job well is not good enough, you have to show the extra efforts you have put in to get promoted. This kind of challenging work environment is great for growth as long as the promotion we get justifies the efforts. 6. Seen senior talent leave for the above reason.

review_title: Good environment, but suffers from being a large corporation
pros: Great benefits, good co-workers, generally good management. Frequent team building events, if that's your thing.
cons: Some policies clearly indicate management doesn't trust employees to do their jobs without supervision. Despite preaching the benefits of full-time remote work for employers since the early 90s, Cisco limits full-time remote work opportunities.

pros: - Good Technical Work. - Workspace facilities - Cafeteria food - Opportunity to work with talented engineers
cons: At SP Routing BU in India, engineers work at least 12 hours a day, 7 days a week. There are no weekends or holidays, and you would even be indirectly asked to work on the days when you file a leave. There is no respect given for engineers, and work life balance is completely unheard of. In the days when we talk about abolishing keywords like "Slave" even from techical jargon, the engineers in SP India are treated as if they are "owned" by Cisco, and expected to be available 24x7. The entire hierarchy of senior management consists of egoistic and narcissist lot who treat engineers like some sort of tools to be used and disposed off. They dont like any engineer saying he/she is overloaded with work - that's something they hate to hear. So, engineers are expected to not complain, and just continue working on their stretch targets during their entire life, sacrificing their personal lives and health, so that the Management can claim to get more work done by less people. If anyone complains, they would be pushed back saying that we are not working "optimally", or we should think of "automation" instead of doing "donkey's work" etc. etc - That would certainly be not motivating at all, after working on complex technical problems. The management seems to be totally clueless when it comes to understanding the value of technical contributions of engineers, and they just go after some jargons and fancy terminologies and matrics. The main responsiblity of the Management is to use the whip and constantly apply pressure on employees to squeeze the maximum out of them, which is a strtegy that is systemically pushed down from top to bottom in the hierarchy of management. They would often be hypocritical and "encourage" the employees to give "open comments", but all they are expecting is that engineers should just "align" themselves with the general labor strategy and directions from top. Project schedules are dervided based on a sort of "bargaining process" between the engineers and management, resembling some sort of civil construction work. The engineers go with a particular effort estimate which will be outright rejected by the Management, who would want "justifications" for every single day projected. The implicit bargaining process results in engineers cutting down the effort projections by half, agreeing to "absorb" the work. Eventually, the project tends to slip, and engineers work 24x7 to meet the targets, only to get constantly criticized and tortured with sarcastic comments regarding the delays and slippage. Even though the quality of technical work done in the BU is superiod, there is never a sense of achievement, and it appears like the management constantly wants to make every engineer feel that they are failures.

review_title: Company with great culture and work-life balance, but change is often slow
pros: The benefits are really amazing. Work From Home policy is very lenient, even for non-managers/Early in Career folks. The people are also very understanding and caring. You can tell from the way they are handling the lay-off's during the COVID19 pandemic that they truly care (extending their employement period, etc.)

pros: Great WFH policy, supportive environment, good compensation package

pros: As a seller you have the opportunity to help literally every single one of your customers due to the huge product portfolio of Cisco. The products are loved by our customers. The pay is above average along with benefits.

pros: Culture, Campus, Stability, Work life balance, Market leader

review_title: Great Company, hard at times to stand out.
pros: Cisco has many pros for working there which is due to the size of the company, they can offer great benefits - Willing to hire new grads and give great new grad pay - Great benefits, time off, time to give (40 hours), and baby leave - They equip you with all the equipment you need to be successful - Leadership is very open - Laid off due to restructuring right before COVID-19 (Feb 25th) but they provided a tremendous package. - Work/Life balance is great if you set boundaries.
cons: - The pay starts great as a new grad but is quickly average competitive compared to jobs area the area. - Since the company is so large every position or opportunity you will see quite a bit of competition -Quite a lot of change happening within orgs. Large company, so this is to be expected. However, about every year you will experience layoffs in some departments, new managers, etc. - If you don't know how to network, learn it. That's the only way you can stand out in a company this large.

pros: Cisco lets you really get in deep on a team.
cons: It's highly team dependent. If you get a good team, great! If not, then try again. Cisco is huge.

Excellent healthcare benefits, paid time off. cons: Salary is more competitive in some areas than others; definitely less so in places like Silicon Valley. However other benefits may make up for this depending on what is important to you.

lting Engineer in Tampa, FL
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
I have been around a lot of large companies and I can't say I've ever seen anything close to this good. I had always been curious about working here, and I had read a LOT of negative stuff about the company. When i came here (red badge/contractor then converted to blue/FTE) i kept an open mind and tried to reserve judgement. my experience has been GREAT. It's not perfect, sure, but WHAT IS?! Great benefits great work/life payscale is good, but not top of the line for everyone. Great technology Great team members/work culture Don’t believe all the absurd doom and gloom blogs about this company. Yes, it’s part of their corporate culture to restructure and RIF, accept it and move forward. That can happen ANYWHERE!
Cons
WFH can be a double edged sword, and be isolating. Customers can be a pain and the Sales culture at Cisco can breed some real Sh*! heads, but that's not exclusive to Cisco either.

pros: You will have the true global workplace experience and the flexibility. Plus inclusion and diversity. Remote working option for up 70% of the time (if your line manager is OK with it) unless you are working for a sales function. You will have the advantage of running your own schedule. Let’s say if you have a training starting at 8pm because of the timezone difference you get to start working again around mid-day without needing any permission. Set Out of Office message and rest. Also vice versa. If you have team mates in different continents get used to being an super early bird, or late bird on regular basis.
cons: Cisco do lay-offs almost every year. Terminations are never based on performance. It’s purely budgetary or employees being at the wrong location/ working site.

pros: The incredible flexibility that Cisco allows to its employees: you can work from any location of your liking as long as you do your job.
cons: In Belgium there are less and less positions available.

review_title: Competitive environment, but rightfully voted Great Place To Work
cons:
ltant in Wellen, Limbourg, Limbourg
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Intra-company mobility, quality of staff, solidity of business and ethical principles, benefits. If you perform, you can do very well at Cisco and get a lot of satisfaction from roles as well as interactions with great colleagues.
Cons
Sometimes over-politicized, especially at mid- to senior levels. Can get in the way of swift and efficient decision making compared to some of its peers. Unfortunately Cisco has had to stick to its bi-annual limited restructuring exercises for the past 15 years as it is constantly trying to re-invent itself towards new business models. Creates stress amongst employee base.

review_title: #WeAreCisco - and I love where I work
pros: Cisco are really going places with their portfolio of hardware, software, and services. We are really looked after with our people deal that includes great premium healthcare, pension and other perks which makes one want to stay with the company. The people culture is also great thing. Colleagues like to embrace new ideas and concepts, and will support new initiatives.
cons: As a large corporate, it does take a while to understand where colleagues sit within the organisation, geography and function. With any IT Telecoms vendor, there is no such thing as a normal 9 to 5 job, and one can find working longer than an average working day, however the reward for doing so far out ways this small sacrifice.

review_title: Flexible workplace with lots of opportunity

Strategy cascades down from leadership empowering everyone to be able to make decisions that tie back to the company goals and customer success. It's a fast moving, hard working company that rewards employees based on success.
cons: It's a big company, you might be a high performer and have accomplished great things in the past but if you move to a new org it can be like you are starting a new job.

review_title: Good work-life balance, lack of job stability and transparency
pros: - Good work-life balance, meaning most of the times no one expects you to work weekends and after hours (may vary by BU or department, but most business functions are this way) - Lots of flexibility; personally had a lot of freedom to work remotely (there are a lot of people who work from home everyday) - Most people are pleasant to work with - Benefits are good
cons: - No formal performance reviews, hence no clear path to promotions or pay raises (it's very unclear what your bonus is based on as well and your salary will not be adjusted for inflation every year, maybe every couple of years) - Not a lot of growth opportunities; if you're lower grade-level you don't get a lot of autonomy or responsibilities let alone chances to voice your opinions - Layoffs happen about twice a year and no one is "safe" (have seen people who have been here less than a year get laid off, so being new doesn't give you an exemption)

pros: Opportunities to manage large teams and complex problems. This company does very interesting engineering work.

I know several woman engineering managers who complain of being over-loaded, under-leveled, and under-paid as compared to their male counterparts in the same org, doing exactly the same work, and sometimes even having a larger team. I know several anecdotes of male senior managers engaging in gender-discriminatory behavior & comments when it comes to compensation, growth, acknowledging achievements, and providing actionable feedback. Instead of supporting women in leadership and encouraging growth, Cisco is consistently burning woman leaders out. Go ahead and count the number of women who are at least one-level skip managers in an engineering team in Cisco. Hint - you may be able to count them on your fingertips.

pros: Very employee oriented culture, great life work balance, open culture
cons: Very large machinery - can be hard to navigate

lting Engineer in Morrisville, NC
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
- The bonuses are really good, if you work hard - Not expected to work after it's time to clock out - Weekend/Holiday pay is fantastic. You can earn so much more if you work a lot of weekends - Culture is all about being yourself, so you can be POC or LGBTQ+ and be in a welcome environment - Great benefits for health and dental, onsite medical and therapy - Certification discounts for any Cisco Certifications - Can use up all your PTO straight if you like, some people take a month off at a time - Good place to start for either those getting started in their career, or those that want to get their CCIE in a product. This is the fastest way to learn.
Cons
- You only learn the product you're meant to support, rarely the entire solution - No learning resources for the product you're supposed to support on smaller teams/products - Company is excited to promote products, then lay off team members *FOR* that product - Quarterly layoffs, but yearly promotion cycles - Weekend shifts are voluntold to you if you're on a smaller team, and aren't necessarily on a cycle (and you can expect to work every weekend. I just worked 2 months straight with 6/7 day weeks) - Business Unit/Escalation team will withhold information from TAC, which can keep us from being able to do our jobs - Any training will be sales training, and not support training, which means we won't know how to fix/tshoot problems any more than when we started. - The products we support are upsold and underdeveloped. You'll constantly find yourself saying "that feature isn't supported until a future release, even though the buttons are there and the documentation says how to set it up. Please don't use it as it's not production ready." - Burnout/turnover is high. It's nonstop when you work for Cisco. Don't expect to take time to study at home unless it's your passion, as everyone was usually too mentally drained at the end of the day. - Any time to study for certifications on smaller teams is impossible due to the sheer amount of work to do. On larger teams you can get time off the queue to study with management approval. Personal Experience: Was strung along for two years about a promotion, contributing to python IC and being the top case taker, but was still told "I can't promote you yet, even though you're at a starting pay grade. Next cycle, though." After being told that 3 times, and seeing two layoffs in two quarters, I broke out the resume. Because of all of the above, you'll find yourself working in situations where different levels of upper management will start to have daily calls on how to keep customers from pulling Cisco from their deployment, when in reality the product just wasn't ready to be sold to them.

review_title: Truly a great place to work
pros: Clean, uncluttered office with great views, intelligent use of collaboration technology, choose between an X1 Carbon ThinkPad or Macbook Pro as your primary laptop, good mobile/VPN access on tablets/smartphones so you can literally work anywhere on any device, diverse and inclusive culture, regular social events in the office (with wine sometimes), company-supported participation in mass events like SGX Bull Run, JP Morgan corporate challenge, up to 5 days of "Time to Give" which employees can use to perform volunteer work, company matches up to US$10K per employee for every hour of volunteer work performed, CSR activity included on every team offsite event, trustworthy and professional colleagues, regular communication from senior leadership, great internal platforms for learning, including access to LinkedIn Learning and other external learning platforms
cons: Sometimes complex internal processes, few opportunities for promotion (people tend to stay unless made redundant), very challenging business environment despite strong leadership in most market segments and solid product/solution portfolio

review_title: Enjoyed the work, detested the manager politics
cons:
ltant in San Jose, CA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Telecommute, worked with global team colleagues, my team always had each other's back ALWAYS.
Cons
~45% of Cisco workers are "contingent" (contract); the majority should be full-time employees. Too many managers are way too political and are here for their own self gains even by stepping on employees who work for them, my level of trust with most managers was low; I will say I had 2 managers I would follow to the end of world (one was a Sr Director and one was a Sr Manager - fabulous, this was 6 years ago and they are now gone, they had 20 years at Cisco). Some managers I questioned (to myself no one else) why they had their role and it was clear they had connections and were "covered". I've been in IT for over 25 years and Cisco is the worse I've ever seen. I have this love/hate relationship: 1) I need to telecommute (EXCELLENT) due to family; 2) Cisco treats employees as replaceable cogs (BAD) in a machine, raises may take 3-5 years to get one. Yeah, it's a right to work environment, this isn't Cuba. If I'm expected to be loyal and jump when they say jump, I expect management to do a better job of supporting their charges. Like I said, not all are bad, but too many, IMHO, are. I've been a manager and leader, and have always respected and supported my charges.

review_title: Great leadership, amazing coworkers, excellent benefits
pros: Senior management team is knowledgeable, transparent, sincere, and has successfully seen the company through many transitions. Co-workers care about their work, help one another, and strive to achieve high quality and innovation. The benefits and flexibility are excellent and are a tangible way the company shows respect and care for the individual. I love Time2Give (1 week of time off so I can give back to the community), parent / grandparent time off when a child is born, global focus on reducing waste / carbon footprint (i.e. composting of food scraps at some sites), and on and on.
cons: It's a large company, there are some inefficiencies, some competition between business units, especially at the middle management level.

review_title: Love working with great people and products
pros: * People: Great people to work with. By far the most amazing team I have worked with. By the way, I had left Cisco and, after 1 year, I came back because I loved working with my current group. The culture shift is refreshing. Be a part of it. * Products: Amazing range of products. And all of them are being inter-connected with one another leading to endless possibilities * Pace: Company is moving at light speed in developing/acquiring/integrating new technologies in networking and other areas. If you are in the right group, the pace is blinding (in a positive way)
cons: * There are still some teams with very slow pace and not eager to change. But the culture is changing positively * No free food. We have free snacks though. But honestly, free-food is over-rated!

pros: Company performance and bonuses have been strong in recent years but showing signs of slowing.
cons: Constant disruptive change - everyone is new to their role so no one really knows what they are doing. You have to be very politically savvy to succeed and being good at the details of your job can be more of a detriment to your career path than a benefit. Lots of opportunities at a entry/staff level but a huge bottleneck at the management level means good talent eventually has to either leave the company, move out of finance to operations (every VP has their own "Strategy" team to self-promote), or stagnates and risks falling victim to one of the nearly constant restructurings. 24/7 work culture can make it very difficult to take PTO and easy to burn out.

pros: In 1997 a friend offered me to join Cisco, and hence, at that time we started to speak about internet, so no info was really available to know more about companies as today. The offer was appealing and the job description very clear. 23 years later I still love to be in this company. changed 3 times organisation from IT, Sales to CX, took several jobs from Project Manager, to Regional IT Leader, Product Sales and Business Development. And hence, this is Cisco, you career depends entirely on your ambitious, you decide where you want to be. The company changed over the years and yes, we intend to say, where are the great days, although I strongly believe Cisco has a great future in front of it. But what I like most are the people, I made friends, and yes you can have friends at work, all over the globe. Another great thing of working for a global company. We are really One Cisco. And hence the perks are great, there is always better somewhere else, although the combination of general benefits together with social responsibility programs like 5 days a year to do volunteering, that makes you want to stay for a company
cons: Ok, not everything is great, like in any other company. Like we intend to be a virtual organization, it's has it's risk for disconnect with your peers. Yes, there video and we meet once or twice a year, you have to work on building your networks, staying connected "from a human perspective". Yes, when you are in sales, it's about the numbers and every week, every month, every quarter your counter goes back to 0.

review_title: Great in some ways, lame in others
pros: Huge focus on employee wellbeing, incredibly comprehensive portfolio. Great place if work/life balance is more important to you than outright earning potential. Strong and well trusted brand.
cons: Like many huge corporates there is a misconception at the very top that the brand will compensate for mediocrity. Consequently many of the employees are 'lifers' not terribly interested in pushing the business forward, especially in middle and upper-middle management. Tenure is worn as a badge of honour as opposed to outright performance. Aspirations are disappointing and the way in which people are measured and driven leads to a risk averse attitude in many based around their incentivisation. For instance a sound business case for high levels of growth will be rejected more often than not in favour of minimal investment and a risk free quota. The portfolio is not always the best or even in the top 3 or 4 yet carries a 'Cisco' premium. This is particularly true where the business is looking to maximise the return on legacy products (eg Firewalls and Routing & switching). Sales are often driven hard around these 'me too' offers at the expense of the next gen innovation. A great example of this is the market move to 'Software Defined' which caught Cisco on the hop - yet the speed at which they entered the SD markets would suggest the offers were actually there, they just were not being pushed for fear of impacting existing, legacy, revenues. Given Cisco's history as a market disruptor (IPT, etc) this is really disappointing. The business has become a proper geritocracy, merit and ambition taking second place every time to tenure.

review_title: Amazing company to be part of, empowered to work how I can be most productive
pros: I have stayed at Cisco 8 years despite many times being recruited by other large tech companies. I feel I am very fairly compensated for the work I do but mostly feel a strong loyalty to Cisco for how I've been able to achieve an amazing work/life balance through taking advantage of remote working. I've always worked for managers many states away, communicating regularly but not too often, by Cisco's HD video technology. I've never been micromanaged and always been empowered to work when, where and how I choose as long as I am performing and excelling at my deliverables. This has allowed me to very successfully transition in to my new life as a working mom where unlike most of my friends I haven't had to make the choice between career and present parenting. I can truly do both, even as a breastfeeding mother and didn't have to take a single step back. Maternity leave was ridiculously generous and long enough that I actually felt excited to come back to work (especially since I work from home near my baby and nanny). The other perks for new moms that Cisco provides are over the top generous between milk stork, $100 lactation store credit, stuffed animals and baby books mailed to my home, free lactation consultant, and more. So thankful for Cisco and the wonderful career, no, wonderful LIFE, working here has afforded me. No reason I wouldn't spend my whole career here as I believe these benefits are unique to Cisco in the tech world. Speaking of the actual work I've always been empowered and encouraged to pursue new and interesting opportunities across many departments and job titles. I've always been promoted and given raises before I even thought to ask for them. Cisco has treated me really well.
cons: Being a huge company there is some waste and duplication of efforts which can be frustrating at times.

review_title: Great Company to work for, but real Culture and Experience is dependant on boss/team
pros: Amazing company and outstanding senior exec leadership Really great co-workers Outstanding development and training programs Real diversity and CSR responsibilities which they take seriously
cons: New leadership in my division drastically changed the culture, trust and real employee experience, you need to ensure that the culture the exec leadership believe in is adopted through the organisation

review_title: Cisco Austin is a Crap shoot
pros: Worked for Cisco for over 10 years the best I can say Benefits are good.
cons: Worked for Cisco for over 10 years the best I can say Benefits are good. In Cisco Austin it is a crap shoot depending on the Business unit your team might be part off. Cisco Austin is practically a satellite location with the teams having to report elsewhere. So too much uncertainty Too political Too many re-orgs Pressure from leadership to work extended hours, I have seen some engineers work through the night Since Cisco is not investing heavily in Austin, they don't allow teams to grow locally. You will be under the gun to work almost daily and off hours with offshore resource in India and other low cost centers in Eastern Europe. Business leadership in SJ always pushing for moving work offshore.

lting Engineer in Kraków
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
The Cisco Krakow office is full of vibrant young and diverse people. The office is modern and it has all amenities you can think of. There are trainings happening all the time and opportunities to train or mentor others. Constant influx of young people with new ideas. Great work-life balance and there's an investment from the company in activities for employees outside of work. Lots of flexibility and possibility of partial remote work. For those who like travelling, there are a lot of opportunities to do so in projects.
Cons
No relevant salary progression, especially for juniors. People can be stuck with their initial junior position/salary for up to 2 years. Even though after a year these juniors are often taking projects by themselves and travelling to the customer representing the company alone. This results in lower employee retention. A lot of people leave after 1-2 years as other companies will give substantial pay increases. Software is a rather young department at cisco. While the networking department is often full of incredibly experienced engineers that have really deep networking knowledge, the software department is often filled with networking engineers that have no software background and that go to a couple of programming trainings (mostly python) to develop/support software. It's not a good place to work at if you want to become a better software engineer. Due to the rapid growth of the company in Krakow, a lot of managers that are hired that have no managerial experience. On top of that, they're often picked from the current senior engineers who not always have the necessary people skills, even if they're great technically. So there's a high chance you might have a bad experience with your direct manager.

cons: Top heavy company with limited talent cultivation. The way up is by leaving and being re-hired - says a lot about their self-assessment that they value people outside their company vs inside. There is no documentation of success, talent reviews, etc so when re-orgs happen, you have zero track record and no say in what happens to you role-wise. You are a new hire when you get re-orged with the same timeline reset before your career can progress. Unless you are a manager, you can go 5+ years without even a COLA. pros: There are a lot of business units in Cisco with a lot of projects, it's possible to move around to find team and project that suits one the best. Recently there is a lot of talk about AI and some teams are using it, others are exploring options. Benefits are good, four weeks of vacation, accrued PTO, not "unlimited" like in many companies, 4.5 % match on 401K contributions, bonus, better health insurance than many companies, ESPP - you can save up to 10% of salary to buy stock with at least 15% discount. Cisco gives the lowest price for last 2 years (on ESPP buy dates) minus 15%, nice. In most teams work/life balance is good. It's possible to work on really big projects and products that most of startups can't handle.
cons: It's a huge company, so there is more "paperwork" than in startups, reporting hours spent, creating and closing user stories and tickets... Also, there are slackers, and for long time those people can go by with doing almost nothing just because they are friends with their manager. Cisco has quarterly layoffs, usually small, once a year, in September to November a big one. Regardless of how much you contribute you may be let go just because the business unit is not as profitable as some others.

pros: At the level of policies(leave, compensation, benefits, bonus) this is one of the best companies to work for.
cons: Engineers in India are treated as second class citizens by some managers. If the manager doesn't feel comfortable with you(for some reason that he alone knows) and would like to exclude you he will play with your weaknesses rather than with your strengths. This is how its done. Its bit tricky but neatly done. Have patience to read. 'Certain people' will be allowed to work on technologies they already know of (at least to certain extent). Those 'certain people' will be given a good edge on the product knowledge, exposure to other teams, technical discussions, requirements etc., 'Other guys'(the second class citizens) will be given tasks on the technologies that they do not know. The timeline will also be short and the requirements will not be detailed enough. The 'Other guys' will need to go behind the 'Certain people' for the details. This will be like you're in mid of a dark forest. No one will ask whether you know the technology or not. Nobody will care whether you're interested to work on that or not. You'll simply be forced to do that. In a nutshell you'll be given work in a technology that you do not know, requirements that are not detailed enough and in a short timeline. If you're unable to do this that will be considered as a weakness and will be taken as a good reason for not giving you opportunity to work on technologies that you already know of, interested in and in which you've already proved your skills. The funny part is that the manager himself will not know the technology but he will stamp others who do not know the technology as weak guys and exclude them. Even when you express your areas of interest that will not be considered as 'Certain people' are already working on that. This double standard is so worse that if nobody in 'Certain people' available to do a work in a technology known to 'Other guys', it will be done even by some other team but never be given to 'Other guys' who belong to the same team. Ultimately, what manager wants out of you is the demotivation and he'll get that eventually. The 'Other guys' must work on the spill over work of the 'Certain people'. Thats what ultimately needed. I certainly don't understand why they recruit engineers in India and try so much hard to exclude them and deliver a crystal clear message that you are not here to do a job that you like to do. Your passion and interests doesn't matter. Moreover, false promises on opportunities will be given by the manager on some holiday trip which he forgets as soon as he leaves the city. So, do not trust the promises. The faith will go in vain for sure. In a nutshell, do better research on the team you're joining. Otherwise, you may regret it and leave soon.

review_title: Agreed that it is one of the best companies to work for
pros: Commitment to excellence is high. At the same time work life balance is valued. So it's hard work but they don't expect everything from you and compensate well.
cons: Similar issues you would find at brand name tech corporations but less of them. So, I barely notice the corporate bureaucracy. It's a big complicated company with a diverse portfolio of products. So, if you have trouble navigating and want a lock-step career, this is not the place for you.

review_title: Great Culture, Great Company, Great Benefits
pros: Benefits, recognition, internal opportunities, great technology, huge brand, happy customers, innovation, supportive environment, collaborative.
cons: A little slow like any other giant player, you need to be up to date to new technologies since they evolve very fast, need to be a bit political to move up, like any other competitor.

pros: Cisco has tremendous resources as a global company. Excellent work-life balance. Using collaboration tools, i am able to work from anywhere in the world to accomplish my role. I am also a member of Conexión, Cisco's Hispanic/Latino ERO. We help Cisco to hire and retain the best Latino talent as well as helping the Latino community at Cisco and our own neighborhoods. I am challenged daily to grow and stretch myself. My manager and peers value my input.
cons: Dealing with change in the corporate world is nothing new and Cisco is no exception. Some tough decisions have to be made in order to compete. With leadership and role changes being very fluid, you need to be aware and know how to cope with this.

pros: Cisco's reward system rewards high performers well. Cash bonus is generous.
cons: Can be stressful at times when projects are due but this is a norm for all jobs.

pros: A dynamic complex enterprise where you will have the potential to move upwards and sideways to enrich your career. Never a dull moment. My Hispanic/Latino background is appreciated and a value-added to the enormous melting pot that forms this genuinely diverse workforce.
cons: The weekly forecast calls... It is currently undergoing a significant transformation, which is causing a lot of growing pains everywhere. Too frequent restructuring causes a lot of churn in the employee workforce.

employee_title: Manager CX AMER High Touch Delivery
pros: Great environment All the tools and knoweldge you cant imagine Connecting people across all the countries At CISCO you grow as you want
cons: I will say is not a CON is becasue we are a world wide company connected with other industries and some times the relatioship with other economies is not health and some times impact CISCO Business

review_title: Challenging Work - Great Place to develop a career.
pros: My input is valued by my peers and my manager. I get challenged to stretch myself and grow daily. It is a true global company. Cisco is a global company and has tremendous resources. I am part of Conexión, Cisco's Hispanic/Latino ERO, We help Cisco to hire and retain the best Latino talent as well as helping the Latino Community at Cisco and in our neighborhoods. I also love the fact that I have a great work-family integration and balance. I use Cisco collaboration tools to execute my role from piratically anywhere.
cons: Change is always good but it seems like we are always changing at Cisco. Organizational changes happen almost yearly. We are going through a cultural change at Cisco and at times one can sense the "political" games happening behind the scenes.

review_title: This company is excitingly out of the ordinary, trust me!
pros: In a year, if you have the right personality, people will reach out to you to do exciting tasks, like flying to San Francisco to deliver a presentation on your culture and heritage, or you'll get invited to a social event nearby, or you'll be asked to be interviewed for a video about what you're passionate about in youtube and social media, with millions of views. In other words, there is NO shortage of cool stuff to do besides your day to day (which time you can manage on your own anyway). We're not just a networking company anymore, we're a technology company and yes it's a bit hard to get into the family, because we want the best skillsets and culture fits, but once you do, you'll be set for life!
cons: For your own initiatives, there is a defined budget (In my case it's about a thousand dollars a month) for you to travel places, pay for your hotels, meals and go execute on what you want or need to do for your job. This budget keeps employees grounded on the initiatives because if you want to do many activities, lunches, trainings, events, etc you're going to need to spend quite some money. Because the budget is set to a fixed amount you might feel constrained. However, In 13 years I have sometimes doubled and almost tripled the allowed budget and I've never heard even a peep from my managers. So use it wisely but don't be too scared of it.

pros: Good people, competitive compensation and opportunities to develop new skills.
cons: Company is always transitioning, great opportunity if you thrive during change and are well positioned.

review_title: Latino who has grown my 19 year career at Cisco in Europe, Latin America & US

pros: Love the working culture, the opportunities we are given to grow as much as we can, and also the proactive and caring attitude all employees have.

review_title: Live, Love, Lead at Cisco and Be The Bridge to Possible!
pros: Cisco is not only the greatest place to work at, but in fact, it is the greatest place to live your life - by learning, innovating, creating, sharing, leading and building an impactful and successful life - personally & professionally, for yourself and for others around you. I have been at Cisco 12 yrs+ now and worked in 2 different continents and 5 different teams and I am as enthused , excited and grateful for each day at work (if not more), as I was when I started. As a woman, as a professional, as a human - I have felt supported, encouraged, valued and challenged to be the best version of myself - through the experience, exposure and education opportunities I have been equipped, enabled and empowered with. All I am and all I hope to be ...I owe to Cisco and the people I work, live, learn, play, innovate and give back with.

review_title: The best company you can possibly work for!
pros: It's almost been 1.5 years that I started working at Cisco. I joined through Cisco Sales Associate Programme (CSAP). Here are a few highlights of my journey so far: 1. Being a fresher, I think CSAP shaped me to face challenges in everyday work and deal creatively with them as they come. A blend of classroom and On-the-Job training makes it such an enriching experience. 2. Its a place where you feel valued everyday and know that your work matters. 3. A whole ecosystem of support to help you anytime. 4. Its an extended family. A very motivated work environment makes you want to put your best foot forward. 5. Its an extremely collaborative environment where you work not only with locally placed teams but also with teams spread geographically! It enhances your experience all the more. 5. Its all work and so much more fun! Regular small activities, team building events, off-sites and get togethers ensure that you don't burn out and enjoy your work equally much!
cons: Like any other large organisation, there are constant leadership changes and internal restructuring which requires you to be an your toes and stay abreast of latest developments all the time. It grooms you in a certain way but might also cost you if you don't know how to deal with constant change.

pros: - Always surrounded by excellent colleagues who motivate me to pursue the state-of-the-art technologies (which aren't restricted only in network) - Workplace flexibility allows me to be well-balancing my work-and-life. Sometimes, I work very hard and feel tired, but on the other hands, I also have lots of time to develop myself by studying new areas of technologies and attending various external tech events. Cisco actively invests my development in any categories of technologies because any of them can be connected with Cisco's. As an engineer, this environment is very exciting and always feel fun to have been in the leading tech company.
cons: - It depends on the customers, but when they are less motivated to learn new technologies and just focusing on financial side, I feel boring and it is less challenging because the deals can be closed only by sales person. - Less salaries than account managers

pros: Good work culture and team was good

pros: Cisco encourages their employees to give back to community in every way possible. They give 5 days every year to all their employees to give back to a charity on the trusted list. Cisco cares about the health and well-being of their employees, but it's dependent on the location and region. Cisco encourages also to develop their employees professionally and personally, by offering learning courses on discounted prices through their internal program learning @ Cisco. Cisco allows relocating to a different region when possible. There are endless opportunities to learn and develop within Cisco, some are free and some are paid for. However personal and professional growth is granted when you join Cisco.
cons: Office politics within certain regions is unhealthy and impacts on the employee's mental health. Certain managers hires from within their nationalities and bring their favorite friends within their own management circles . Sales can be very tough and harsh for no reasons sometimes, just to prove that the manager has the upper hand & control on everything. Not all sales employees are fairly treated, I witnessed some are holding higher targets on low grades, while some are holding small targets on high grade, and the compensation difference is around 40% less for the people with low grades

pros: Cisco is an amazing company to work for! The benefits are incredible and stock options are wonderful. I came in through the CSAP program and the training was the best in the industry. The culture, people, and drive of the sales organization is top notch!

review_title: Cisco is a great place to work!
pros: - amazing culture and work environment - great motivation - always learning! - always getting the help we need
cons: - sometimes you feel that there's a lot of pressure and deadlines but your team is always happy to help

pros: One of the best things about working at Cisco is the friendships you make along the way. I had the opportunity to be part of a Cisco Sales Associate Program when I first joined Cisco. This program was a yearlong, worked alongside 50 other CSAPers from different countries and had 3 months intensive training followed by 9 months on-the-job training, working remotely with virtual teams. The wealth of experience I gathered on the job is extensive. Asides from being knee-deep in the technology and sales of that technology, I worked in the regional hub with teams of people from varying background and cultural experiences; this broadened my perspective to career and life. This experience I must say kick off my career. I am definitely a better employee because of this. If you are ever considering joining the CSAP program, my advice is jump right in. The initial days will be tough, stressful, annoying, but it is definitely worth it.
cons: Expect that the kind of culture you get from your cohort/ CSAP hub will change, depending on the country/hub you move to after the end of the program. Some of the fantastic culture you are you used to looses panache; this is common when you move from a larger hub to a much smaller one.

review_title: presales engineer working on datacenter networking solutions
pros: lot of travel, and working on exciting and challenging projects meeting customers and partners across a wide range of industries
cons: the processes in big companies are always hard to be dealt with but you get used to it and I really think that at Cisco it's not that bad

pros: Good environment to boost your career Exceptional benefits Good working culture
cons: Big target responsibility Quite some pressure of multiple stakeholders

review_title: Love people & technology? Love where you work
pros: If you love people and technology - Cisco is an excellent place to start, grow and extend into a role. CSAP (Cisco Sales Associate Program) - is a global accelerated program designed for you to learn and propel your career at Cisco. You are given the opportunity to gain professional certifications, travel and create worldwide friendship. This year long program was the perfect way for to start my career at Cisco. Cisco will allow you to move to find a role to suit you and managers are supportive for you progressing in your career path. There is a reason why #lovewhereyouwork and #wearecisco go hand in hand, flexible working is encouraged to help you work how and when suits you, Fun fund is what happens every few months to bond and have fun with your team mates. If people culture is something you are looking for in your career, Cisco is where you will be made to feel at home with a new Cisco Family.
cons: As with any big company; restructuring, politics and change can majorly impact careers but this is not unique to Cisco. Change in technology, change in workplaces will happen in any field this is not something to fear.

review_title: CSAP Program for early in career candidates
pros: Cisco Sales Associate Program is a great chance for new graduates/young professionals to start strong career path. I was a part of it as a Sales Representative. During the year Cisco was massively investing in my learning and development, both sales and technical. We had professionals and coaches working with us from all over the world, best in class. The most important thing is to stay active and absorb this year as much as possible. Moreover I was having several mentors from my country and from the hub, whom I could always ask for help and additional explanations. Not to forget one of the most fun part of the year - is that I met a lot of knew people with whom we spent most of the time traveling, hanging out. Some of those people became very good friends of mine.
cons: Moving to another country or even continent for the whole year was difficult for someone. But it truly depends on the person and his/her attitude.

pros: Cisco has a great work culture. Employees are very helpful and care about each other. If you need help you can ask anyone. Very happy to have these colleagues, since a lot of my questions can be quickly answered due to the experience some others already have. Besides working hard, Cisco also makes sure that the work/life balance is good. They do this by organizing regularly drinks, parties and family events such as Sinterklaas and a summer BBQ. Besides that we have a yearly sales event in Vegas, this truly shows that the management want to invest in us to keep up our knowledge and get excited for the new fiscal year.
cons: At the end of the quarter it can be very busy with regards to reaching your and your team's target.

pros: Cisco is a great place to work because you get to work in world's N1 networking company with the coolest people. Your colleagues are always ready to help and support. You always have a chance/urge to improve yourself professionally and company will help you with that.
cons: You can't be satisfied with your current knowledge. You will always have to improve it.

pros: Fantastic organisation with a huge amount of opportunity, not just within your day job but also outside. Great travel opportunities, giving back, company events etc. Fantastic scope to develop your career - I personally enrolled on the graduate program CSAP, which is known as one of the best sales programs around and for a very good reason! It is also highly regarded throughout the rest of the organisation.
cons: Lots of decisions are made out of the states often with their best interests first.

review_title: Great company to start your career at!
pros: Culture, Flexibility, Cisco Sales Associate Program for early in career, ability to work remotely, managing your own business within the company makes you feel like in control.
cons: Still a heavy corporate vibe as opposed to some other tech firms Numbers game

pros: I started at Cisco through the award-winning Cisco Sales Associates Program (CSAP) and the amount of investment that Cisco put in to transform us into Cisco-grade engineers was unbelievable. There is always help around the corner only if you remember to ask! As an Associate Systems Engineer, I was trained on Cisco's vast portfolio including Enterprise, Security, Data Center and Collaboration tools. We were encouraged to complete CCNA and CCNP certifications. The work-life balance is probably the best thing about Cisco, next only to it's multi-cultural workforce. Shout-out again to CSAP that makes Cisco one of the best places to start your career at.
cons: Leadership changes mean changes in the goals we're trying to achieve but in a dynamic industry like ours, I believe that's a necessity.

pros: Very focused sales organisation Good benefits for Sales people and a good incentive program for people who have achieved their numbers Flat organisation and high level visibility if you are a performer.
cons: Pressure could be high at times, Might have to work through weekend at quarter ends and year ends.

pros: 1) Joined Cisco through one of the industry's best early-in career program called CSAP (Cisco Sales Associate Program). This extensive 1 year training program includes a 6 month on-the-job experience & prepares us for field role. This program infact accelerates our career & gets us at par with a 5-8 year experienced Systems Engineer role. 2) The culture of the company itself is to nurture each-other & grow together. So all the colleagues , mentors & managers are extremely supportive , guiding us to climb the ladder of our career 3) As a part of technical pre-sales, I get the exposure to both crucial technical design discussions & the business side of the company.

pros: The people and culture at Cisco are incredible. The office has a very modern and progressive feel to it. The company makes you feel very proud of your choice to work here. The executive team are really down to earth, genuine people
