review_title: A great place to work if you can handle 'limited restructuring' every 6 months and you're not a contractor.
pros: Fantastic on-site accommodations Excellent work-place environment Exposure to cultures from around the world Excellent place to learn & grow your career
cons: Layoffs every 6 months do not inspire confidence in employees who survive the culling. Sense of direction seems to be the equivalent of shooting a pellet gun in a dark room. Executive level leadership changes direction just about as often as they lay off blue badge employees. VP and above level management gets shuffled often, when you just start to establish a reputation with your superiors they either leave the company for greener pastures or are effected by 'limited restructuring' The ratio of contract workers to FTE (full time employees) is too high. Not enough opportunities for contract work force to obtain an FTE role w/benefits. I DO NOT RECOMMEND WORKING HERE IF: You're looking to make a 'nest' at Cisco and stay long term via starting out as a contractor, you'll never get converted to FTE. You're a contractor.

pros: Excellent campus, at least at Cessna in Bangalore. Excellent cafeteria, both in terms of variety and quality of food served, at least at Cessna in Bangalore. Free subscription to SafariOnline, Lynda.com, Udemy.com, Plural-Sight.com etc Excellent cab facility, though the charges that contractors have to pay to avail the facility is exorbitant. Unlimited Work-From-Home options, flexibility to arrive and leave from office any time that suits you. Reimbursement of broadband expense, good insurance coverage including parents, spouse and children. Absolutely no dress-code, you can wear anything you feel like including shorts.
cons: Major re-structuring and consequent layoffs practically every quarter in all locations and all BUs (and an annual big one around Diwali/Oct-Nov time-frame). Exceptionally top-heavy organization where hardly any work gets done. If you are politically connected well, you will stay otherwise prepare to get fired. Useless long-timers as managers, who keep firing people based on their likes and dislikes of people. Dis-proportionately large numbers of Contractors as compared to FTEs (at least in Services/CX) which shows the lack of any long-term vision. Marked discrimination between FTEs and Contractors in terms of treatment meted out (I was an FTE, so its not a disgruntled Contractor ranting). Absolutely no touch with HRs, they only interact with you on the day of your on-boarding and thereafter only when you raise a case which will be responded soon enough. Beyond that, no interaction, to the extent that there is no Exit Interview either when you resign. No onsite, at least none in IT. No hikes every alternate year. And promotions are next to impossible, and even if you do get promoted do not expect any increment in package. Conversion from Contractors to FTEs is a myth (almost never happens, at least in Services/CX).

pros: Lots of downtime. Nothing is good here if you are driven.

review_title: Great company for early in career!
pros: Cisco is an awesome company to start (and grow!) your career. The culture supports and encourages internal movement, so whether you join in your dream role and stay, or decide you want to switch to a different team and learn a new part of the business, you'll find your home at Cisco. Another benefit is the opportunity to work with peers around the world using Cisco's own collaboration technology and build a diverse, global network.
cons: Not all companies are perfect. Cisco could do better when it comes to standardizing on-boarding for new employees and explaining pieces of the business, especially to people just starting their careers. But the Early Career Network is a great global resource for those who are new to Cisco to build a cross-functional network and start to feel engaged and involved with the company.

pros: This is a great place to work for anyone that is looking to continually better themselves. The growth opportunities are never lacking from a technical, management, or personal perspective. Everyone here wants to help make others around them better and they take work-life balance extremely serious.
cons: continued development is expected - not really a bad thing :)

pros: Cisco is a great company! I have worked at many different companies including start-ups and other mature companies. I will be at Cisco until I retire. Cisco does an outstanding job at giving employees the freedom to deliver to their full potential and rewards excellence. Many companies claim to encourage upward mobility but never deliver. Cisco has an incredible amount of opportunity and every leader I have encountered at Cisco actively encourages her or his team member to prepare for the next role. Additionally, There are many avenues to share your ideas and execute on them if they make sense. Cisco celebrates diversity and has “ERO” groups to connect people of different backgrounds with each other. As an Air Force veteran, I am a member of the “Veteran ERO” and am always uplifted by the many initiatives and opportunities we have to celebrate our fellow Veterans and fallen Heroes. Lastly, I have never been at a company that has such an incredible culture of lifting each other up! We all need help and advice at times (in technology, probably more often than in other industries!). Most other companies have a few people you know will help you and not make you feel like a burden. At Cisco, it is RARE to find someone who is not overly eager to help, point you to someone who will help, or help you find the right resources. It is humbling to ask a question and immediately be in touch with someone who authored the book on a subject! As a large and successful corporation, benefits are very good and employees are given the necessary resources to succeed. We work on the newest technologies, with modern processes that help Cisco (and us as employees) to stay ahead of the curve!
cons: If you are not accustomed to change, you may have some challenge getting used to work at Cisco. Our leadership does a great job of staying relevant in the industry (our market share and market cap shows this). To do this, we are in a constant state of change. You basically have to hold on tight and enjoy the ride!

pros: Less hike , Little Politics in upper management , Hire and Fire company but gives good compensation while firing.

And Cisco is in a unique position to help veterans find a rewarding career in technology by providing access to both learning opportunities as well as connections to our partner ecosystem.

review_title: Great place to work if you can own your career.
pros: I have had a great experience at Cisco for the past 6 years, moving from contracted employee (red badge) to full time (blue badge). Full Time means much less of the 9-5 hourly requirements that contractors have and a job based on deliverables and owning your time. By that I mean I have flexibility to set my schedule to make child drop off, personal time and other scheduling things without managers approval as long as I am staying on task. The ability to access the huge amount of Cisco and 3rd party training for free as an employee has been a major bonus. The yearly benefits like health/dental/vision, matching 401k and stock program are of high value. If you work at the larger offices (San Jose or RTP) the onsite amenities (cafe, gym, medical, etc) are top notch. Salary can vary widely, but I feel they are consistent with tech companies in the area. The annual bonus is split into 50% in the Spring and 50% in the Fall. Bonus is dependent on Company and personal performance. Employees are encourages to give each other recognition from $25-$500 in the form of a gift card for a job well done. I do value the way we treat customers and follow up to solve problems. We do the right thing and I would not be here if that was not the case. There are plenty of alternative careers within the company if you feel the need for change. Managers will support your path from my experience.
cons: You can get lost if you do not focus on your skills and creating visibility to your work. There is always an org change on the horizon, so you may change managers and job titles often. There are layoffs about once every 1-2 years. They can target the whole company or specific organizations. They will feel harsh and not based on performance and value, but the company is always changing and answers to shareholders. The constant change has led to very little feedback or official reviews for me. I have been fine, but this may be an issue for folks craving feedback.

review_title: Great Culture, Good Vision Tarnished by Constant Layoffs
cons:
ant Layoffs
7 Nov 2018 - Director in San Francisco, CA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
CEO Chuck Robbins has clear vision for future Intelligent acquisitions to accelerate into Cloud / XaaS space Focus on Customer / Customer Experience is sincere and gaining foothold (vs product / engineering led) Culture - you're part of something and teams support each other
Cons
Layoffs, called "Limited Restructuring" occur like clock work every 6 - 9 months, usually in September/October and February/March. These have happened consistently in the 6 years I've worked at Cisco. It's demoralizing, erodes the strong culture and instills a sense of inevitability for employees Limited advancement opportunities to Director, VP and above levels - and, annual layoffs at these levels, not tied to performance, but for "organizational health" (ie balancing the senior positions to early in career and junior employees).

pros: Flexibility PTO Vacation Time Off Autonomy Smart People!
cons: Upward mobility - Lay-offs/restructuring every year

pros: 1. Great benefits 2. Remote work is available 3. New programs intended to help build your career
cons: 1. San Jose based mentality is pervasive. If you are remote, you are almost always forgotten. Promotions outside of the valley are extremely rare. An employee that worked with me was told by her HR representative that she was "easily replaceable" with someone in San Jose. (Cisco HR is absolutely the worst!) 2. New programs to promote diversity and inclusion seem to pop-up every 3 months, but gender equality is all talk. More women are laid off than men every cycle, and promotions for women come at one quarter of the pace to men. (This is more likely due to the extremely low percentage of women in general) 3. Age discrimination is rampant. Seniority (or experience) matters for nothing - new employees (usually through start-up acquisitions) are consistently favored over long-time employees for new positions. 9/10 times younger employees are not 'restructured' given that they are comparatively inexpensive and generally easy to relocate (if need be). Given how complex and complicated it is to get anything done at Cisco, this slows down the flow of business every lay-off cycle, and creates a self-fulfilling need for restructuring.

pros: good compensation benefits and very good and talented technical staff

review_title: For me, this company represents more than the perfect place to work
pros: Great people, who are knowledgeable, open-minded, friendly, family oriented. Company is superbly organized in "everything", from processes, to documentation, learning portals, support and training systems, just every possible thing you can imagine. Good benefits and pay. Status symbol. This actually goes a long way, since people you do business with will treat you better, and seem more open to suggestions and listen to you well
cons: None during my 3 year contract there. Although while working at the Korean office, some people had bad work place manners (had a meeting room scheduled for an important client webex, and the lady overstayed by more than 30 minutes and just WOULD NOT leave the meeting room. But then again, I guess that's the "Korean" work culture/manners, since that seems to be accepted as "normal" behaviour. Not much career opportunities if you're based overseas.

pros: The company in my experience took great care of its employees. The pay is competitive the the benefits were generous. I was thankful for the opportunity to rotate to different teams and gain such valuable experience.
cons: It's not specific to Cisco, but rather to a difficulty in many corporate stuctures - it seems challenging for later-career folks to continue to find meaningful, rewarding ways to contribute. I felt as though, unless I achieved a director or VP position later in my career, it would be an uncomfortable place to be.

review_title: Mixed experiences - much like most large enterprises in transition
pros: * Good work life balance * Competitive starting base salaries, but limited growth thereafter * Good benefits (dental on site, good gym etc. at San Jose office) * Working in headquarters is a good experience, but given the siloed nature of roles, you'll almost never meet a sales person in your office location * Great ecosystem of Cisco products for collaboration * Product Managers are given autonomy for the P&L of their product.
cons: * Quality of peers - Many people in power are just coasting in their career. Unfortunately, the commitment to a role at Cisco Product Management is proportional to how deeply engaged someone has been in the technical realm. There are too many people who have gotten into power just because of their relationship skills, and offer little or no value addition. On the other hand, people who have some technical acumen want to consolidate their position to ensure they're not laid off before their retirement. Creates a really weird culture of limited sharing and silos. * Very frustrating on how slow things move * Engineering used to be great, but is not any more and the company is not really equipped for its transition to software * Young people are discriminated against - that Cisco doesn't hire undergrads is also a problem since there are some really easy job functions that could be a good learning opportunity for early-in-career professionals * Negotiate all you want for the starting package, because you're not going to get appraisals for a while * Very limited diversity for most job functions * Best time to join Cisco was 2 years back so that you'd be at the peak right now. Unfortunately, assessment of company in the next 2-3 years is grim given recent innovations.

pros: Cisco has a great culture - we encourage our employees to be active in their communities and to volunteer, we have a strong team environment, and we are encouraged to innovate and take risks. We have great collaboration tools that allow many employees to work remotely and we do encourage work/life balance. I love my team, my peers and the future of Cisco as a leader in technology.
cons: Learning to navigate your way around Cisco can be a challenge. It is a very big and complex organization, but your teammates will help you! There are pockets of bureaucracy and legacy behaviors that we could improve on. We need to integrate some of our tools and become more cutting edge.

pros: What I really appreciate at Cisco is flexibility. I decide how I manage my work and personal commitments, whether I work from office or home. I need to deliver on my tasks in time agreed. There is great trust put into employees. If I have to take care of a personal situation, I can do it when needed. Other positives include good benefits package (Time2Give - extra time off for volunteering; meal card, connect card, pension scheme, birthday day off, and many more). I enjoy the culture of the company - I truly feel empowered to engage into activities related to inclusion, diversity or giving back, on top of my regular work responsibilities. Cisco also offers lateral moves, so one has good opportunities to build a diverse career here.
cons: The workload can be overwhelming, and management is not always on top of the things; yet all of this can be worked on.

review_title: Finance at Cisco Systems Is A Great Place to Work!
pros: Job Rotation is the only reason why I've been here for 18 years! Once you master your role--usually in 3-4 years, then you can rotate to a new role where you can take on more responsibility and learn new skills. This has allowed me to take new roles without changing companies and I've been able to carry over things like equity, PTO, etc.
cons: In the past I've taken some parallel positions just to learn something new. It may be that If I had stayed in a role for a longer tenure then maybe I would have been promoted faster--but who knows.

pros: I've been here 10 years and leadership has really worked hard to improve things like leadership transparency, diversity at the top, employee benefits, etc. I'm grateful to be working for a company that always strives to be better!
cons: We have so many products and I dont think we do a good job at helping employees who aren't involved in products directly to really know what products we have and what exact impact they have (Cisco Kinetics, Connected Health, Cisco Remote Expert, Tetration, Firepower just to name a few....)

cons: People Managers are not pushed to rotate, so little room for growth unless you decide to leave the company.

pros: Great team, people support, and fine cohort
cons: The growth maybe sluggish for those who intend to leapfrog in their progress ladder

review_title: Shocked at how much I like working at Cisco
pros: I was a small company girl, last year my company was acquired by Cisco, in candor I was very concerned about working at such a large organization. I was pleasantly surprised by how inclusive and supportive the culture was. I have never felt that I had as many opportunities as I do at Cisco. Of course it is also great to work for a company with as strong a brand as Cisco! The other thing worth mentioning is that at Cisco our team is so strong that when I went on vacation this summer, I didn't have to work! Being in Sales that is a first for me.
cons: Cisco is huge! That means sometimes the you have to deal with information overload.

pros: I have been at Cisco for over 11 years and I have loved every minute. I can honestly say that what I do matters every day in the lives of children, neighbors and communities. I help to solve some of the countries biggest challenges through the use of technology. I live and work with purpose.
cons: As for most top companies, Cisco sets the bar high and expects everyone to rise to the occasion. Although we have great work/life balance options, you have to set your boundaries and that can sometimes be a challenge.

pros: - Work life balance - Great work culture - Flexibility of Work from Home
cons: - Salary is below market standard -

review_title: Amazing Flexibility for this single mom
pros: I work from home, so I'm home when my kids get off the bus. When one of my kids has an appointment, there's no issue with leaving my desk to take him/her. I use my Time to Give (40 hours a year!) to volunteer at school, and to lead my daughter's Girl Scout Troop.
cons: Global workforce and remote working creates challenges for the team environment. Webex video meetings help, but there is nothing like spending time with your colleagues face-to-face. In my experience, upward mobility when working remotely is limited-- you need to work in one of the centers if you're looking for a management position.

review_title: Overall good company despite annual layoffs
pros: - Benefits -Stock -Mandatory holiday close during Christmas-New Year's -Great culture -flexibility
cons: Not all managers believe in the Cisco culture so they have a tendency to mircro manage and frown upon working from home. Work life balance can be blurred -

pros: Best company to work with
cons: heavy pressure in some period

review_title: Love to be able to work from home whenever I want to but be ready to manage your time wisely
pros: - My favourite thing is that I can work from home whenever I need to, and I don't need to tell days in advance. An email in the morning when I start working will suffice. This is very important for me as I'm not living in my country, and I travel often back to see my family and friends. - Management style is very positive (always trying to help you and making you improve, not nagging you or punishing you). They also try to make you grow with trainings or extra projects - You can always express your opinion and you will be heard - I don't have flexible schedule as my other co-workers (This is due to working in customer support, that it's not usually the case for other roles). As we are working in shifts, my schedule is 8 to 4. This is a blessing in disguise because at 4 I can close my laptop and go home and it's totally normal and acceptable
cons: - As you can get some extra projects to learn new things (and change the routine of your core job), you can end up having to work in your free time if you want to improve in your career, so you shine and have visibility within your team or worldwide. That's why you need to manage your time wisely and learn to say no. - The workload is endless. (This is due to working in customer support, that can vary for other roles) You cannot catch up will all the work, you just have to do your best every day. - Salary is less than average for the market in the same city (Happens worldwide)

pros: Cisco is a great company by many reasons: - Always a pioneer, listen to the market, anticipate, have a vision and transform the strategy to stay a leader - Provide all the technologies and work environment to their employees to be agile and productive. Well-being is become an important part of it. - We have the flexibility to work from any place and adapt our time based on our objectives, this is not so evident in another company, we have the privilege to have this opportunity and trust. - My BU leaders are great by well communicating our imperatives, critical objectives, campaigns linked to Cisco transformation - The green aspect, Impact initiatives with all the social parts, the diversity and the HR program evolution are just so important to my values. - I’m really proud to work for such a company.
cons: It’ in progress but there are still room of improvements. Managers role or Managers behaviors are not consistent. The importance to work in a healthy environment with good pressure have a good impact to a team and to the results. This is not the case everywhere in this might affect a career, a team and even the image of the company.

pros: Good package & benefits. Friendly & helpful colleagues. Good management team.
cons: Not challenging work - no scope to use latest technologies & advanced algorithms.

pros: I have worked at Cisco for over 20 years in development and services organization and it has been a fun ride. What I love about Cisco is that at its heart it is truly customer focused company. If what you are doing is right for our customers you don't need to be a "somebody" to make it happen. As a woman there are two things that I really like about Cisco: #1 - If you get results, you will be rewarded. I have had good career progression by working hard on important things. #2 - Workplace flexibility, we have all the tools we need to work wherever and whenever we need to. This lets me work hard and balance being available to my family. The other thing which I love, love, love about Cisco is its commitment to giving back. This is part of the DNA of the company from the beginning. I call it "entrepreneurial CSR" because the company just encourages us to "go for it" and follow our passions in giving back to our communities. We get 5 days volunteering per year which the Cisco foundation matches with a cash donation for every hour we volunteer.
cons: Change - if you don't like change, this is not the right place for you. It is important to be flexible and to be a constant learner to be successful at Cisco.

review_title: An amazing place to work with amazing people!
pros: There is an inherent trust that everyone will give their best in a flexible working culture. Being accepted for who you are and being encouraged to bring your whole self to work is another plus. Giving back is a huge priority for Cisco and everyone is encouraged to get involved in volunteering which I love!
cons: Flexible working conditions mean sometimes it does feel like you are 'always on' but it's a small price to pay for being able to fit work into your life rather than fit your life around your work.

pros: Cisco is a progressive and innovative environment to work in. There are opportunities to challenge the status quo and the freedom to make your role the way you want it to be. It is a very supportive environment where employees are looked after. I feel that my skills have grown a lot working here. One of the greatest benefits is the trusted environment which allows flexible working. As a mother of 4, which a 1 year old going back to work full time after maternity leave, this has been a great benefit. Like anything, this is built on trust and high expectations of high quality work being met. It doesn't get boring, there is constant change.
cons: Like any large company, there are politics and levels of bureaucracy. This can be very frustrating, but it's hard to find any larger organisation where this does not exist to some degree.

review_title: Diverse and great place to work
pros: People, Culture, Diversity, Technology, FUN, Great Place for Early in Career (CSAP Program is A-M-A-Z-I-N-G) and young professionals.
cons: nothing really come to my mind now

review_title: Women in Technology - Great place to be!
pros: This company is by far the best company I've worked for, and I've been in the technology industry for 20 years. Our leadership is strong and diverse, and the amount of visionaries that lead the charge on technology is amazing! Working for an industry leader across multiple technologies/verticals gives you insight into the macro environment, rather than just little niches of a challenger brand. Compensation is on par, and financial benefits (ESPP, stock options, 401k) are excellent. The company also has a heart -- and puts its money and time where its mouth is. Volunteering is encouraged, and the opportunities are endless to give back to the community and the world (and in ways that are important to YOU).
cons: Being in sales, it can be all-consuming, but 'work-life integration' is possible. One has to be comfortable with change -- as "sameness" isn't an adjective that I would use to describe the environment. The organizations change and shift very dynamically to adapt quickly to the marketplace and to demands on the business.

pros: True working flexibility, the people and benefits really make Cisco a great place to work.
cons: None that I can think of!

pros: Good salary Good workplace Cutting edge technology
cons: Work life balance is not manageable

pros: Impatient company that wants to change and adjust and lead in new markets
cons: Still very biased company with some managers making discriminatory remarks to and about women several times a month.

pros: - Amazing opportunities to move around - Great collaboration potential
cons: - Management (Few of those)

pros: Biggest networking company in the world
cons: Team alignment issues, reward based on subjective criteria

pros: work life balance. team collaboration.
cons: salary may not be at par with other Si company. no merit base promotion.

pros: - Salary - You will be surrounded with the best talents in the business. - Opportunity to be great is limitless. - Very minimal office politic. If you want to achieve greatness, you have to path your own way. People will notice your work.
cons: - It's a big organization, so one might lost his/her way to navigating his career without support from senior employee. Find the right mentor and in Cisco you have the freedom to find your own mentor to guide you.

review_title: Everything you look for in a company!
pros: Work/life balance As a Latin@, I feel included & can celebrate my culture Company organizations like Conexion are so helpful and inclusive Work from home Work remotely from anywhere Great benefits Awesome opportunities to learn & training Awesome managers Bring dogs to work!
cons: Huge company, easy to get lost if you don't pay attention

pros: Amazing opportunities for growth and development. I've been here a while and have had the chance to take on a wide variety of projects. Not all managers are as incredible as mine (supportive professionally and personally, encourages agility and defines fail as "first attempt in learning") but the tools are all here for employees to be the best they can be. Executive leadership is second to none.
cons: Because many (not all) employees can work remotely, it's difficult to connect to coworkers. While it's great to have the flexibility, we have to work harder at establishing and maintaining a unified sense of commitment.

pros: Team-oriented culture, amazing salary and bonuses, global reach and opportunities, committed to professional development, opportunities to learn new skills
cons: Large organization can mean we're slower to move

review_title: Best Place I Have Ever Worked
pros: Extreme communication to employees, all employees are valued, liberal views, ability to continually develop, educational opportunities, growth opportunities, flex time, work from home/ remotely, global, Cisco campuses are modern and have great features, volunteer opportunities and paid time off to volunteer, paid birthday day off, bonuses, employees can monetarily recognize fellow employees (connected recognition)
cons: Too many contract employees leads to less opportunities for permanent positions and instability in the knowledge and workforce in place, pay raises are not a regular yearly practice, too many "restructures" too often

review_title: 19 Year Cisco Veteran in IT, HR, L&D, Finance... and Still Counting!
pros: I think most folks know by know that Cisco is a great place to be in regards to workplace flexibility. You can pretty much do your job anywhere in the world where you have a decent internet connection and are willing to be flexible with your working hours. I'm still at Cisco because the mentorship, support, development and career opportunities have been amazing for me. You have the opportunity to be exposed to different parts of the business, develop a passion for it and gain experience, then find a job with that group. My interests and experiences have lead to some really great roles at Cisco, not always doing the same thing, and for the most part - the managers are supportive. As a female, I have rarely if ever encountered a situation where I felt discriminated against. I've had support to work in different countries and been given time for personal development, support to achieve a post-graduate degree or just time off because I needed it.
cons: Not everyone gets to have the same great experience, and yes your organisation and your manager can impact this. However it's also up to you in terms of what kind of career you want to have here and be proactive about it. Extend yourself a little more - you need to give in order to receive. Admittedly, there can be some administrative things that could be improved in the company - we don't invest enough on improving some of our internal processes and tools. However i understand that we're probably still luckier than other companies.

pros: Working with very smart, happy and motivated people; Interested in your personal growth; Strategy and GTM supports where the industry is headed; excellent opportunities for women; Provide excellent forums to keep all employees current on business priorities and company initiatives; Values "giving back" by matching donations and even giving "Paid Time Off" to serve.
cons: Working with such smart, motivated people can also be a little intimidating; Bigger companies take a little longer to get things done (no different than other big companies)

review_title: Everyone is so helpful and positive! A refreshing change!
pros: The people 100%. Everyone is so helpful, positive, and extremely smart so they make me want to improve every day. The benefits and pay are awesome. The time to give and volunteer policy shows that they care about helping the world improve, some of the stories are incredible! They provide communications and trainings on the latest changes to the products and processes so we are up to date. The internal communication setup is far beyond anything I have seen, with Webex Teams we have a very intelligent setup to communicate with virtually anyone at the company and at any level of management. Lots of opportunity for growth, they encourage you to move up or around every 3 years to keep from getting complacent! I could go on and on.
cons: It's a very big company so of course there are things that are hard to scale. We have a lot of systems and tools so that can be challenging, but the team is working on reducing those. I'd say things change a lot continually but a lot of that deals with the industry we are in.

pros: Great job/life balance; career advancement, skill building, community volunteering all encouraged; helpful and respectful manager relationships
cons: Not really a con but new hires usually don't understand this process. Promotions and raises are not common during years with low corporate growth. Yearly raises are not a Cisco thing. Take that into consideration during salary negotiation. Otherwise, NO other cons.

pros: Excellent benefits, perks, team and atmosphere
cons: Growing super fast, so it is challenging to keep up.

review_title: Communications Team - a place to grow
pros: + There are many opportunities to grow a career here. I've participated in stretch assignments, rotational positions, and been on several communications teams at Cisco. + People here are genuinely helpful. This is especially important for new hires, b/c Cisco is a big company, but everyone helps you navigate. + I have had 4 great managers at Cisco in 9 years. Cisco invests in management and leadership skills, so I shouldn't be so surprised at the high quality managers I've reported into. + Cisco takes development seriously. The amount of learning offerings here is incredible! I've taken advantage of on campus Toast Masters, remote and in person speaking workshops, mindfulness training, and more. + Depending on the role and team, Cisco is a pretty remote-worker-friendly company. I love where I live, and I don't have to compromise that to give Cisco 100% and they get that.
cons: - It's a big company, so expect a process for everything. This is often actually helpful, but it's not for everyone.

review_title: Cisco - a great place to work or women
pros: Cisco is a great place to work for women. There is a real effort to make sure there are women in senior positions - and everyone is treated equally.
cons: There could be more job rotations

pros: Amazing culture and people at Cisco. Very good policies especially for women. Very active skill development and personal development program and great at allowing employees to explore their strengths and skills through stretch assignments.
cons: None I can think of

review_title: Great place for parents who need flexibility
pros: Many teams have flexible hours and locations, as long as you get the work done. When my kids are sick, I can work from home. When I want to take a longer break to visit my kids at school, I can. Cisco has high performing, dedicated employees, but that's only possible because they take care of their own.
cons: A pro and con of working at a global company is that you may sometimes have to take meetings at odd hours to collaborate with others around the world. At least you can do that from the comfort of your own home.

pros: Benefits, Team members, Great culture, Opportunities for growth
cons: Global roles = lots of travel

review_title: Great Culture - Challenging Work - Can Work From Home
pros: I've been with Cisco for 18 years in the engineering department working on a very successful product. The culture here is great - the company emphasizes work-life balance and giving back to the community. In many positions one has the opportunity to work from home, which is fantastic! We also have five days paid time off each year (in addition to our regular vacation time) to serve our communities through the charity of our choice. In my experience there is very little micro-management, the people are great to work with, and it is a very diverse work culture. I've learned to appreciate many cultures and I've traveled around the world to Europe, India and Australia in the course of my job. I've learned a great deal of technical skills through my years here and it is a fast-paced, challenging work environment. Our new leadership under CEO Chuck Robbins is focusing on innovation and simplification of our products and the investment community loves it (stock price up 45% this year)! The compensation package is great with excellent health insurance and 401k match. I love my job!
cons: Sometimes its difficult to get departments within the company to work together due to the tendency toward silos.

pros: Great flexibility and amazing work life balance Great career development and opportunities to grow Good benefits

ant Re-org
29 Sept 2018 - Senior Product Manager in San Jose, CA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Cisco is a great technology company and moves fast through acquisition. While that is good for business its not that great for employees, especially those who have worked there for a while. Every acquisition comes with a re-org. Plus there is constant churn at the VP/SVP level.
Cons
Un-due stress created for employees through constant re-org and resulting job cuts. Even in profitable businesses. Part of working for a company is a sense of trust that it has your back. In Cisco, its very clear to most employees that they cannot trust the company to take care of them. The next acquisition might take them out.

pros: Overall Benefits are really Good

pros: - Just brand name, legacy reputation, and big market capture in Networking domain. - It's a group of many small startups, say. So, if you fall in good BU, you will get good work, exposure, hikes, and live in peace. - Nice clean big campus, facilities, gym, office infra. - Pays huge to freshers from premium colleges, and to Senior Management.
cons: - Pays Low Salary as per market standard of Product companies. Lesser than some big service companies. Always postpone yearly hike cycles by 1 or 2 quarters. - Regular firing/LR. - Too much work pressure. Too many product lines make it difficult to learn for Engineers. Customer escalations, bug counts are day to day worries. Very few old employees left who know product details, so no one is there to help. - Managers & Sr. Managers insulate engineers from Directors & VP who are real decision makers for hike & promotions. So mid-level engineers suffer from both side (lot of difficult work, and minimal hikes). Managers take credit & themselves get promoted. - More suffering for people in Infra, platform, services, etc.

review_title: Never a better time to join to Cisco
pros: Great people - everyone is extremely helpful, receptive to new people, shadowing for different roles is easily accomplished Lunch/breakfast onsite - puts the word "cafeteria" in its place as it a food oasis in a desert of boring options Opportunities for advancement are tremendous as well as potential to move across the USA
cons: Small things but from where I live and what I've experienced: TP location can be good or bad depending on where you live If you're not a fan of Las Vegas you may not enjoy being there for 3 days every august (but if you love Las Vegas then Organization can seem a little disjointed, coming from an organization of 200 people to one with 18k just in sales things that came easy like HR requests, websites to find information can be daunting initially, and small employee changes and what seem like mundane processes take a lot more time than seems necessary - a lot of red tape... Several members of the SLT team in San Jose has left recently which can be slight uneasy but overall vision has remained stable

ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Cisco has made a huge investment in bringing a strengths-based approach to our culture and is backing it up in a myriad of ways - from processes that help leaders give the right kind of attention to their employees to investing in self-led learning for employees so every individual can continue to develop and grow in areas that are energizing for them. It is in the midst of a very exciting transformation with reinventing the Network, enabling a multi-cloud world, unlocking the power of data to inform AI, and deploying security everywhere. All this and amazing sustainability and giving back programs. The culture is amazing.
Cons
Like many organizations of this size there can be challenges with finding the right opportunities and being able to move with agility through the changes we are making.

review_title: Just like most other large MNCs
pros: Get to work on latest technologies
cons: -- The executive leadership say all the right things during internal all-hands meetings to make employees feel optimistic. But somehow, things don't seem to be executed to the bottom level. -- Directors reporting to directors and VPs reporting to VPs and some of these directors/VPs don't even have a team under them. Not sure why we need so many directors and VPs when we are not allowed to bring in skilled employees who can really contribute to the work. Excellent and and hardworking contractors eventually move out when another company is willing to bring them in as employees. And Cisco ends up losing productivity by having to search for and train another contractor. Happens over and over again -- When the company got a huge windfall from President Trump's corporate tax cut, employees were hoping we get to share some of that. Alas, the money was used for stock buy-back. Obviously, those holding large number of Cisco stock benefited the most. And guess who are the people who hold the largest amount of stock who enjoyed that windfall? Any special, one-time bonus or salary adjustment for employees to share some of that? Zilch.

pros: Depending on the Team, the technology you work on differs, but there is a great push to adopt new tech. Also there are many internal openings in various domains. The Campus is awesome, food delicious(not free but via food coupons) and lots of sports and relaxation facilities. They are very transparent about the Bonus component and you can be assured that your immediate manager cannot misguide you on how much you are supposed to get since the company performance figures are publicly shared. Transport facilities are really nice.
cons: Hikes might be bit disheartening if you are a top performer. Cisco does regular layoffs of entire orgs if they do not perform over a period of time. This might be a issue of concern if you land up in an underperforming product. However the layoff compensation is quite adequate and one of the best in the industry.

pros: Highly intelligent, very skilled individuals. Excellent flexible work practices which allow for a better work-life balance, although not perfect. Great benefits. New business model is moving Cisco in the right direction.
cons: Very little visibility and understanding of career paths. Not many opportunities for higher grades. They rather make them redundant then create opportunities.

pros: A year-long Cisco Sales Associates Program has been a life-changing international experience. The program takes all the efforts to make you a better version of your own self. It does so through assessed role plays, technical and soft skills training, which helps prepare for a career in Sales / Systems Engineering. Instructors and managers are seasoned professionals which not only make it challenging but also make it fun! It's a great way to develop yourself while building your network among the top university graduates from around the globe.
cons: It's hard to realize things come to an end, but you have to move on, great things are waiting for you.

cons: The company is $50B in annual revenue and still has some silos. Its incumbent position in most markets makes change hard sometimes.

pros: Good PTO (4 weeks per year) and bonus program. Flexible working hours and work from home is common. The company is growing again after several years revenue decline. The transition to software and subscription business pays off. Very good learning place for folks who just start their career as the company has good process and infrastructure.
cons: Multiple rounds of layoff/restructuring when revenue is down. Selective downsizing in certain business still takes place so that resource will be invested in new growth area. So it depends on the team you are in.

review_title: Not what it used to be and not for 'early in career' or upward focused
pros: * Pays slightly above market * Good work life balance * Generous work from home * People are generally pretty nice if a bit passive
cons: * No upward mobility. Absolutely zero. You will be at the same level you hired into * Boredom. You will be doing the same very narrow task again and again and again. Or you will be waiting for decisions from levels above you. * Very very siloed. Deliberately. You will probably have limited interaction with your immediate team. Pretty lonely * Annual layoffs. The behavior and performance problems are long gone and the people now getting laid off are bad fits for their organization. Why are they bad fits? pros: 1. Cutting edge Technology and loads of opportunities and challenges for learning and Growth. 2. Opportunities to work on High end system design and development with with really brilliant minds. Vast products and platforms to explore your skill set. 3. Collaboration to work with cross functional team and understand the end to end development flow. 4. Visibility and response from vendors, suppliers and customers with Cisco Brand. 5. Very good learning and development options for soft skill development. 6. Good work life balance if you well understand your role and have clear planning. 7. Wonderful campus and infrastructure and work place resources to balance your daily life.
cons: 1. Growth may be limited compared to SW groups unless you are absolutely extraordinary. 2. Recognition and pay is not up to the market standard for people staying for long compared to lateral. 3. No stock options for grade 10 or below. Your hardwork and effort will help to get good stocks for your lead. 4. So much process oriented which delays the timeline and execution. 5. Responsibility of the product release lies on the hardware engineer who had to literally drive other teams to get their work done. 6. Short product development cycle gives times pressure and impacts quality of the product.

pros: Cisco is a very good company to work for. There are countless smart people around that are willing to help. It’s an innovative company in either acquisition or development which means you’ll never be bored, plus we have excellent portals and content for learning. You need to acknowledge the days dedicated to “giving back” i.e 5 days for you to spend doing your chosen charity work. There is great flexible working and amazing tools that help make that easy. It’s a company lots of people feel proud to work for and many people spend a number of years at. Plus I’ve seen a lot of people leave and then come back because Cisco really is one of the best companies to work for.
cons: There are typical examples of inwardly focused management and intolerably lazy people but they can be avoided. My main wish is that it was easier to move around the world, you often hear that it’s very difficult to move countries which is disappointing given the company is so global.

pros: Great environment to work if you have a good management.

pros: One of the best training programs out there! You come straight out of college and have a one year long training program where you learn sales and technical skills. All of your colleagues are your age and you will end up forming a very tight bond over the year. You will also become a Cisco Certified Network Professional by the end of the training which is equivalent to a masters in networking. The benefits and bonuses are very competitive! Best year of my life and I can actually say I enjoy going into work everyday! :)
cons: Wish they had free food like a lot of the other startups in Silicon Valley. Politics sometimes get in the way of big decisions.

pros: I was part of an acquisition and really came to respect and appreciate the Cisco culture. In my experience over 5+ years in Supply Chain, the culture was great. People were always respectful of each other and worked to collaborate and build consensus. The pay and benefits were very good and the work environment was top-notch. I know there are many experiences in a large company, but in my case I can say it was 99% positive!
cons: Cisco is a big company, so the pace of change can be frustrating

pros: Flexibility, Benefits, Interesting People, Culture focused on the team
cons: Big company politics, lack of investment in basic infrastructure to keep current but that is improving

pros: People Fun Balance Accommodation Social
cons: On-boarding section done by Manpower

pros: Exciting - working in pre-sales, can be really enjoyable! Challenging - Makes me think, and often have to learn about new tech.
cons: Can be difficult to strike up a good work life balance.

pros: It's a very enriching experience both in a professional and personal level. Firstly, you can learn a lot about technology, sales and soft skills from formal learning and on-the-job experience. Secondly, you're surrounded by an international and diverse group of young professionals, which teaches you about dealing and understanding different cultures. Also, you build a very strong network around the world. Finally, you receive competitive salary and benefits while training.
cons: The training might feel detached from the every-day reality of your first position after the program. It will eventually make sense when you earn more experience and progress in your career.

pros: It is a great introduction to Cisco, with good opportunities to learn a lot. It is divided into three categories of learnings within sales acumen, professional and technical skills. Cisco invests heavy in the candidates and does not expect a short-term return on investment, so you will experience a really thorough program. There is great international opportunities and it is very easy to create a great network.
cons: Before you start to get commission, the wages are not that high.

pros: - The network you build up including the fellow interns, managers and even executives - Extremely well organised, with a dedicated team working on the internship for the whole duration of it. - Interesting accounts to research about and projects that make actual impacts. -Excellent culture -Covered all expenses, competitive pay, social events etc.
cons: - Workload is heavy at times and you may feel pressured.

pros: 1. Extensive training program. You will be a pro at the end of this program! 2. Exposure is enormous as we get trained with our colleagues across the globe. 3. You get paid to learn! 4. the instructors you will get will be the best in their field. 5. GSX! 6. the program not only focuses in technology but also the sales aspect. So you will be an adept tech sales manager. 7. the growth and opportunities are vast
cons: I seriously dont have any cons to write

pros: Intensive training on all the architectures by experienced trainers of Cisco including: EN, Security, Collaboration, Data Center and Service Provider Loved the whole program as it helped me to improve my technical and business acumen
cons: You will have to work hard to accomplish the goals, which in turn is for your own good. SO not exactly a con

review_title: Once great company now shedding everything, which was good about it...
pros: Highly talented people, good benefits and lots of development opportunities for younger employees.
cons: In Eastern Europe Cisco's senior management team is turning what was once a great, collaborative work environment where diverse opinions mattered into a military organisation where you're managed with a baseball bat and the managers who display the most disregard for people are the ones advancing their careers. Highly political environment (and not in a good way).

review_title: Slow strategic planning, intimidating work environment
pros: Industry leader in networking, strong presence in all market segments, diverse hardware and software product line
cons: Way too much inertia in responding to new technical trends and customer concerns, old, hacked up, buggy code base with insufficient refactoring to address weak areas, Way too much inertia in adopting and moving on new technical trends and market directions, too much infighting, intimidating management culture, no real performance review process, antagonistic attitude toward telecommuting.

pros: Excellent work life balance, flexible hours, great culture.
cons: Sometimes it feels like things are taking too long to get done.

pros: Stellar products, great brand equity with customers, opportunities to make money in sales, constantly innovating.
cons: More individual based than team. Very American in that sense

pros: -you can get onboard VERY quickly and all your devices and trainings can be ready in 1 week. -you can give feedback easily to your manager -The pay is good
cons: 1-Extremely stressful env EVERYthing revolves around quota and sales even if you are not in sales teams. but if you are not getting your Quota while you are not sales function it will impact your performance and your bonus. 2-In my interview i was asked if i ever worked with quota and I said no but when i started my job I found out that they added quota on me and its noncommissionble and must bring it each quarter. i disagreed and then I said if I work on quota then I need my commission.. Managers did not agree and I had a conflict with them. 3- The company has VERY high turnover from employees and contractors. its not easy to deal with too many changes per day and week and month. 4- They keep acquiring companies and its tough to focus on your role since every other quarter there is a new re-org and new policies. 5-The work pace is TOOOO FAST and the company has TOOOO MANY customer accounts and they expect you to over perform and do your 150%. All the team members and your other colleagues are not easy to meet and talk with them. Every thing is Webex and ALl the workers are overloaded with work. 6- Its nice to have many Tools to help you do your work like webex etc BUT its overused with all the teams. for example if you ask any question about anything they team member will answer you with list of ALL the webex recordings and links by the time you want to watch them and understand the answer that is like a week worth of things and the team member thinks he did the write think for you but really he gave you Major new work. 7- Too many trainings, by the team you do your internal meeting (physical or webes), then you calls, then your huge list of links and webex recordings its really tough to achieve during your day since all these things take your time and you may have time later on the day to do some of your work. 8- There are SO many feedbacks on you during the week and after each sessions etc etc you need to be always connected with the team and it feels that you ONLY live for Cisco there is nothing else to do in this life. 9-I have never seen a company that asks their sales team commitment calls to be WEEKLY. So the sales team are in MAJOR stress and they stress the other teams with them. 10- Unless you like that type of env and CONTINUES work , then I don't recommend that company for people with Family and kids and social life. I noticed most people working very long hours from 8am until OPEN. 11- Cisco has many products (old, new, acquired, etc) and once you join, they will buy new company and then new products. Most of these products work in theory but in real life and at customer site its REALLY complicated and tough and they may work but with a lot of difficulties and many Cisco internal teams involvements. its Tough technical env. with all these complications. 12- Cisco were a hardware company and trying to switch to software company and that is difficult and too many challenges especially they don't have the software company mindset.

review_title: Free thought not welcome in my experience
pros: I am supposed to enter 5 words for "Pros". Money.
cons: Everything else. An organization filled nearly to the rim with individuals that have never had a job anywhere else in their career or have not held a position at another corproation in the last 15 years that merely tow a corporate line with no room for thought that is diametric to Cisco's current fiasco. Any new perspective provided is immediately met with "anti-Cisco" sentiments. What is the point of hiring those with "outside experience" to only refute suggestions by stating "This has always worked for us" all the while conveniently ignoring your loss in market share and inability to innovate. Ok to be fair Cisco's idea of innovation is through acquisition. Good job, folks. The old timers need to be dropped and new fresh, clear minds that understand the newest generation of technologists in the industry. Old Cisco does not, or at least refuses to acknowledge, that these new generations approach technology, and problem resolution differently than their predeccessors. So new approaches are to be developed in both sales and product strategy within Cisco to address these needs. It is of no wonder why Cisco has been losing ground in market share and will continue to do so if their old timers are allowed to continue to operate at the regional level in positions of power.

pros: Flexible work week, work from home options. Challenging work, talented people. Opportunities to make a difference in the industry. Huge careers potentials with the right manager.
cons: Big company now so we've lost most of the "startup" mentality. Lots of culture dilution over the years from absorbing other companies. Too many management layers. Fewer career potentials when having the wrong manager.

pros: - Work from home policy is very flexible - Possibility to take leaves on a very short notice - Option available to buy more leaves - Any equipment that is needed for work can be ordered without any scrutiny. - Convenient location if driving from eastern part of county. - Work/life balance is acceptable. There is almost never any pressure to stay beyond normal working hours. - Great involvement in local community projects and charity organizations. - People are genuinely very nice and fun to work with. - Sports and Social club does a good job organising events throughout the year; there is however a membership fee to participate. - On top of the above there is a separate fund to organize team outings every quarter which are always good fun. - A lot of attention is given to constantly monitor and improve coffee machines.
cons: - Strange location for an IT company, in the middle of an industrial park, outside of town. Not a very pleasant place to go for a walk with trucks and forklifts roaming around. Oranmore village is at least 20 min walk away, which is a bit far if one wants to go out for lunch. That's also where the bus stop is, so it's something to consider if using public transport to get to work. - Canteen is very bad. The catering staff are trying their best, but are very limited with what they can do because the kitchen is very badly fitted out, so they can’t prepare any half decent meals. - Cisco is ultimately a sales, not an engineering company so while good engineering practises are appreciated by some, it’s not what necessarily gets people promoted. - Salary, promotions and opportunities are good if one knows how to play the game and gets noticed by the right people. - A somewhat weird/cringy ‘we are an amazing company’ attitude from some people. It’s disheartening how much self-affirmation we received from winning the somewhat irrelevant ‘Great Place to Work’ survey last year while conveniently forgetting that we were competing against some small insignificant companies. We are unlikely to stand a chance if the top US software companies (i.e. companies we should really be compared with) decided to participate in a survey like that. There was a time when they decided to start giving us a free bowl of fruit every day, which is a great initiative if it wasn't sold to us as the greatest thing ever i.e. on the same level of getting a free house. - Because we don't really having any real proper competition in Galway, the company gets settled in the virtual security offered by ‘we are good enough for Galway’ mindset that hinders any effort or initiative to continuously improve and yet wonders why it is so difficult to attract experienced people in the field to work here.

pros: Love the philanthropy and good hearts of many folks. Some great leadership like Guillermo and Rebecca. Chuck is doing some great things in a post-Chambers world. cons: Tenure based promotion system. Many managers take credit for their direct reports' work or efforts. review_title: Good, but Could Be Much Better
pros: • Work-life balance is prime here and everyone respects people’s personal time • Culture is fairly nice and open. Not cutthroat • Great for anyone looking for a stable, predictable job — especially good for people taking care of a family (onsite daycare, maternity + paternity leave, etc)
cons: • Salary negotiation is non-existent if you are hired through the university program. Really. Nor is team matching. • Promotions are rare and are often based on inter-company politics. When they are awarded, they are underwhelming and don’t match the local rent inflation • RSUs are very rare and, again, very political / based on team+BU • There is always talk about innovation by the leadership, but the culture is fairly stale as are the products, so opportunities for innovation are few and far between • No free food or snacks. A couple of buildings do have free snacks, but it was for a “beta snacks program” that was never spread company wide.

review_title: Great overall company culture with micro-cultures within
pros: - Career opportunities are available internally if you are proactive - Great company culture if you enjoy interacting, collaborating, connecting with people since it is relationship oriented - Health benefits are great and there is a health center in the main headquarters - People are great since I am still friends with many of them in Silicon Valley - Learning opportunities are available - Surprisingly, I was with the company for 9 years full-time and 1 year as an intern and it was due to the focus on continuous learning, growth, and challenge. People was also key to the culture.
cons: - Microcultures within the larger company. Overall, Cisco has a whole is a good company but I've experienced a few negative and disgruntled employees who are disconnected with the company since they do not make an effort to learn about the larger picture which is why I left due to negative vibes in my organization - Passive aggressive in some technology groups

review_title: Times are changing, mostly for the better, and quickly
pros: Incredible ongoing focus on people and experiences Opportunities to help determine direction just keep coming Executives really want to hear from everyone, not a yes culture Employees feel more heard and a part of decisions around what's next Easy to rotate or move into other parts of the business to round out your skills and knowledge Recognizes the need to evolve constantly and tries to do so

pros: 1. Good and big campus 2. Better facilities like Gym, Quite rooms, Open area seatings, Cafe, Massage chairs etc 3. Flexible work timings
cons: My review is specific to Service Provider BU, Bangalore, India 1. Top to bottom approach. The engineers are not given much attention and importance. The deadlines are decided from the top and just informed to the engineers. 2. There is no teamwork. All are individual contributors and hence there is no bonding within the team. 3. Managers are there only to convince you and not to understand your needs. 4. Most of the good work (infact the development work) is done at US. Only sustenance work is done here. The management will give lame excuses if we ask for it 5. The managers wont trust you and the senior team members too. 6. There are no fun activities. 7. They dont value the people. Not even as a resource. They are used and thrown out.

pros: Some great teams and management, great people and lots of flexibility. Parts of the company will still make positions to fit their people rather than try to fit people into rigid job roles. Flexible working hours are great. Good people will generally accrue responsibility and be recognised.
cons: Restructuring/layoffs are endemic, bringing constant attrition of people (good and bad) and low-level fear and malaise. Many great teams have been turned into poor ones, with capable, experienced, helpful and flexible old-hands replaced with incapable, inexperienced, unhelpful and inflexible teams in low-cost locations. This is not a criticism of the people, who can always be developed, but of the managers who try to automate their teams, removing any intelligence from the jobs and putting it into the tools and processes. The result is people who are simply told what to do and how, meaning no personal responsibility, minimal personal growth and low motivation, plus when the tools or processes break (which is frequently) there is little capability to keep the business flowing. Finally there are still too many teams with a lot of political grandstanding in the senior management--this is at best a nuisance and at worst can lead to poor decisions being taken by defocused management.

ltant in Kraków

review_title: No longer a place for anyone over 40
pros: Good people below the management level. Good corporate tools, decent perks
cons: Abundantly clear that the company is clearing out employees who have either been there a long time (12+ years) or who are 40 and older. Every Grade 11 and 12 get replaced with junior Grade 8's. Also a place where rewards go to the loudest and never to the most able or deserving.

review_title: Cisco: a Great Company, an Empowering Culture, with Excellent Opportunities
pros: Where do I begin?! Over the 13 years+ I have worked at Cisco it has only gotten better! There is a renewed focus on it's greatest asset-- the people, and it really shows in how the company fosters a team atmosphere, continual training/learning opportunities, and dozens of employee-focused activities, benefits, perks, etc etc etc. I left Cisco for a period of time, and after experiencing several other companies, how they treat employees, the culture differences, I can honestly say that Cisco is by far the best company I have ever worked for. It is fast paced, and if you are not a "high performer" it can be a challenge, because the people here are incredibly intelligent and competitive... just dive right in and learn to swim!
cons: The fast paced nature of the business can be overwhelming sometimes, but if you embrace it and work smart, with continual learning built into your career plan, then the sky is the limit. Life is about choices, and because of the collaborative, "always on" nature of the network, you must learn to unplug from work to keep your life in balance--- otherwise you start "living to work" instead of "working to live". You have to manage YOUR career and calendar, otherwise the aggressive, success-driven nature of Cisco will "eat you for lunch".

pros: Wide range of technologies to learn and work with.
cons: Little to no opportunities for advancement. No regular pay raises or compensation given for top performers. Bloated management structure with not enough workers to continue to pyramid scheme that gets the executives paid absorbant salaries. Yearly layoffs ensure you team members are always leaving or looking for work. Below industry average employee benfits.

pros: Cisco is a world class organization with best of breed technology and products. Plenty of resources to help you be successful and provide value to customers
cons: Strategy and direction are changing for the good, however, it will take time to implement. Larger organizations aren't nimble and willing to make changes quickly.

pros: Good benefits, PTO, and relatively good healthcare premiums, 401K match, able to contribute to growing team and processes, great colleagues

pros: Placeism - Cisco doesn't discriminate about where you are working, as long as you ARE working. We are truly global - and it doesn't matter if you sit on campus, on your living room couch or on a plane - as long as you are engaged. We have amazing collaboration tools, including Webex, that allows us to use video and be virtual/present anywhere. Our executives, especially at the top, are very accessible and engaging. They are incredibly transparent. Our CEO and his leaders host a monthly all-employee meeting through CiscoTV, and have a team of people answering questions about anything and everything.
cons: We are a larger, more diverse company in terms of products, so you don't always see regular salary increases, and stock for the average worker is probably non-existent. While we are hiring, it helps if you know someone, as things can get lost.

review_title: Kinda corporate environment with good pay and flexibility in my hours. Co-workers are great people.
pros: The pay here is competitive to other surrounding companies, and we have hold overs in our area from Sourcefire which was a startup purchased by Cisco a few years back. We get benefits like lunch 3 days per week, quarterly fun-fund and PLI bonuses every 6 months

review_title: It was good for a little while
pros: - I learned a tremendous amount during my time with Cisco - Benefits are pretty good, better than most other companies in my geographic area - Opportunities for internal movement
cons: - Leadership tolerates drama, lying, backstabbing - Lack of accountability for managers and individual contributors - Star players are often invisible to management, even their own managers - Old fashioned office politics are strongly encouraged and required above a certain level - It's often the most destructive employees who get the most positive attention (squeaky wheel gets applauded when they fix things they broke?) - Very short term memory of cause-and-effect consequences (same mistakes made repeatedly by leadership) - Self-centered culture, cliquish, judgmental and eager to exclude from the "in" groups - Very much a sink-or-swim organization, but talent is valued less than "playing the politics game" - The organization will consume your life if you let it, some managers don't accept that you have a life outside of work - Manager's word always taken as solid gold by leadership - Overall very toxic environment

pros: - Great work-life balance. No strict deadlines for almost most of the work items. - Very flexible environment. Enormous Work from home, paid time off benefits. - Positive culture in general inside the team. - Overall, fun to work at in your day to day life. - Customer focused company. Everybody make sure Customer's ask are accomplished and served well.
cons: - You will find yourself struggling to receive quality work and project guidance. - Lack of long term vision for products. Comparatively less features development efforts to make the product great while comparative new born products in market from other brands is bringing lot of features on table. - Most of the feature ask come from Customer/Marketing side. Less internal research and motivations to bring new features on the table. - Lack of collaboration between teams. Hence, often you find multiple teams ending up working on same thing. - Due to same Titles across Software and Test engineers, PERM process getting delayed due to work restructuring. - As an early in career individuals, not a great place to be for a tech skills learning and career growth. - Lot more talking before committing any project and less of doing.

pros: Great place to work with good work life balance
cons: Salaries and benefits need to improve

review_title: Mostly a good place to work
pros: The new head of HR, Fran, has made some positive changes which are well appreciated, including closing the gender pay gap, inclusion and diversity training, getting to take the day off on your birthday, and taking up to a week off to do charity work. Other people say Cisco has good work life balance. I think it depends on what product you are working on. I feel like I am under a lot of stress generally and put in a lot of hours. I have been at Cisco over 10 years and there haven't been a lot of breaks. Many of my coworkers work from home at least a couple days a week, especially after they moved us to an open floor plan. The people I work with are for the most part friendly, smart and professional. I love making killer products that make billions of dollars of revenue each year. I learn new things constantly and feel challenged.
cons: At least in engineering, there is not a supportive environment for women. There is lack of education among the first line managers how to promote respect and give air time to all type of people, and to promote, give opportunities, listen to and value the ideas of women. And there is some blatant sexism. For example, when I had my baby, my manager told me the 'right' thing to do was to become a stay at home mom. And despite making a sacrificial effort to perform well my first year with a baby, my manager said he gave me an average rating because I had a baby. His perception was colored by my being a mother. I thought I deserved a higher rating for an exceptional year. And he asked me what are my priorities, my child or my job? He didn't ask my male coworkers this question. Even now, he 'forgets' to give me a bonus even though he gave every other report of his one (who are all male). In the previous two layoffs, the only persons he laid off were women. He asks me to plan the fun group outings, not my male colleagues. On separate occasions, my director and my VP asked me to take minutes when there were plenty of men available to also take minutes. Many of my female coworkers moved on because of the frustration of not having their opinions valued as much as our male coworkers. It's a tough problem to solve because people come to Cisco from many types of backgrounds, but I feel there is no management support from any level of the management chain except for Chuck and his direct reports. Open space floorplan is distracting visually and audially. The space is so tight that the moveable whiteboards are not near our desks. Currently, morale is a little down because it is not clear how individuals will be engaged in making the future roadmap happen. People fear for their jobs. We've had repeated layoffs in my group, and there will be more to come.

pros: Great people to work with. Benefits are top notch, including tuition reimbursement for degree seekers. Provides for continuous learning by providing company sponsored Pluralsight/CodeSchool and Safari accounts. Internal training opportunities (Cisco on Cisco if you will) are also available.
cons: Budget, Budget, Budget. While all of the above opportunities exist, having budget to take an internal class or getting management to approve the time (and possible travel) to attend the class is difficult. Getting equipment takes some planning and justification out the *ss, a quarter or more in advance. (note that the Pluralsight & Safari accounts are almost automatically approved. I believe there is a significant corporate/quantity discount). Getting promoted beyond "the middle" can take a long time. Products are developed, in my experience, in a vacuum devoid of customer input.

review_title: Highly recommended, with a few buts
pros: In my opinion, Cisco employees enjoy a very competitive benefits package. Salaries are fair, plus there are additional financial rewards such as an annual bonus and the opportunity to be recognized with gift certificates from co-workers. The facilities (campus, office, relax areas etc.) are world class. There is a lot of diversity, many different nationalities in the office which creates a good vibe. You will have opportunities to take part in many fun and/or charitable activities, and the company encourages it by giving additional time off to participate (for example preparing Christmas gifts for needy children, animal shelter visits etc.) Many opportunities for development like training, mentorship or shadowing. However this requires initiative from you, don’t expect anyone else to handle your career development for you. Often the company can sponsor industry certifications like PMP or ITIL. Flexible work options. In most roles you can work remotely, and in some you will have a lot of control over your work schedule.
cons: Not specifically a con, but your experience at Cisco will depend a lot on your manager and team, which probably applies to any company out there. If possible, use your network to find out more about the specific team you are planning to join because not all teams are the same in terms of atmosphere, work schedules etc. You can’t really expect quick and regular salary advances and promotions. In my experience, you will need to consistently perform above your level, plus the timing and budget must be favorable. In other words, hard work plus a bit of luck are needed. Some employees are obviously performing above their level and waiting for the right recognition. Because of that I've seen valueble employees decide to leave. On the other hand, if you’re good at what you do and have the patience it’s often worth the wait.
