pros: 1) You will get challenged: regardless of whether you're a Datacenter Engineer, Network Engineer, Programmer, System Engineer or whatever chances are you're going to be working on some cutting edge gear in some really challenging projects. If you want to push yourself and work with some really intelligent people this is the kind of job. 2) You will be rewarded: salaries I found were competitive and their bonuses excellent. Overtime was available if you wanted it. Perks were varied and excellent. They had a reward scheme called connected recognition which was good - if abused. 3) Travel was common: in my line of work, it was common to travel across Europe and the world. Cisco have a very well organised and structured travel system and they will make sure you're well taken care of when abroad. 4) The corporate culture is healthy and caring. They're not too big on waving their own flag or banging their own drum yet at the same time they quietly promote Cisco and help out in things like STEM programs at schools and universities and startups. 5) Progression: Training was available if you wanted it and it was easy to move within Cisco to different roles if you could demonstrate your ability.
cons: 1) Usual corporate politics but thats the same everywhere to be honest. 2) Conspicuous lack of season ticket loan which was a bit weird - though I think they've rectified this since I've left. 3) Sometimes it takes time for new acquisitions to really bed in within Cisco which can lead to friction between existing Cisco employees and the new guys. 4) Communication between business units quite rare. It was common for me to visit a datacenter in some far flung land and discover Cisco owned cages and racks I had never even heard of.

old company jobs are interesting but not exciting

ltant - HR Leadership Program
11 Apr 2018 - Human Resources Consultant in Raleigh, NC
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Cisco's People Deal is real and is pervasive in all of the moments that matter in your career. From your recruitment through retirement/moving on, Cisco aims to make sure they make each "Moment that Matters" special. The HR Leadership Program (HRLP) has given me multiple rotations through various HR specialties, giving me a good base knowledge of HR and has helped me identify where my strengths and passion will allow me to contribute at a high level. In HR you are treated like a true professional. As long as you're performing at an acceptable level, no one pays attention to or cares where, when, and how you get your work done. This is great for work flexibility. I have worked from several locations for extended periods of time only needing to take part of that time as Paid Time Off, and not missed a beat. The technology plays a large role in the work flexibility as in any given day I can be talking with people from any part of the world, face-to-face over WebEx or Telepresence video.
Cons
As the technology can allow for great work flexibility, it can also allow work - if you don't proactively manage it - to take over your life as you CAN always be available. Manage your schedule with your stakeholders and you'll be fine.

review_title: A great company with great people
pros: - Engaging work and managers invested in development - Work life balance is encouraged - Good compensation, benefits and perks - Good transportation options - Senior level management is capable and transparent

pros: Very smart people, easy to work and get along with. Cisco takes care of it's employees.

pros: You will work with some of the best and brightest. Come ready to learn - - your colleagues will be a major asset for you. Take advantage of their expertise. Cisco is very generous with work/life balance, offering much more flexibility than any other firm I've worked with. Cisco doesn't cut corners, and as a result, has stellar industry-leading products. If you work in a Sales or Marketing role, as I did, the doors will be wide open to you. Cisco has partnerships with major players in almost every industry. You will have the opportunity to network widely within your field.
cons: The divide between red and blue badges is wider here than at many other companies. If you get stuck in a contract role, you'll face a real uphill fight to get converted. Decisions from leadership can sometimes seem draconian. I've seen entire teams dismissed at the drop of a hat. Presumably these events come as the result of a compelling business reason, but that's not ever communicated clearly throughout the ranks, contributing to an overall sense of vulnerability among staff. There are many BUs within the company that are siloed off from one another, making it difficult to streamline and share institutional knowledge. This can lead to inefficiencies and duplicated efforts. I can't honestly say that the executives' vision for the company is clearly communicated. It can be challenging to find after several months (or years) of working toward a target, that the target was moved by someone in the board room and your team wasn't informed. It can be like pulling teeth to secure budget for certain projects, while leadership will rain dollars on other departments that they happen to favor. In some cases this makes sound business sense, but in some cases it seems inscrutably arbitrary.

employee_title: Compensation, Benefits and Job Analysis Specialist
review_title: The Company You Always Wanted and Deserved!
pros: Cisco enables an industry leading work/life flex. Cisco's hierarchical structure feels very flat and is incredibly symbiotic. Company culture isn't harsh, but encouraging and friendly. It's all about development--focusing on the team and specifically the positive and building relationship you should have with your manager. Those who are ambitious, work hard, and genuinely network will be recognized for their efforts and will be rewarded with great work opportunities. Cisco espouses the principle that in joining this one company, you can have multiple careers. Cisco can scale talent due to their collaborative technology--enabling us to hire top talent across the globe making Cisco a very diverse and culturally enriching environment.
cons: Business functions can be siloed from one another. Not always an apparent information share between functions. Building bridges and tearing down walls can be arduous and time consuming. There is a lot of red tape, and it's not uncommon to deal with work that, in principle, should move very quickly but is slowed down because teams can be scattered across the global with different timezones. Cisco's culture of "let's create a formal meeting" in order to get work done isn't efficient, and it's hard to be a change agent in a team that has a culture of working to solve problems by creating formal meeting after formal meeting.

pros: tons of cash in hand to weather the current identity crisis it is going through
cons: way too many cooks in the kitchen in the top leadership. too much direction by committee.

pros: My entrance into Cisco was through the HRUP program. HRUP is the best rotational program I've come across (internally to Cisco and externally). If you are a junior in college, interested in HR, go apply for the internship now! Outside of great pay, great company brand, and awesome co-workers, you are given the opportunity to explore ANY area of HR when you come on full-time. With buy-in from our CHRO, you get to explore five different areas of HR (including the internship). I have loved my time in the HRUP program, and am now in my final rotation. I would highly recommend it. It's been the BEST foundation for my career moving forward. I'm currently recruiting for Cisco and it is incredible. The brand name gives you such access to awesome talent. Candidates ALWAYS say "It's Cisco!" when I ask them why they are interested. It's so easy to be passionate about Cisco and sell working here because it really is incredible.
cons: There are pockets of cynics who are annoying. "What do you expect. It's Cisco". They bug me. There is a lot of change, so, if you like structure, stand back. Sometimes I miss words amongst all the acronyms we speak. Some of the buildings still look like it's the 90s, but they are slowly getting renovated. It just always seems like my building is last.

review_title: Welcoming to members & allies of the LGBT community
pros: From the start, I have felt welcomed, supported, and accepted without question. Cisco has an excellent LGBT employee resource organization (ERO). cons: In our discussions about the rights of LGBT employees, we are well aware of the differences in experience country to country. We have a long way to go; we encourage our LGBT colleagues to join us in the conversation of making Cisco more globally tolerant.

review_title: Love Cisco but Cisco HR is a fail
pros: many awesome elements of the company
cons: Cisco HR wants to "help" managers by hard coding tools so that managers are "in empowered" to reward employees as they sit fit. For example, once a manager wants to promote an employee there is a guideline on how much pay would accompany that promotion. However Cisco HR takes it too far; the pay HAS to be a certain amount, can't exceed a certain and must come out of a budget deemed promo budget. A leader who is managing within their budget is completely crippled by the rules HR sets around how to manage the team & rewards. Its ridiculous and completely contradictory to "The People Deal".

review_title: Great Place - People, Technology and Culture
pros: Great place to work with industry's best talent

pros: High salaries and benefits package. Generally given a high level of autonomy and responsibility. You need to be prepared to work extremely hard and not to worry too much about the 9-5. There is plenty of flexibility in work but the focus is global!
cons: Office politics can be a pain. There are often sudden changes on strategy which can annoy certain people.

pros: Good salary, good benefits, a great place to work remotely
cons: Ridiculous levels of overhead--pre-pre approval for even simple expenses like a mouse. Absolutely no approvals for travel of any kind. Ditto there is absolutely no budget for training at all, even if the courses are internally offered. You may grow distant from the company/fellow employees etc over time since you'll never actually see any of them. Managers are promoted past their level of competence. Simple things like submitting a fix for a bug have masses of overhead. They change management tools constantly so you'll probably have to update information in multiple places about the same thing. Lots of the help on the web is archaic and simply results in 404's. IT support is generally pretty bad too. The meetings that are held are mostly focused on sales and pitching the information appropriate to sales staff. Customer support relies on direct connection with engineers who as a result have to be available long hours/weekends with some frequency.

review_title: Cisco will waste your important years of your career .. period
pros: Absolutely nothing I can think of
cons: Primary Cons - No development / innovative work - Only bug fixing & debugging work - low level coding standards used in the code base - you will spend most of time debugging some error which a guy in USA office is stuck with - will lose your coding skills gradually due to no application to daily work - software engineering role is more like a dev ops networking kind of role - will be surrounded by people who don't care about what they work on, basically people just living for the weekends - not a lot of monetary benefits , very petty hikes & bonuses - hiring standards are very low, they pretty much hire anyone who has basic coding / scripting skills - employee strength is huge , which leads to chaos in daily activities - no well defined vision, requirements from your manager keep changing every monday - you may work on some code on an idea for a few days , eventually to find that idea has scrapped by higher management - not one of those companies who shift performing employees to HQ in USA - flexible work timing is just a trap , which gives them right to make you work at night or weekends - lot of blame game between teams, just to divert bugs / issues from themselves - not at all suited for people starting their career , as learnings phase is almost null - innovative or product development ideas are dropped because people are busy debugging build issues - Cisco bangalore does not have any R&D labs as such, was built for sole purpose for providing support San Jose office - very low skilled people , not up to date with emerging technologies , nor do they have the zeal to learn - in case you joined newly from college, you will be randomly assigned a division, then its pretty difficult to move to any division of your choice (may take years) Secondary cons: - more than 7000 employees in the campus, too much crowded - cafeteria food is very bad - located in a dirty and polluted area TO SUM UP, YOU WILL BE REDUCED TO A GUY WHO ANSWERS QUERIES, SOLVES BUILD ISSUES, AND RESOLVES BUGS RELATED TO THE WORK IN SAN JOSE HQ

pros: 1) Opportunities to learn technologies in depth. 2) Get customer handling skills.
cons: 1) Cisco Services executive leadership is working hard to transform the services business to a call-centre business. On an average Cisco Services in US pays significantly less than other Cisco orgs at any grade level. It is common for employees to jump orgs and give themselves an automatic raise. Services is losing talent for several years because of these disparities & scores of extremely good engineers and first line managers have moved out for money. 2) Promo cycles are a myth. It is not uncommon for people to work their @ss off for several years in a row just to be told that either the much awaited promo/equity cycle did not happen, or it was too little to mean anything. By the way, this happens right after massive promos in senior management layer. 3) Management keeps cramming more work into the job role every few months - for no extra dime. Engineers besides learning and supporting their technologies & customers are asked to cross train with other technologies, learn scripting, automate processes, create content, help improve product quality. If engineers don’t invest their personal time there is no way they can meet these unrealistic expectations. 4) Outsourcing has brought morale to a new low. Tremendous amount of services work got moved south of the border in last three years. There is no concrete communication from upper management whether or not they want services' employees in US to thrive or to look out.

review_title: Was a Great Place to Work
cons:
lting Engineer in Reno, NV
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
I worked for Cisco for 20 years, 11 months and enjoyed most everyday. I had a lot of opportunity to grow my talents and participate in making the internet what it is today. Worked many hours and traveled a lot but it was well worth it. Met a lot of great people all over the world.
Cons
After 20+ years I was all of sudden laid off along with 800 other employees. I was not given any opportunity to find another position or any reason why I was being let go. I was planning to retire in 4 years and now due to my age I am having a hard time finding a new job. Since the new CEO took over the company has gone downhill as far as loyalty to employees is concerned. Most people I know are always worried about being laid off. I would not recommend Cisco to anyone now as long as this culture persist.

pros: Great compensation and great benefits. You get a lot of experience under your belt here and it is a very well-respected company. If you put in your time, it can lead to big things in your future within this company, or the next if that's what you want.
cons: If you are in virtual sales (GVS), STAY FAR AWAY. It has gone from being the most rewarding and enjoyable job to an unhealthy call center environment. The VP decided to fix something that was not broken and make everyone work out of the RTP office instead of hiring real raw talent. The director rules by fear and walks the floor to make sure people don't leave before exactly 5pm on a Friday afternoon (this job is requires long hours and they don't allow you to put in overtime, mind you), and you have little or no support from operations. Half of my peers were either in therapy or needed it, and they were always so terrified to come in every day. Also, there are layoffs every single quarter. The ageism is real in this company. You are not safe unless you're an older white male. The culture isn't the best here for women either. No one ever feels safe to report when men are inappropriate.

review_title: So much potential, so much mismanagement.
pros: Great commitment to social and corporate responsibility, diversity/inclusion. Strong technologies, acquisition strategies and in general work/life balance is good. Great ability to advance and move laterally within the company. Good benefits overall.
cons: Too much middle management, micromanagement and a total lack of trust in employees - no empowerment. Benefits vary widely depending on where are you located (San Jose and RTP are totally different worlds than most other offices). Sales management is stuck in "route/switch" hardware sales mentality and is unwilling to adapt to new ways of selling. Commission structures for sales are incredibly broken and aren't adapting to new software/enterprise agreement models leading to very unhappy sales teams and lots of attrition. Enormous year over year quota upticks are almost impossible to understand. With the exception of Meraki, Cisco absolutely devastates the cultures of companies they acquire - taking away all the perks, quirks and inspirations that make those acquired companies so successful. This also leads to resentment when small pockets get to retain those perks that other acquired companies lost (again, referencing Meraki). Frequent "Limited Restructurings" are used in punitive ways to get rid of folks that management doesn't like or that offer up strong opinions. They also seem to affect a suspiciously high number of over 40/very senior workers. "Managing Upward" has become an artform within Cisco, leaving higher management levels with a very clouded view of the real problems that exist.

pros: Excellent benefits (time off, crazy maternity/paternity leave, free college, etc), good pay, looks great on a resume. If you like working in TAC (support), you could do it until you retire. It's very hard to get fired.
cons: Getting a promotion or even a raise can be very difficult in TAC. If you are an innovative person, life at Cisco can be hard because Cisco wants you to be a cog in the machine. Teams in TAC with difficult to support products can find themselves overwhelmed with work, while teams supporting other products have nothing to do. There are multiple customer service offerings at Cisco who's day to day job comes down to nagging TAC about support cases regardless of case progress/status. Cisco wants to be agile like a startup but has too much overhead in terms of sticking to the status quo and propping up legacy business units to move quickly. There seems to be a lot of pointless changes that happen only to justify the existence of whatever team is responsible for making the changes.

review_title: Technical Leader in Cisco Service Provider, India
pros: Opportunity to work on latest technologies and evolving IOS-XR which is widely acknowledged for its high quality. Excellent, innovative and challenging road map across various product lines in Access / Edge / Core Networks. Working with top talents in the Industry across geographies. Interaction with Cross functional teams like Product Marketing, Customer Account teams and Sales TMEs . Encouragement to change the roles based on the strengths and skill sets. World Class work environment which is collaboration oriented and supported by well maintained infrastructure. One of the best and secure Employee Transport facilities.
cons: Inability to change the culture across all the team members to overcome hurdles. Too many context switches are demanding and they turn out to be counter productive. Slow career growth due to large teams.

review_title: State of the art campus, cutting edge hardware design activities and good work-life balance guaranteed
pros: Nobody tells you where to draw the line or what not to do, as long as you get the job done. You will have sufficient time to explore any relevant technology and get your hands dirty. Cisco Bangalore has state of the art lab facilities, ample and regular in house training options. From hardware design standpoint, we are given opportunities on par with what happens at San Jose, maybe with a 1-2Q delay but good work does eventually reach our shores. The management is transparent top down and recognitions are promptly awarded where due. Pay is on merit and merit is greatly valued with limited scope for internal politics and cronyism. Overall, a great place to be in.
cons: Sometimes you will doubt hardware's relevance in Cisco's long term 'No.1 IT company' strategy. Market dynamics change pretty fast, especially in the Service Provider world.

review_title: Right Place for Multi Talented people
pros: 1. This place is huge and filled with awesome minded people. It's a myth that coding is intrinsic property of a person. I feel coding is not individual but a cohesive task and with right people you have higher chances of writing better code. Cisco is one of that place where writing bad code is really tough job because it's not you can do easily here. 2. Growth opportunity here is tremendous. From outside it is one company but from inside it is around 10 different business units and believe me they all are not easy to get inside. It is really great how you can switch between these all BU's and be in the same company. It's great for the profile build up. 3. Hell amount of innovation and technology languages. You name it, Cisco has it. 4. World class office space and world class discussions.
cons: 1. Work from home gives you great work life balance but at the same time you end up working 24X7 2. Huge org, so it is difficult to make yourself visible. Some people generates tendency to be in shadows. 3. Little bit slow in day to day work style.

review_title: 20 years of steady progress for the LGBT community
pros: Despite my initial reservations and shynesss I have grown more confident as a gay employee at Cisco as Cisco’s leadership and its policies towards the LGBT community have grown to be more progressive. It took one call to HR and zero paperwork to add my partner to benefits. When I reached our HR to say I had come out and wanted to know if there was an employee group, their first words were “congratulations.” Our resell partners sponsor an LGBT social at our annual sales conference (we have the best resell partners on the planet). And we have executive sponsors who honestly care about our welfare. They matched my donations to Orlando, PRIDE, and supported us in the San Francisco parade. They are sensitive to the situations other employees face in other countries.
cons: They are not leaders; rather, fast followers in LGBT advocacy. In North Carolina. In Texas. In Washington. At the San Fran parade. Room to grow. Not a place to expect leadership. But a place to expect acceptance, decency and support.

pros: Great compensation and great benefits

review_title: Freedom is a massive benefit but isolation and uncertainty may set you back
pros: You'll never have freedom like you'll have at Cisco due to the flexible working hours and remote working culture. Generally, the company perks are great and salaries tend to be good
cons: Problem with the remote working policies is that your team mates will seldom come to the office and you may soon feel isolated. This also generates a bit of an issue with team spirit and collaboration. There are also multiple overlapping roles, and your role is likely to change or be cut on a yearly basis. Overall, this environment can become toxic and demotivating. It is also hard to be promoted unless you move jobs willingfully.

pros: Cisco policies address the issues that face LGBT+ employees head-on. I've only recently come out and it was difficult, but there does not seem to be any backlash to my face.
cons: The issue comes when the local employees disagree with the corporate inclusion policies. When the people around you get their news from Fox and Friends.......it's still an uphill battle for equality.

review_title: Out and Proud LGBTQ at Cisco Systems
pros: In 2014, I was part of a small Cybersecurity company of 20 persons, the only woman and out LGBT person on the team. Cisco acquired our company; and with any acquisition by a large multinational corporation, there is some wonder about how the culture will change. I was very happy the last 3 ½ years to see the culture became even better. The Executive Leadership Team (ELT) is serious about executing on our core strategy and “The People Deal”. People ask me how I like working at Cisco…I love it! We work like a small start-up in my business unit, with the encouragement to Be Bold and take risks in Innovation; however, there is the power and strength of over 70,000 people working with you for the same goals. It is awesome to travel all over the globe and have your Cisco badge work in hundreds of locations. As an out LGBTQ person, I have found Cisco to be such a welcome and inviting place to work. Some highlights include, welcoming my same-sex spouse as part of the greater family; great health care benefits; Time2Give, where I volunteer 40 hours a year at LGTBQ non-profit organizations; Community Giving, where Cisco matches my donations to LGTBQ non-profit organizations and pays them $10 an hour for my volunteer service (for time above Time2Give time off); a strong LGBTQ & Allies employee resource organization with a private Facebook group & quarterly global meetings; Lesbian Lunch & Allies monthly meeting in San Jose; paying for my attendance at LesbiansWhoTech Summit in 2015; the ELT taking a public stand against discrimination on social media & in the press; Cisco signing the UN policy about diversity in the Workplace; and on and on. At a LGBTQ & Allies global PRIDE WebEx, a sales person in the UK asked an executive about being in the closet with his customers, worried he might not be able to make his quota if a customer knew he was gay and would not want to do business with him. The executive answered, “We obviously must have hired you because you are the best at what you do in your region. You represent Cisco. If they don’t want to do business with you, then we don’t want to do business with them.” I am grateful and proud to be part of the Cisco Family. #WeAreCisco #LoveWhereYouWork
cons: Like any large corporations, there can be too many persons involved in approvals for public facing messaging. Appreciate that there is a culture to find improvements with improving processes at all levels.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Salaries are competitive. There are many perks such as healthcare; flexi-time; working at home; shares; the ability to gift other employees awards in the form of vouchers; pension contributions and up to 30 days holiday if salary is used to buy 5 days on top of the base 25 days. Good infrastructure, facilities, nicely laid out buildings, a small canteen and generally good people, with a few exceptions (see '
* Widespread acceptance of remote workers, provides home office setup. * Lots of very smart and knowledgeable people.
cons: * Big company. Sometimes the left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing. * Lots of (long) meetings.

review_title: Good company iff you are in right team and right designation

cons: There are many.. let me share few of them: - If you are joining Cisco Service Provider India, do not expect hike/raise for at least next couple of years. People do not get hike for years(3-4 years).. Promotion is too hard to get.. you need to perform like best in team for 3-4 years continuously to get it.. - There are very less teams where you gain a good domain knowledge while working.. else everywhere just sustenance work. - Most of managers do not care of your learning/development, their main concern is just to get the bugs fixed on time. So most of them follow the push mechanism to get the work done. - You wont find any motivation to work. No one talks about new technologies and year by year you will loose confidence in yourself.. as you will work hard even then you wont get any appraisal.. - Most important thing, engineers are treated as slaves. Till the time they need you, you will be treated well and when they don't need you they will find a better slave and dump you..

review_title: Good for starting your career, but..
pros: The company is good for new grads / bachelors who can make use of the great facilities in the campus like great cafeteria which serves hygienic and tasy food, multiple sports areas, etc. and also get to learn a lot of things from the tech side. It gives them a lot of opportunities to explore different things and develop skills. The expectations on a new grad is mainly their weekly bug fix targets, which would not be too difficult to meet, so there is a lot of time for hobby projects. I assume at this age, the expectations from employee side would also be limited (in terms of compensation, benefits etc.), and Cisco would surely meet those.
cons: The problems at Cisco start when you spend say 5+ years and move to higher grades. - The pay hikes come once in 2 years and when they come, the budget gets used up for giving some director/VP promotions, leaving pretty much nothing for engineers. Some of the directors get even some random promotions at odd times! - In spite of all this, when an exec leaves, we feel there is absolutely no difference that it makes to the system that makes us wonder what they were doing to justify their heavy paychecks. - Execs are allowed to stick around in the system and make a "graceful exit" even if they are stripped of their responsibilities as part of some re-org. However, for the lessor souls, you may be asked to sign your resignation one fine morning when the lay-off season comes. - As an engineer, your growth is not related to the engineering contributions you make, on which the top management has limited interest or visibility. Your growth mainly depends upon how much "contacts" you have with the top management, and how you advertise yourself by showing off as "being on top of everything" 24x7. There are chances that some of the pressure tactics would take you to depression / mental breakdown.

pros: - Opportunity to explore and learn a wide spectrum of technologies - You get to interact with several great engineers - Excellent WPR services, be it Gym, Transport, Cafeteria, etc. - Very responsive support system (IT, HR, etc)
cons: - A lot of visionary top leaders have left the organization in last few years. The current top management is unable to connect with engineers. They lack vision, charisma and motivational skills and just know how to use whip and do some program management. Have absolutely no interest in building team dynamics or developing the career of engineers, and seem to be mainly focused on their own job security and progress. - For an individual contributor, career becomes stagnant after around 10 years, unless you are in the "good books" of someone in the top. But this may not be specific to this organization but a common Indian thing. There are a lot of stringent criteria that will be used deny a promotion for an IC. However, in the management ladder, you could see mediocre folks getting promoted quickly and growing in the path just because they have some X number of people under them and are able to squeeze more work on less number of people, etc. - Work life balance is not great, with several managers indirectly promoting working close to 24x7. I am sure this sort of work culture would have considered as a strong violation of labor laws if it were in some European country. Again, this is not a Cisco specific thing, but a normal scenario in Indian IT industry.

pros: I am part of Cisco India SP group for the past 10+ years. pls note that my views apply to Cisco India workplace and is different from Cisco US. I have not worked in any better place, following are pros 1. A very well oiled machine with complete life cycle of product development is present in India. 2. Expertise available in all areas which is fantastics for career growth. 3. A very competitive work place where fairly low percentage of people can take their position for granted. 4. Cisco pays bonus in better than reasonable way, usually close or above promise. Never betrays on that. 5. Work place resources (non-software) are best in the world, yes best in the world. Ex. fantastic transport,work place environment, furnitures, gardens, cafeteria. 6. Better than average software tools but not world class. However, cisco keeps improving. This makes a life little easier. 7. Reasonable work life balance with burst of high pressure cases. 8. High focus on customer delivery. 9. reasonable rewards (360 degree)
cons: Here are the cons 1. Opaque performance appraisal 2. India management is still under US Management and is unable to take directions on its own, typically gets dictated by US management at the cost of Indian teams efforts. Need to be self empowered and take up Products all by itself. Many product successes and significant talent available to become self-reliant. 3. Below par salary levels, causing attrition of good talent.

pros: I have been with Cisco for around 10 yrs and I feel its a great place to work. 1) Its a happening environment and you feel you are up-todate with the latest innovations and technology 2) Resources are plenty, there are so many great minds, books, e-material, routers, simulators where you get to learn whatever you yearn to 3) Around 80% of the colleagues share their learnings/knowledge with each other
cons: However there are some downsides which can be improved 1) Priorities keep changing especially when you are growing. Every morning, You prepare yourself for what to do that day, but top mgmt asks for some other urgent data and ur entire plan for the day is screwed up. The next morning you will not prepare for anything 2) Productive time to learn or explore something is slowly getting replaced with too many meetings/ updates. 1 hr of everyday update in one forum is far better than updating the same status in multiple forums, meetings, mails and debating over it 3) As a result of 2), our actual productivity happens during the family time which results in improper work-life balance -> sleeplessness ->frustration -> less energy/enthusiasm to explore new things

pros: Great starting point for your career. Working here sharpened my professional skills to get me ready for my next step.
cons: Turning inside Account Management role into a call center. Management is all about politics and the "it" groups. VERY much like high school. Going in and getting the job done doesn't cut it anymore. You have to make sure you're one of the "popular" ones to get promoted, or to keep your job. I watched multiple colleagues that couldn't cut it in multiple positions be moved around from one job to another all while making better money than the person next to him or her that is hitting goal, not making as much money, and who will be let go before the person being shuffled around. If you have an opinion, make sure you DON'T go to management about it, showing you have your own thoughts only puts a target on your back. I have never seen so many backstabbers in my life.

review_title: Cisco India is Service Company - Nexus , Firewall - No Hike for 4-5 years
pros: Go there if you want to Retire after 50.
cons: If you thinking that Cisco is company that work in niche of technology , you are wrong. Specially if you are hired in India.Cisco India is outsource based of Cisco USA , All New developments and research are done in US and once every thing is done , its transferred to India for Maintance . Whether its Data Centre Product Nexus or Firwall or UCS.. Secondly too many processes that will hinder your producivity..No information Sharing form Seniors..Proprietarty OS wrapper , So arent markettable Outside Cisco and No Pay hike for atleast 4-5 Years ..Normal Promotion Takes 5 Years.

pros: I worked at Cisco in RTP for a few years. Over time it become obvious that my project peers were working other full-time jobs and shouldering me with an unfair amount of project burden. I made management aware of this issue but they were too busy to effectively look into the matter. It was a complicated issue; management typically doesn't have time to manage staff at Cisco and actually see whats going on. Many managers have too many employees, some like mine have the title of manager but are really too busy working a sales role. This puts them in the place of trusting mid-level employees.If your under a shady one theres not much you can do. It got very shady in my exit interview when no HR representative was present. In lieu of that I was given a web form to fill out. Pros: Great opportunities do exist. as with most large companies Its really a roll of the dice as to who you work for.
cons: As stated the cliques and poor ethics that grow in certain areas.

pros: - Great work-life balance, and very open culture between colleagues and various teams - Everyone in the team is very supportive of each other, and always keen to share best practices and their own experiences - Customer Success is a new team in Cisco, but we are seeing large support from the CEO and Sales Leaders as Cisco makes the shift to selling more recurring revenue solutions. This is definitely the fastest growing team; and possibly where there is good career growth!
cons: A lot of KPIs that the management is pushing for in a bid to prove the value of the Customer Success team. Cisco is a sales organization, so there is large pressure for creation of expand opportunities. Even though there is so much push to get those KPIs fulfilled, people on the ground are limited due to the strange way in which the expand opportunities are measured. This is especially difficult in APJ region due to resistance from internal stakeholders. Everyone in the team came in very excited and motivated about Customer Success, but I am seeing some level of disillusionment and exhaustion to keep up with ever-changing performance measures, tools, new offers with little to no time to adjust, and high pressure from the managers. Also experiencing "growing pains" with large number of new members in the team.

pros: Professional atmosphere, intelligent culture, competitive salary, work life balance, mentoring program
cons: Big corporation makes it easy to get lost in your role

pros: Cisco hires a company to do your relocation papers and legalization in Poland and also provides tax advisers services. Sign-on bonus is ok. You can make good friends there and a lot of skilled and good engineers still work in TAC
cons: The salary is 20% lower than the market - you can get more just across the fence at AON, ABB, Motorola and many others. Do not expect to grow as an engineer there - mostly you will deal with platform specific bugs and defects in a very, very narrow field. Do not expect to build a carrier - to get a higher grade is extremely hard. And it's all about showing your hard work and not about actually working hard (Visibility - as it called in all big companies). Do not expect a salary raise. Bargain straight from the beginning. The raise is independent from your work and expertise, but rather from the stars in the sky. Expect to be surrounded by fresh graduates, who will bombard you with stupid questions and will lower your value as an engineer because they will do the same job as you do for less money and you will educate them for free. Working in TAC you will be the first to be hit - angry customers with problems will shout at you, sales will shout at you, because customers shout at them, your manager won't shout but will be on their side. Don't relocate to Krakow - smog is a huge problem there (especially if you have children) and rent market is crazy and full of scam.

Limits large scale internal innovations as a result. Can be difficult for employees to move between internal jobs as these aren't always well socialized and the company culture doesn't outwardly encourage rotations as a opportunity for individual growth.

review_title: Good work-life balance and benefits, management varies
pros: Cisco provides good benefits (10 company holidays, 4 weeks PTO, 1 week volunteering time, 4.5% 401k match, ESPP, maternity/paternity leave, emergency time off), promotes a positive work environment and a healthy work-life balance, and encourages movement within the company (including being rather supportive of remote work arrangements). The huge range of products provide opportunity for lateral movement. The large size provides a degree of stability. Salaries are good but not the highest in the industry.
cons: Cisco has traditionally operated as a number of quasi-independent Business Units. Soft-qualities such as work-life balance, encouraging movement, and quality of management can vary significantly between Business Units. That said, Chuck Robbins' Executive Leadership Team has been making a concerted effort to address problem areas. Cisco grows by acquisition so a significant fraction of the innovation happens outside the company. This also leads to relatively frequent layoffs of redundant divisions and attrition as acquired employees become fully vested and seek opportunities elsewhere.

pros: CULTURE ------------- Strong and evolving, focused on engineering quality and outcomes TECH -------- On-premise codebases suffer due to legacy, but command a massive customer base and hence continuously refactored and churned with new features. High focus on engineering practices, quality and automation. Solid architectures. Cloud services and components are new, employ relatively latest paradigms, but lack any significant customer base. LEADERSHIP ----------------- Passionate senior management that puts the interests of the org and people above all else. Encourages feedback, ideas and initiatives. Ready to experiment with people, processes and perspectives. ORG STRUCTURE ------------------------ Relatively flat and transparent, dynamic structures that rapidly evolve to solve problems. ENGINEERS ---------------- Rock-solid technical leaders, a good percentage of expertise among engineers makes this a good place to work and learn. INNOVATION ------------------ General impetus and encouragement to any innovation at all levels. Hacking is highly encouraged. FUN + BENEFITS ---------------------- Engineers get to use best in hardware, equipments and infrastructure Relaxed, fun and alive work atmosphere while also being super-intense and engaging Amazing, huge campus here in Bangalore
cons: Lack of vision at product management - On one hand, the on-premise portfolio is struggling to re-invent and be competitive among newly emerging competition. On the other hand, the cloud strategy and services have turned out to be unimpressive, at least until now. Product Management at all levels is unable to figure this out yet.

pros: Salary and opportunities for training good. Flexible working policies very good
cons: Cisco bought out our successful company and have ruined it in around 5 years. It's too big, what makes sense as a direction at the top, loses its way in translation down the layers and becomes farcical. Constant redundancies and reorganisations just to try and make the bean counters happy, with no real thought as to whether they make sense. Good people can be cut from important/successful projects because some line manager in the States has been told to cull x people and conversely some people can be left with a job title and a good salary, but no constructive work to do - soul destroying and I'm so happy I got out.

review_title: A company that supports digital transformation
pros: As a hardware vendor to survive digital era, Cisco has chosen the right path and is on track. Out of 10 recent acquisitions, 9 were software-driven, and Cisco is embracing ecosystem in Cloud environment with the multi-cloud strategy. I love it Cisco heavily invests in its employees and partners to grow and transform for customer success.
cons: Sales team forecast and monitor the progress on a weekly basis, which can be tough for the ones who're not used to face-paced business environment.

review_title: Cisco High Touch Customer Success Manager
pros: Cisco is a great company to work for. Conditions of employment are great , lots of perks (health care, etc), and opportunities to help develop your own skills, generally pretty fair pay rates, lots of flexibility of manage your work/life balance. Of course, the Cisco 'ask' is that you work to the best of your ability to service the customer and the company, in that order. As a Customer Success Manager, my role is to help our customers consume the Cisco products that they have bought; though not in a 'break-fix' sense. More so in working with the customer to aid and guide them, whilst orchestrating the services and support they may need to get the best from the platform, in the context of the customers organisation. Its a very satisfying role.
cons: Like any large company, Cisco is sometimes difficult to navigate, and is often driven by process, to achieve consistent outcomes. Fortunately, there are generally provisions in-built for 'exceptions to process' in order to meet a specific customer circumstance.

pros: Good work and life balance
cons:

review_title: Good place to work for millennials with little or no IT background but passionate about technology
pros: Diversity - people are from different backgrounds which makes the work environment rich in sense of ideas, cultures and experiences. Many interesting, talented and dedicated people from whom you can learn a lot. Trainings - the abundance of online learning materials that every employee can leverage in order to gain more knowledge and master certain skills whether it be required or desired. Innovative tools - one of the best things is that we get to use what we sell (especially collaboration tools) that makes our jobs more productive and engaging. Activities within and outside the office - many volunteering and sports activities that are not only fun, but also very helpful in terms of getting to know your team mates and other people working at Cisco. If you are a person who likes personal and professional development, open for constructive feedback from anyone inside the organisation, enojys challenges and leverages opportunities, it is the right place for you.
cons: - It is an enormous corporation, therefore hierarchy and bureaucracy are unavoidable as in all of the big organizations. - The hiring process is selective and competitive which is why it takes an effort to make it through. - If you are not open to constant challenges and changes, it is not the place for stability.

pros: Great work culture Top talent Globally Active philanthropic community

review_title: CSAP Program/ Associate Sales Representative in Cisco
pros: This a great sales training program to start the career journey. Cisco is a tech giant and well known as an amazing company to work where you get to work alongside fantastic people - innovative, intelligent and passionate individuals. Innovation is in the core of Cisco’s values which pushes you to challenge yourself and grow more after every single challenge. The structure of the CSAP program prepares you with a wide perspective about technical sales to ensure you would be successful after the program as well. As an Associate Sales Representative during the program, we were trained by fantastic people who strived constantly to ensure our success both professionally and personally. The role is exciting and challenging in how it exposes you to always think beyond of not just selling products but selling business outcomes. Personally this is the most important thing for me - I value the relationships I have with the customers, and with this mindset I always try to find the best possible option for them to reach their own goals. In Cisco there is no leaving things to chance - if you are in the program that is because they believe the value you represent and the value you could add to Cisco. This program will give you the endless opportunities to grow and be the most successful version of yourself.
cons: Not necessarily a con however if you are a person looking for a stable work environment with a small room for change, Cisco is the very opposite of it. To be able to keep up with technology, like every other company, Cisco also needs to be adaptable and ready for ever-changing processes. If you like challenge and put in effort to be on top of the news, it wouldn’t be a problem.

review_title: Great company to kick-start your career

pros: First thing comes to my mind about this group : Always do the right thing to Customers which is evident in the way the backlog gets prioritised, the leadership works and the way teams interact with Customers & Partners. pros: Great Company and good technical Talent

pros: Cisco really looks after her employees. Benefits are great - ESPP, bonuses, PTO (We had the same number of vacation days as we had before Cisco bought us, so I can't actually tell). Opportunities to change career paths - both to relocate, and to change business unit - Cisco allows it. Community involvement - employees get 5 days a year to volunteer at a NGO of their choice, plus matching program. And there's more. A lot of professional courses, both technical, management, human-interaction skills, and management - Cisco invites excellent tutors to educate her employees on many many subject, you just need to ask your manager for approval. I took technical courses mainly, such as MongoDB, Postgres, Extreme Java development, ElasticSearch, etc. And for all of them I can say - I've learned a lot and enjoyed it. Work-Life balance is good. Even in times of crisis, we were not as stressed as we were before Cisco bought us. One reason is the demand made by Cisco to it's departments to define reasonable, deliverable goals. Even getting fired by Cisco is pleasesnt - I was fired as part of a mass layoff - the compensation package is very generous and they even provide proffesional help on getting a new job. To me that says a lot. Plus, Every one I've met in Cisco was super nice and professional. Also, Once my manager approved - Cisco had no problem allowing me to work part time, on fair conditions. That meant a lot to me.
cons: Big company means big bureaucracy. Some of their processes are very cumbersome and frustrating. Like getting a refund for something you bought for work. So many layers of management and departments - you don't really get to know most of what the company is doing. even though they try to get employees connected and involved - it's a challange.

review_title: You're on your own (that's good and bad)
pros: You're given the tools you need to do your job and you're entrusted to "do the right thing" (that was in the orientation). There's a complete absence of micromanagement -- no one will tell you what to do, though they will sometimes provide guidance if asked, or as part of regular team operations. Work/life balance is great; everyone is given a CVO to support working from home, which can be expected when you're working with teams all around the world.
cons: Everyone is doing their own thing. Sometimes the pieces come together to make a functioning product/service, but only at the lowest levels. The higher you go, the less likely it is that what you're working on will play nicely with what someone else is working on, and there is little broad leadership to tie all of the pieces together.

pros: Cisco has a strong brand for good reason, our technology creates the industry benchmark. Cisco encourages innovation, and as a result we are continuously improving and creating relevant products & solutions across vertical industry & market segments. Collaboration is encouraged, and making use of the tools allows the individuals the flexibility of managing our personal lives, whilst still being inspired to overachieve in this highly competitive business. The learning & exposure opportunities are endless, and in the right markets there is a huge opportunity to grow. Cisco has exceptional leaders, creating a solid vision, where the technologists can innovate, and the sales & engineers can expect the technology to work as expected.
cons: The expectations on achieving sales objectives can sometime be ruthless, and having one bad year could compromise your role in the company. The trends of constant restructures & reorganisations is negatively impacting on the employees moral.

pros: Custom fitted we meet our customers need.
cons: Sales, employed sowing personnels and pay

pros: An amazing collection of smart people, typically new(ish) technologies, and serious name recognition on your resume. Pay seemed very reasonable, direct managers were fantastic
cons: There's no loyalty once you get perhaps two-three managers above you. A company this size is, perhaps by necessity, run by numbers and not people. That means if it makes sense to restructure and 500 people need to find new work, that's what happens. Everyone knows this every day, so if another offer comes along, there's no reason not to take it, and I think the whole product line suffers because of that.

pros: It's great working with top technology talent of the world. Great focus on revenue implications of every product initiative.
cons: Lot of redundant processes and flab that wavers PM focus from actual deliverables. Lot's of stake holders for every initiative that results in long delays in decision making and new initiative roll out

pros: Great big company. Cisco culture is still on a personal level and that is a great quality! Living far from the office, managements advice is to work from home. How good is that! The vision Cisco has is very exciting to be part of.
cons: Strict promotion process what can make talent to leave. In the transition the company is in, there is a culture gap of traditional Cisco and the new Cisco.

review_title: BEST company I've ever worked for
pros: Culture is absolutely fantastic. Managers are trained to be managers and handle people effectively. I love coding as spare activities, my manager encourages this and it has led to very creative and interesting results. We feel like part of a family and the benefits are outstanding. I just told my parents 'hey this colleage gave me $100 on a connected recognition award because I helped him outside my normal activities" and they were like 'wait, you guys send MONEY to each other just because?" and I explained, not just because, there is a way for us to recognize one another with giftcards, of course supervised and honor-based. They could NOT believe it. sometimes neither can I. Tons of benefits. would recommend 10/10.
cons: some roles (like mine) are not fully mobile, meaning I need to visit partners every now and then, this doesn't allow me to go for example to a friend's apartment in new york and work from there, and explore NYC at night. (just an example).

review_title: Great place to work for grads
pros: Joining as a graduate and having been part of other graduate roles with other companies that I won't name, Cisco really devotes a lot of time to training and developing their employees. The interview process did not accurately reflect the culture that lies within Cisco, one that truely cares and provides meaningful work. As someone who struggled with the quarter life crisis, wondering if a terrible 9-5 job for the rest of my life in 'mundane corporate' doing pretty much nothing but pretending to look busy whilst shuffling numbers on spreadsheets or doing meaningless presentations no one cares about, Cisco definitely changed my perspective on corporate life. The work is meaningful, it gives me purpose, and whilst it is challenging, you are adequately rewarded and then some. The people are excellent and if you are passionate about technology, this is the place to be. A moral and ethical company, I strongly feel that Cisco is a great place to work. I highly recommend to anyone who were overachievers in high school and university who feel like their talent is wasted at other companies to apply to Cisco as they will push you to your best.
cons: There is some cons to mention however. Again and again, I keep seeing people who are toxic to the organisation promoted. Positive encouragement and a flexible culture should be fostered and those that promote this culture of pushing boundaries, thinking outside the box, creativity, and making decisions with a bit of gut should be moved forward. Those who hold a traditional view of the office, making every i is dotted and every t is crossed, with their archaic ways and no value add to the company should be kept in positions where they have no influence over the culture or better, removed.

review_title: Interesting and exciting role at the cutting edge of the sector
pros: Cisco is a rapidly evolving, ambitious and forward thinking company at the cutting edge of the sector. Being part of the newly formed Customer Success function within the business is giving me an opportunity to help drive, shape and participate in one of the newest, most innovative roles in the business. As a large organisation, there are also a plethora of opportunities to branch off into other areas as my career with Cisco evolves.
cons: As this is a relatively new role and function within Cisco, the processes and reporting are still quite new and would benefit from some refinement.

pros: work life balance, Flexibility and culture

pros: Cisco gives you lots of opportunities to develop your skills and grow in your carrier path. If you put a lot of effort in your daily work, you will always be recognized and rewarded. Cisco cares ebout employees, having opportunity to work from any place leads to great work-life balance.

review_title: Customer focus is king at Cisco
pros: Cisco is truly about "customer first" so you don't waste time and energy for internal fights or administrative nightmares, people and management style is driven by self-empowerment, Cisco has great agile work culture and teaming, people really want to help each other, at Cisco you enjoy a world-class workspace and unique technology available to everyone which make working in a truly global company such a great experience, home-office is just normal since ever, which gives a fantastic level of flexibility for your daily work. You can do what you believe is the right thing to do.
cons: constant change and self organisation can be challenging at some times. You constantly have re-shape your job role, which can be sometimes a bit overwhelming.

pros: Clearly moved on from just a router supplier and now a real network company far beyond hardware, really investing heavily in the software and capabilities part of the business. The Executive are also well aware of moving to a software licensing business and making sure there's no Cisco Shelfware. The Executive appear to be investing heavily in customer success in it's own capability but also with the partners that's encouraging.
cons: It building up the capability from a small start, so a lot of things are new to everybody, but that does give the opportunity for the company to be open minded about new idea, which so far it seems to be. Whilst the majority of the company take on board the new mission there are a few NIMBI's, but then that would happen anywhere.

pros: Working in Cisco is one of the best experiences that someone can have in his career path. Really pleasant working environment full of intelligent people from all around the world. As Customer Success Managers we deal with many different functions of the company and we are working closely with the customers in order to help them accelerate their business outcomes using Cisco technologies. The opportunities to grow in this company are plenty. Nice benefits and highly skilled people ready to assist you at any time.
cons: As it is a dynamic environment it needs careful consideration for someone who doesn't like changes. Sometimes the training material and process can be too much in order to be up to speed as fast as possible.

pros: Good place to work if you are looking for work flexibility and work life balance. Cutting edge technologies.
cons: Too much process oriented hampering innovation.

pros: While I was there, Cisco was an outstanding company who always supported their employees in any effort to improve. Upon manager approval, they would pay a significant cost for any college course (as long as you pass). They also support many service opportunities for employees. I volunteered numerous hours with coworkers at Second Harvest Food Bank, the American Red Cross and RAFT (Resource Area For Teaching). Cisco will donate $10 per hour of your donated time to the non-profit for which you volunteered.
cons: Too frequent restructuring and changes in management.

review_title: Fantastic colleagues, great culture, jury is out on corporate strategy
pros: Smart people everywhere. Non-hierarchical culture, good ideas from anywhere can get attention and support. Best flexible work practices in the industry, hands down. Cisco really walks the talk and shows how a virtual corporate culture can flourish and pay off. New benefit offerings also speak volumes about how they care for the whole employee - longer paid bonding leaves for parents and grandparents, flexible emergency time off policy that each manager can tailor to meet their employee's needs, Time2Give which provides a full extra week of paid time off per calendar year to volunteer for a non-profit or educational institution of the employee's choice (above and beyond any team volunteering and give back events).
cons: Cisco did not act quickly enough to shift its business model when AWS and other cloud vendors became threats. Now we are playing catch-up. Don't get me wrong, we have ALL the resources needed to win the catch-up game: cash on hand, transformation strategy, excellent CFO explaining it to the street, excellent people... But we have some things that could drag us down: sheer size (lack of agility), continued success in high-margin core business (hard to decide to cannibalize yourself), high-level leaders who have been around too long, have too internal a view, little outside experience and who have succeeded too long in the old way to be willing to jump quickly to innovative strategies or new business models.

Some groups are financially doing better than the others so sentiments across the board vary a lot. Most employees are terrific. Many office spaces are remodeled recently and snacks/coffee/fruits are provided as perks.

pros: As an early in career employee at Cisco, I have been able to gain exposure to many organizations within the business and with upper management. I love that you have the autonomy to make your own schedule, which enables a great work-life balance. The company really values their employees and customers - and I love that we come first.
cons: If you are not able to manage your own time, you might be overwhelmed with getting tasks done and managing the distractions that might arise in this environment.

employee_title: Sales Program Manager & Bow Tie Guy
review_title: Great Company to Learn From and Grow Network
pros: Cisco has 70k employees and somewhere around 40k contractors/vendors (total guesstimate) that work with us full time. We do business in over 120 countries worldwide. If you are a go-getter and have a passion for learning from work experience and global coworkers, Cisco is a perfect place to gain knowledge and grow your network which will help you through the duration of your career. Also, many roles are partial or full telecommute-roles, aka, work from home roles. Helps a lot for families with small children or folks who just live too far from a Cisco campus. There is a good range of younger, fresh out of college employees to seasoned veterans who have been in the industry for 10-30 years - so it's easy to find people that you want to hang out with or learn from. Their social media teams are very engaged and a lot of the groups make working at Cisco fun! The different work teams and affinity network groups host fun events such as sports tournaments, concerts, outdoor lunches, networking events, and many more. We are partnered with Ticketmaster/Live Nation, as well as sports leagues like the MLB and NBA, so you may run into free tickets occasionally. Great benefits (health, dental, vision, stock purchase program, 401k, life insurance), although salary is a bit low.
cons: Free food is not a company standard, although many groups offer some free meals and snacks in the office. The pay is lower than the likes of Google, LinkedIn, Facebook. The company is so big and complex that sometimes, shy, young new hires are underutilized and underdeveloped. Too many meetings. Relatively low base salary, but benefits make up for it.

review_title: I do love where I work!
pros: -Excellent salary, benefits, perks, work/life balance (most of the time) -Great early in career presence, support, and opportunities -People are friendly, welcoming, helpful; fun culture -Lots of great resources on campus (doctor, gym, cafes)
cons: -Leadership information and decisions not always transparent, don't always trickle down well -Internal movement can be difficult and political

review_title: Cisco IT as an Early in Career employee

The people! Everyone I've worked with has been very nice and eager to share knowlege. On campus gym and doctors office at a very reasonable price. Dogs can come in the office on Wednesdays and Fridays.
cons: There's no IT training program for recent grads like there is for sales and HR. Initial team placement after recruitment was off, but I was able to rotate into an area that I'm really excited about after about a year. Continuous layoffs really impact office morale.

pros: I started working at Cisco immediately after graduating college. I was placed in operations and was able to learn some valuable generic business skills. Although the role wasn't necessarily a good long term fit for me, I was able to find a new job within Cisco IT after about 2 weeks of looking for something new. This new role has been amazing! I have a manager who is flexible with my work hours, coworkers who are fun and hard-working, and work that makes me feel fulfilled. Every time I talk to my family about my job and work/life balance, they are amazed and advise I stay at Cisco for as long as I can. I believe I am paid well for my status of early in career and I am learning a lot of skills that will be beneficial in whichever line of work I do. Management is great and I feel that out of the three managers I've had, each one of them were attentive to my personal and career growth. I have not had any experience at other corporate workplaces, but I know that I have fallen in love with the culture of Cisco. I feel as if this is a safe place with no judgments, people who care about you, and provides an open work environment. Definitely a great place to work and I highly recommend!
cons: Cisco is a large company and therefore, it can sometimes take a while to get things done due to red tape. I personally have not encountered this problem yet but have heard stories. Even though I am lucky to be on a team with an average age of about 26, many people who work at Cisco are a little older (or wiser). As an early and career worker, it can sometimes be difficult to relate to those who are 20+ years older than I am but that doesn't mean they are any less nice.

pros: -Flexible work hours and location. I can work remote on days I need to -Visibility to upper-level employees. Frequent events for early in career to learn from the best wisdom at Cisco -Meaningful tasks. I already feel like a value-adding employee after 2 months. -Amazing teaching and learning opportunities. Entire online database of internal education that we are encouraged to learn from -Amazing family. Cisco teammates are excited to help me grow, I do not feel like the environment is negative and competitive. Other young Cisconians willingly have helped me adjust to Cisco
cons: Make sure you are excited about the technology industry and the future that connection can bring the world. Otherwise, you won't like working here.

pros: Management empowers you to voice your new ideas and proposal improvements to the organization. Management will place you with meaningful work that is yours to own start to end. Culture really embraces to influence without authority from all levels which is great. I'm also a board member for one of Cisco's Employee Resource Organization's -- Early Career Network. It's an inclusive community for young professionals starting their careers to network & develop cross functional on the campus. Some of our events include happy hour events, professional development workshops-- negotiate your salary, and volunteer opportunities.
cons: very fast-paced culture and competitive. there's never not enough work to do.

review_title: Awesome Company! Nothing but Truth here!
pros: - Work flexibility - Able to work from home on some days and when needed - Get days off to volunteer - SJ and RTP locations have a gym and medical facility - ECN - Early in Career Network that hold social ,professional development, and volunteer events to meet other Early in Career employees. - Stretch assignments that allow you to take on tasks outside of your organization. All you have to do is signup on the portal.
cons: - Sometimes team members are across the country.

review_title: Great Company to Have a Work-Life Balance
pros: As someone early in their career, I've found that Cisco is a very welcoming environment. Individual contributors have the opportunity to work from home two days per week, and managers are very accommodating to working with occasional schedule conflicts. The benefits (401K employer-match, health insurance, PTO) are fantastic, and employees are also given the opportunity to earn Connected Recognition (awards via gift cards) for outstanding work. In addition to regular PTO, employee are given 40 hours of PTO per year designated to volunteering for the community, and Cisco will give $10 to the organization for every hour and employee volunteers. The cafeterias on campus are delicious and a great deal, and many of the floors in the buildings are being newly renovated. Overall, Cisco is a great place to work!
cons: It is a very large company, so you do have to work alongside people in other time zones via WebEx.

pros: Great experience to work for a company that is a leader not only in the industry, but on a global level. Awesome culture. Seems like there is room for growth especially within Customer Success since it is a newer department. Great pay in comparison to competition.
cons: Because it is such a large company process and change doesn't happen fast. Seems like your input and suggestions are heard, but not much management can do about it. Customer Success is still in start up mode so the process is overwhelming for now, however, it is being refined currently to solve that problem.

pros: Cisco has great benefits, the pay is pretty good, and I think at the top they're moving the company in the right direction. I see and understand the vision that Chuck and the other executives are going and think that the new direction is exactly what the company needs. In the next several years, share holders are going to be very pleased. I think there is great opportunity for growth, and am excited to see where this goes. The work/life balance is incredible. Cisco really wants you to take care of your family because they understand if you are taken care of, you will take care of the company.
cons: I have never seen a company so full of corporate politics. It seems like in order to succeed you have to give the perception of results rather than actually produce results. While the executive team definitely has the right vision, I don't think the lower levels of management, especially those who have been at Cisco for a while, really are excited to make the changes necessary to take this to the next level because it's not the "Cisco way".

review_title: Cisco culture degraded after Chunk Robbins' taking over
pros: We can meet many talents (may be old ones) here. Overall legacy benefits are still good enough in this industry (at around, or a bit above average). If you can lock high position/salary, you shall take it.
cons: After Chunk took over 2 and half year ago, he only give regular employees 2 times of promotion/salary increasing. First interval is 12 months, 2nd interval is 18 months. In John Chambers' time, this interval is 6 months. Normally, at Cisco, each time only 8 - 15% employee got promoted. Even the interval is 6 months, it takes > 3 years for a regular staff to get chance promoted in average. Now Chunk make it 18 months or more, the simple calculation will tell you that each promotion takes more than 10 years in average ! So unless you are at your later stage of career and secure a top position, it's not wise to join Cisco. It's not friendly to its employees anymore. For average people, if he/she joins Cisco now, his/her career development is stalled.

Cisco constantly promotes senior manager (not very technical people) to Principal Engineer. That is why it keeps losing its technical leadership. Losing market share to its competitors.

review_title: Great growing team and exciting company
pros: It has been exciting to join a team where you have opportunities to shape the team culture, participate in process improvement initiatives, and be immersed in innovative technology solutions. There are plenty of opportunities to learn and grow at Cisco. Our executives within Customer Success are open minded and engaged with us to continue to improve and identify how best to serve and help us succeed in our roles. Good benefits
cons: Despite Cisco being a large company, you should expect and be comfortable with change. Processes are continuing to evolve and adapt as Cisco aligns its efforts with its strategic vision. pros: This is a great sales training rotational program for people with sales experience who want to first learn about and understand the Customer Success role. Cisco in general is an amazing company to work for and our leaders are just that; intelligent, committed, individuals who strive to ensure our success. Customer Success is the new era of sales and I would highly reccomend this position. This role is unique in how it exposes you to the new way of not just selling products, but selling business outcomes. It's also exciting for those who like to innovate, value relationship-building with the customer, and pioneer new processes and ideas. I really enjoy being able to have direct impact at a company this big and being a member of the Customer Success Team here at Cisco gives you that unique opportunity. I can't emphasize enough the responsiveness of our executives and leaders; I'm honestly amazed at how Cisco has given new employees the ability to have exposure with our senior management and how willing and compasionate they are about our sales team. I would reccomend Cisco, Customer Success, and Sales to anyone, hands down.
cons: Working at a fortune 100 company as large as Cisco, especially as we migrate our revenue model and product offerings, means there will be holes. I think this is natural at any large company but the mindset of adapting to ever-changing processes, acquisitions, etc. is crucial in order to thrive. Not necessarily a con if you like a challenge and put in a lot of effort. No "work from home" but not necessarily a con either; I personally prefer to come in the office but just something to keep in mind as people have different views on this.

review_title: Not the Cisco of the 90's and early 2000's
pros: Great benefits for employees outside Silicon Valley. Respectable benefits for Silicon Valley Companies. Generally higher than average local salaries than other companies in RTP. Many opportunities to learn and grow professionally, so long as you drive your growth. Top-notch people to work with in US. Complex technology. Cisco culture. Have a serious family emergency, or even minor, most groups understand and always say take care of your family. wonderful examples of employees out for 5 months with medical issues, Cisco and individual team took care of them and family. Child out with serious illness, again most groups really pitch in to help out. Long term, short term disability outside California is not as good as CA, but better than most companies in RTP. Parental leave meets local laws, but not equel throughout company. IC's allowed to make deisions PTO at 4 wks starting can't be beat.
cons: Cisco is very risk adverse for long term projects. Some are ahead of their time, but company not willing to develop market or save product for when market is available. New products only seem to build on existing. Market share loss to cloud vendors, etc. New Security services along with Advanced Sere vices pulling in most of money Work loads can vary by groups. Yearly layoffs becoming a thing. Seems that it's quicker and less expensive to lay off top technical people and hire new ones with some new expertise, rather that really invest in and develop current dedicated staff. Mobile worker cubes and open work environments not conducive to burying your head into work. I'm sure there are far worse places to work in North Carolina

review_title: innovative but paranoid and not very loyal
pros: This is a big company with a lot of great employees and a lot of innovation. Cisco does not want to join the long list of previously great Silicon Valley companies that missed a market transition. They are constantly trying new strategies (which gets a little exhausting at times, throwing stuff at the wall and seeing what sticks). I think the salary, bonus, and RSUs for top performers are very strong.
cons: 2005-2014 I thought Cisco was a great place to work, but not a good stock to own. Now it is kind of the opposite. If your Business Unit is not growing by 10% annually, you will get your budget cut proportionally and that money will go to the growing BUs. Our BU growth slowed, and we got cut a little in 2014, a LOT in 2016, and now again in 2017 including me.

review_title: Massive identity Crisis - not for the faint of heart
pros: Large company with some talented people and some opportunity if you are in the right place at the right time . Cisco also highly values its corporate culture and identity, and has taken recent strides to create a newer, more modern work culture to the best of its ability.
cons: Large company with lots of places for un-talented, lazy people to hide. You may also find yourself in the wrong place at the wrong time working for/with the wrong person or people.
