cons: - Constant lay-offs make it hard to stay aligned with your goals and even know what you job is at times. Sometimes you also wonder how they make some of their decisions on who to keep and who to let go - Because the company is so large, it can feel like the work you do is just a drop in the bucket - Collaborative work spaces

review_title: Great company to have it on resume but not to grow with
pros: - Having Cisco in your resume.
cons: I have been at Cisco almost 20 years and I have seen it all. - You get the promotion in title but not in money or the direct training. - They used to want you to have a 65% customer facing, now it is close to 90%. - Terrible tools to work with, and especially exposing customer to it, frustrates everyone. - No trainings being offered. We have internal trainings available but management dont give you the time to do it since they expect you to be almost 100% customer facing. - Bonuses are being cut off all the time. - Benefits are being cut. - Frequent management reorganization is distractive. - Everyone is trying to save their job so there are not many enabler managers. - Layoffs every 6 months and outsourcing jobs to 3rd party contractors offshore. - Don't expect this work to be 40 hours a week. most of us put double that. That is what is expected.

pros: - Fantastic place for women to work. There are certainly areas where they could be recognized, appreciated or rewarded more often, but 8 times out of 10 Cisco does encourage and support its female employees. - Lots of opportunities (along with the freedom) to get involved in any of the countless org-related, business-related, company-related, CSR-related activities. - Breadth and depth of senior-level engineering talent is incredible. - Plenty of money available to spend and so many initiatives can get funded (at least until initial field trials).
cons: - Extremely mid-heavy (director and senior director levels), sometimes with zero direct reports. - As is the case with most employers, HR is an necessary evil. Stifling stack ranking culture. - Pay is less than competitive. Raises and promotions are not merit-based. - Company-wide layoffs (aka "restricted restructuring"), RIFs, downsizing every 15-18 months with clock-like regularity. This happens on a massive scale globally, affecting the US predominantly.

pros: - New Hire Training in SF - Cisco Webex in the US - Cisco Webex Management/Leadership in the US - Sales Kick-Off in Vegas
cons: - Product: Working for Webex felt like you were part of a marketing hoax by Cisco, there is barely any integration to other business units and the revenue contributed to the overall revenue is only marginal, which leads to you not being taken seriously unless you are working on big deployments. - Management: There is no leadership in the UK. Fear-mongering and a passive aggressive attitude in team/individual meetings add to a strange and dampened atmosphere. (!) If the Software/Cloud Sales Lead calls himself "the Supreme Leader", then take this seriously, as its meaning is conveyed in his management style. Middle Management, many without any prior experience, is a mouthpiece of upper management. - Work Environment: Sadly, the environment is toxic and there is no sense of team atmosphere. There is an obvious segregation amongst team members. Multiple people have been fired in the past. - Compensation: Average to below average if you live in London. - Career Progression: No career progression (!). "Senior" positions are created for doing the same job and for little extra pay, you have no options to progress further unless you move to a different business unit, which some were able to do. - Location: You will be based in Feltham and you will not be allowed to work remotely (but it's Webex, right?) or in the City (unless it is an emergency or other circumstances).

review_title: Great place to work, not so great to get stuff done
pros: Cisco has great benefits, decent compensation, and is generally a great place to work.
cons: The company is greatly held back by the weight of its previous successes. Its flagship products (router/switches) are powered by an OS written in the early 90s. The groups that work on these products are typically 10 years behind the rest of the industry, and are so large that the rest of the company is held back by them. Management has been aware of this for years, and so has been acquiring other companies to do the development work that its core engineering groups are simply incapable of doing. This makes the company a bit schizophrenic as there is no real coordinated effort to move the company in a specific direction. This is not a condition unique to Cisco; Microsoft famously has similar problems with Windows. It does not make the company a bad one, but it's certainly not as forward looking as you might think. The siren call of several billion dollars a quarter for basically not changing *anything* is tough to ignore, and I certainly don't blame them for it. But as an engineer, it's frustrating to watch this happen.

pros: (1) One stop for all of networking products. You'll find the best folks in industry who have journeyed through the evolution of computer Networking. (2) Some of the folks have rich expertise on software development process and Networking solutions and technologies, and are easily approachable. Folks are smart and ready to share knowledge. (3) Offers a great work life balance, Good for married people or for those wanting to settle. (4) Things are only left for individuals to explore. You have lot of technologies around to explore/learn and gets your hands dirty with. some of the tech-leads and principal engineers are really of great quality. (5) Over a period of time, the technology stack and culture can get imbibed into you so much that you'll get comfort-zoned easily, and I saw many people who left Cisco returning back after a few years, after missing the great cisco culture :-). Overall Cisco is a great company!
cons: (1) The market correction of salaries for experienced ones is often ignored(though it was brought up in many forums). People who joined 3-4 years back get the same salaries as current college hires/freshers in some of the BUs. Cisco India has less stock options/perks. (2) Your career growth- in terms of position/title can be bit slow or depends upon your senior management (as in any other company), and in terms of visibility grows depending on how many seniors you have in your team. Every company has pros/cons and same thing here. Overall Cisco is a great company, having a high reputation, good to have in resume, offers good work life balance and exposure.!

pros: Lots of great people - generally super-helpful Excellent flexibility to work mobile or from home Top-notch communications technology (natch) Pay & benefits are pretty good Workspaces are pretty good (the newer ones anyway) Strengths-based performance management system (Stand Out program) Excellent learning & development opportunities
cons: Lots of politics in the sales organization Scale - finding the right people who can help you can be challenging and the org chart isn't very useful Salary increases only come if you get promoted - no cost-of-living adjustments Continuous restructuring as company changes focus Bureaucracy - getting stuff done can be difficult Product mentality is still network-biased and breaking out of that is challenging Work-life balance not as good as first claimed

pros: Best people in the business. Great customer focused culture. Open door policy that really works.

pros: - CISCO work culture is Open and inclusive. Open: There are no barriers or inherent hierarchy that limits an employee from reaching out to peers or seniors. The culture encourages collaboration, learning and gives the employee a place to broaden their horizons in terms of theirs skills and knowledge. Inclusive: CISCO believes in inclusive environment where everyone gets equal opportunity to grow and develop. It is not only inclusive in terms of people but also in terms of growth in recreational activities like sports and arts. It is quite difficult to find such a culture in other companies in India. - Awesome benefits: The benefits provided by CISCO is by far the best that I have known. The benefits include Health coverage for Family (yourself, spouse, children and parents or in-laws). This is quite rare compared to other companies health benefits. Free GYM, periodic health checkups for yourself, family and parents. Extremely well maintained sports facilities for shuttle, cricket, volley ball and basketball and various others. It supports tuition fee refund for any education/course you take. - Good Personal and Professional life balance: The work culture is flexible and allows the employee to maintain a balanced personal and professional life. Managers are very understanding and in general the management encourages the employee to ensure a good balance in work and personal life.
cons: The hike and promotion cycle is fixed. The employee has to finish a certain period of time before being considered for a hike or promotion. This doesn't correspond to the work done by him/her.

review_title: Cisco - More like a bank. No real RnD going on.
pros: Good package, Good work life balance, good start for fresher's I'm terms of package.
cons: No job security. Employees live in fear of layoffs everyday. No real RnD going. Cisco wants to be huge, but there is no concrete vision. It's more of a bank. Lot of buying and selling. Staying at Cisco for long, could end your career due to lack of challenge. They don't have uniform policies across countries. Biased policies, Indian employees are taken for granted.

review_title: Flexible work schedule and Brilliant professionals
pros: Forward looking culture. Great work schedule flexibility, pay, and benefits. Tremendous collaborative culture. Worked with some of the smartest professionals I've encountered during my career. Empowerment to drive innovation and personal brand.
cons: Because even a single team can span the globe, the non-traditional work schedule that is so wonderful can also intrude upon "non-working" hours. The flexible location / virtual collaboration philosophy that Cisco markets is limited and doesn't always apply to positions that can effectively be managed remotely; there remains core belief that synergy is more effectively driven physically.

pros: I love the people that I work with - they support me and challenge me every single day! I also love that Cisco places such importance on giving back to the community. We are encouraged to give back with our time, and we even get 5 days of "giving back" time every year, in addition to regular time off. I also love that no matter my passion, or how I want to grow, there is a role for that at Cisco. I also love that I have had the chance to take a TON of leadership training throughout my career. There have been opportunities specific to being a woman - how to navigate an industry where I am a minority, and helpful tips on managing my career, and opportunities available to all, to grow as a team leader, a strategic leader, and as a person.
cons: Every role has his ups and downs, as does every company. But what I have found is that we work through them all as a team and as an entire company. We all have to do our part, and we never lose alone, because we have the whole Cisco team behind us.

review_title: Great Pay Master with strong focus on RnD

cons: Scope of improving leadership , free up management from politics

Business Outlook
Pros
I loved being challenged and learning new technologies. The people I worked with were like a family; everyone was always looking out for each other. The engineers I worked with were some of the most talented in the industry.

review_title: Bright, generally decent people, good culture; some concerns
pros: - Generally speaking, the majority of the people that are hired are bright, passionate and decent. - Cisco culture is generally good: geeky and business saavy - Executive Team is solid and reasonably visionary (though this varies) - Cisco has automated a lot of the low-hanging fruit of administrivia - e.g., expense reports - to reduce some of the clutter - You are part of a very large and powerful force in technology. - The company encourages people to do a lot in their communities, etc.
cons: - Cisco has gotten into this weird habit of doing small lay-offs ~ every 6 months. Some of this is just a forcing function to help Managers who are not doing a good job of moving out under-performers. The list goes out and managers are allowed to put people on it. But it also creates an environment where everyone feels vulnerable. At the wrong place at the wrong time? Got re-orged to a Team managed by a former rival, who sees you as a threat? Regardless of performance, you can be RIF'ed. - Company is transitioning from traditional hardware/rout/switch & accompanying on-prem software dominated company to have a bigger emphasis on cloud-delivered software and subscription based business. It's a bit of a bumpy ride. - a little stodgy/old world tech (IBM-ish) in some areas. - all the things that go along with a being a huge company: e.g., grinding bureaucracy

review_title: Always changing, never boring - which is a blessing and a curse ...
pros: Great company culture, with no penny pinching, solid training and amazingly intelligent colleagues. Opportunity to make some great money. I support and sell a mature, industry leading product. Full time work from home, with a reasonable travel schedule.
cons: Things change constantly. Every year is another guess as to wether our team stays together, or not. Despite selling a great product, it's not getting the focus is needs to stay innovative.

review_title: Great company to work. Excellent benefits.
pros: Exposure to latest technologies. Excellent work from home option. Half yearly bonus. Recognition in terms of RSU, gift vouchers and much more. Company transport at a very subsidised rate. Manager feedback etc
cons: Be ready to be fired any time. Quarterly results play a vital role. Cisco is well renowned for networking and firing Annual appraisal depends on your business unit. You will get used to hearing headcount reduction, business unit sale or some acquisitions quite often. Appraisal only single digit. Performance doesn't matter when it comes to firing. I feel sad for my fellow Colleagues losing jobs

pros: Great company to work for as long as your willing to put in the time and effort. Great benefits, compensations and bonuses. Employee commitment is there in good times. Company meetings are amazing. Food services provided are a nice touch.
cons: Way to many layoffs, reorganizations, restructure of groups. Cant keep a leader for more than a year for the past 5 years. When time gets a little tight layoffs or major budget cuts happen which makes it unmanageable to handle your daily tasks. , meanwhile 40B in the bank. I say reduce leadership spend (salary) to save employees jobs

pros: Still the leader in the industry. Lots of experienced people in the RS, networking, SDN etc. area. Good employee benefits, OK work & life balance. Salary is OK but not great.
cons: Too many re-orgs. Depending on your team, but once per 6-month would not be abnormal. Your performance is evaluated heavily by your visibility, so the people just doing the talk and knows how to play the game of favoritism are considered having great "leadership" skills. Hard and honest work seldom get you promoted. Few people would speak out when decisions from higher management clearly not making sense, where are the backbones?

cons: Competition is coming after Cisco. Past few acquisitions failed.

pros: Good pay. Good challenges. Good autonomy.

pros: Technology leader; industry bellwether; sophisticated internal tools and systems for support; amazing team of people ready to cooperated and collaborate; great customer base.
cons: Many acquisitions facilitating confusion. Constantly changing strategies and company goals. Sales tactics too focused on quotas, rather than customer requirements. Outsourcing too much to India-based partners who are good people and hard workers, but offer Cisco cheap labor using inexperienced partially qualified labor. Advancement based on personal network, rather than performance. Many (non-technical) employees (Program Managers, Marketing, Sales, etc.) are decent people with good intentions, but are unqualified and lack relevant experience with technology.

pros: Great company to work for, especially with constant focus on cutting-edge technologies and diversification into new areas of IT infrastructure and applications. Benefits are excellent.
cons: Constant reorgs over the past few years means slim chances of moving into a position that is a better fit for the employee. Getting your "foot in the door" may not necessarily be the best way to advance your career, whether an employee or contractor. I have seen good managers with 10-15+ years get laid off during these reorgs, so no one is safe.

A lot of managers offer flexibility with the ability to work remotely once a week, however this position is not a remote job. The organization does their best to recognize hard working individuals
cons: Low pay compared with other customer facing roles at Cisco High Stress - the account teams and customers expect you to be the one with the answers You can get pigeon holed into one particular technology, especially if your technology is not 'hot' Have to work weekends

antly acquiring new companies gives great horizontal and vertical career growth as well the opportunity for skills development and training

review_title: East or West Cisco is the BEST!!
pros: 1. Transparent organisation publishing company performance, ongoing changes and methods to adopt 2. Great people in management who care about employees and take their feedback seriously 3. Flexible working structure, not much is asked in terms of sacrificing personnel time 4. People are there to help in every step of the way

review_title: Help us attract more diversity to Cisco
pros: -innovative company -moves quickly despite large size -sales driven -management makes the right decisions to correct the course -provides large responsibility to the individual contributor level -excellent management -I believe this company provides as close to equal pay as possible - I am fortunate to work for a woman who is an executive's multiplier who lifts me up with her access to execs.
cons: -not as diverse as I would like it to be -doesn't provide the opportunities for exposure at higher levels (need multiplier effect to be multiplied) -women at the top tend to be viewed as ruthless and not helping other women succeed -not a lot of ODs are women - which appears to be a big differential - without my manager's support I would be very lost in this culture.

review_title: Great work life balance and respectful co-workers
pros: This company has a culture of consensus, which means that we can take a lot of time to make decisions, but at least there's no bully in the room dictating one way or the high way. What I enjoy the most about Cisco is that it has given me the opportunity to be truly me: I have been promoted twice in 7 years, while having a 1 year old son when I started and a baby 4 years after starting at Cisco. Whenever my kids are sick, or I had to take them to an appointment, my team always had my back. This is the main reason why I am at Cisco - this employer will make sure men and women can have exciting opportunities at work WHILE being a parent. We have 40 hours a year of volunteer time, I use it to attend my kids field trips and volunteer at school. There is true worklife balance and a lot of flexibility when it comes to working hours. As a woman, I value this tremendously.
cons: This is a very very big company and if you don't network and get out to meet people, you'll miss out on opportunities.

review_title: Smart intelligent people inthe trenches, stale senior leadership
pros: The people. The technology. The teamwork.
cons: Old School boys club still exists in sales. It's not based on capabilities but who you know. If your in sales there is a lack of opportunities to move upward. Very few women in sales leadership roles.

review_title: The best work life balance company

cons: * Slow on change * Slightly political due to turf wars

pros: Ability to work remotely is a Pro

pros: Flexible working Opportunity to travel Working with huge global organisations

pros: macbook, no time restriction, work from home, great campus

pros: flexible working style, hour, and stable

review_title: Cisco is a fantastic place to work!

review_title: Playing catch up on Inclusion & Diversity
pros: As a new hire out of college, I was trusted with managing an application a few months into my role. This was very empowering and showed that leaders in the group were accepting of my talents and skills and they did not make assumptions about my inabilities just because I was fresh out of college. When mistakes were made, they were acknowledged and treated as learning opportunities and individuals who genuinely work hard get recognized. We have a great Inclusion & Diversity team and there are diverse leaders that help individual contributors gear up to bringing their whole selves to work. If it were not for the Employee Resource Organizations (EROs) / Employee Resource Groups (ERGs), working at Cisco would not feel impactful. I am grateful that we have an Inclusion & Diversity team and leaders that support the EROs so that leaders of the EROs can work to change the culture positively throughout Cisco.
cons: Not all organizations / teams in Cisco are open to all diversities and do not promote inclusion & diversity. It is not easy to be an LGBT employee in certain groups at Cisco and bring your whole self to work for fear of being treated differently. Cisco tends to be a follower in inclusion and diversity trends rather than a leader in trends when it comes LGBT employee needs.

pros: Breadth of solutions to represent, dedicated to diversity, excellent pay and benefits package, and commitment to making the world a better place - Cisco lives that daily. Very inclusive and generally does an excellent job of communicating strategy and goals through town hall style meetings
cons: Regular right-sizing of the business can sometimes catch employees off-guard.

pros: Work life balance good family culture
cons: Legacy more focus on routers and switches

pros: Very good culture, Great work life balance, Huge campus with lots of facilities

pros: Work from home, great benefits, everyone is very friendly, all expense paid travel

pros: Cisco truly embraces a diverse workforce in terms of gender, ethnicity, generation, experience, and more. As a female senior leader, I can look around and see plenty of people who look like me and plenty who don't, all working collaboratively and with great respect and trust. At Cisco, everyone has a voice and we look out for each other.
cons: Cisco is a large and rapidly growing company and like all large corporations, you have to have a strong network to be the most effective. That can take time to build but once you make a few connections, it expands rapidly.

pros: Flexible work schedule, great benefits, team orientated.
cons: workforce adjustments yearly.

I feel I can further my career in a same way as my colleagues. flexibility and availability to work from home allows for more balanced work-life schedule and even though I work many hours I do enjoy it and I feel this is m,y choice and not something that has been impose on me. Cisco also encourages women to take technical and managerial positions and we are being rewarded for it.

review_title: Cisco continues to inspire me to be my best at work every day
pros: As a lesbian, I can bring my whole self to work every day I am both challenged and supported by my management I have been promoted and offered lateral movement cross-functionally My work-life balance is good, and supported by management and colleagues My pay and benefits are comparable to colleagues who are working elsewhere
cons: Company not growing in total, but going through transition/growing pains now Physical commute (in SJ) can be painful

pros: There's a reason why so many employees stay for 10+ years and/or come back after leaving Cisco. Great benefits, diverse workforce, excellent work/life balance, reasonable pay. Good training and career opportunities for women right out of college. Dedicated people. Strong executive team. Very competitive.
cons: 1. I recommend that mid-career women joining Cisco enter at a level they can live with during the rest of their time at Cisco. Only lateral career moves will be available to you after you join. Don't expect to see a raise or a promotion. 2. There is a layoff EVERY year at Cisco. Work slows and morale tanks the moment the rumor of a layoff begins to circulate. Bottom line: one quarter a year is lost because everyone around you is terrified of losing their job. 3. Engineering org is predominantly male and engineering leadership is almost universally male. It's easy to get used to men talking over you in meetings, and promoting your ideas as their own. 4. There is a lot of finger pointing at Cisco. People have a lot of responsibility but little accountability. 5. Extremely hierarchical. You talk to your manager, they talk to their manager, that manager talks to their manager. Only Director level and above have any authority. 6. Every career movement is dependent on your manager's approval. If your manager is a dud, your opportunities at Cisco shrink to zero.

pros: Interesting products if you can fight the politics
cons:
Constant layoffs and no future

review_title: good place for women bc of work life balance

review_title: Great flexibility, discriminatory culture, poor training
pros: There are a lot of things to like about working for Cisco; A fantastic, flexible, 'work-from-where-you-are' policy, great benefits and PLENTY of projects to work on.
cons: Cisco is a company with old values, expect age discrimination and little to no training. It can be frowned upon to take time off, or take time for learning, which results in most of the workforce woefully overworked and sadly behind the times in training. The cult of positivity is also very strong at Cisco, which makes trying to change processes or culture VERY difficult, any suggestion of change is usually taken personally and can result in active obstructionism to your goal.

review_title: Great Challenges and Opportunities to Grow
pros: Collaborative, challenging work environment. Pushed to create your own role and goals, lots of opportunities to stretch and develop.
cons: High expectations and always challenging work, sometimes the many disparate tools make it more difficult to find solutions in a timely manner.

pros: Great Culture Smart motivated colleagues who are willing to work with you Great name recognition Strong Partner network Strong sales machine
cons: Currently in a massive cultural change from a infrastructure/hardware firm to a software and services firm is causing a major shift in people, process and strategy Sales teams having a difficult time adjusting to new ays to sell Too reliant on selling to IT, not as relevant in the LOB suite Sales methodology is product sales, not solution or suite selling and that is limiting success Constant layoffs hurting morale

pros: I have been at Cisco for almost 20 years and yes, I never thought I would be at any company so long! However, Cisco has provided me with the professional opportunities I was looking for throughout my entire journey. I have been in several functions across the company - Sales, HR, IT, Operations and was part time for over 8 years while raising my children. I have lived in Sydney and Paris with Cisco and been able to travel and see the world. The people are smart and challenging and there are always problems to solve each day.
cons: Like any company over 20K people, there is a need for consensus at times across several functions and that can slow progress down and be frustrating.

pros: Cisco allows for lateral rotational opportunities, a number of give-back programs, and there are employment resource organizations which allow for networking opportunities. There are a number of employees with tenure grater than 4 to 6 years.
cons: There are often layoffs every 6months but these which can be countered by lateral rotations.

review_title: Great place to work, some patience necessary
pros: Fantastic benefits, flexible hours, interesting problems to solve, and fun people to solve problems with
cons: Older parts of the company (both Cisco HQ and recently acquired startups) are reluctant to change their ways, and enjoy grand standing on seniority. Also, some colleagues have extreme alpha male tendencies, which can make for an uncomfortable new-hire environment.

pros: The customer centric culture is sensational. Willingness to work together to make the customer successful is paramount. Growing opportunities for women - Chuck Robbins has advanced topic of gender and overall diversity during his tenure.
cons: Not sure we have the right strategy to speed up and execute more quickly. Ongoing. rolling quarterly layoffs are destabilizing - but not sure there is a better way to get to our goals at quickly enough.

pros: -- Excellent place to work. -- Great flexibility to work -- All the information easily available -- Very good office space. -- Gives more oppurtunities to work with new technologies.
cons: There is Nothing Major to tell on the cons.

review_title: I can't say enough good things about Cisco
pros: Flexibility, inclusive, fun activities, respectful and collaborative environment, innovation. Compared to lot of other companies, Cisco has a variety of events and activities to engage people from all culture and generations.
cons: Need to employ more Women in the work place

pros: very supportive of mobile working and working from home. great option for working moms. lots of interesting internal programs and courses for development.
cons: very SJ (US) oriented - workers from other parts of the globe are de facto excluded from various activities due to timezone and holiday differences. many frontal courses are offered only in US constant LRs make it hard to plan ahead career development

pros: Excellent job opportunities; Remote work; Technology; People
cons: Global company so timezone issues when working on projects; Pay not always equal to men although this SHOULDN'T be an issue

pros: Flexibility, great pay, innovative and good people
cons: No annual appraisals so managers can do what they want, most upper management has no clue about the bad moral, no promotions, no stock options, no recognition

pros: Working at Cisco is very flexible. Cisco is all about work-life balance. There are lots of opportunities to succeed and add value.
cons: Expect to work hard, competition is stiff. Women are still paid less than men, however, they are working on it.

pros: Cisco has the perfect balance of innovation, from a technical perspective, and established business practices with a strong customer base. A primary benefit to employees is a reasonable pace. It's possible to do excellent work without sacrificing one's personal goals and the work environment is definitely more collaborative than competitive. An additional benefit is the ability to move about the company to work on different products and projects. The employee population is remarkably diverse and both the executive leadership and HR underscore the value of inclusion and collaboration (diversity) in both it's composition and everything it says and does. Cisco takes diversity very, very seriously. Deep support for working remotely is absolutely outstanding! We're able to draw talent from all over the world instead of limiting ourselves to only those people who are willing to live in or near Silicon Valley.
cons: The overall culture isn't quite as tech intensive as the culture I've experienced at major software and services companies such as Microsoft. At other companies for example, demos of products in development were a critical component of any meeting. At Cisco we tend to focus on the bigger business picture.

pros: Smart, caring people, lots of opportunity to shine and make an impact, as well as give back to causes you care about and support the community. Leadership is truly compassionate and caring and will work hard to support your career journey.
cons: If you don't have a solid career plan, you can become stagnated and for those of us who have trouble with direction and asking for help, it's a challenge (but that would be anywhere!).

review_title: Hope I never have to work anywhere else
pros: I love the flexible schedules and the ability to work from home. The culture, the people, the constant learning... it's great. In 12 years I have only ever encountered one bad manager and that person was released within 6 months. They really listen to the people in all levels of employment.
cons: the hours... while the schedule is flexible, when working in a sales support role, the hours are not the typical 8-5 m-f. I have worked many late nights and many weekends. There are some weeks where my hourly pay is minimum wage due to being on salary. Answering the phone or responding to texts and emails outside of the 8-5 hours is required, not just expected.

review_title: Great diverse, flexible place to work!
pros: I am a professional woman who has worked at Cisco for 6 years and have loved the company culture since Day #1! Cisco values and respects its employees and I enjoy working in a diverse environment of mutual respect where all ideas and points of view are welcome. I also enjoy the flexible work environment and Cisco's commitment to work-life balance. I also love Cisco's commitment to giving back to the Community. Cisco's Corporate Social Responsibility is strong and that is important to me!
cons: Change is constant at Cisco and, in order to be successful at Cisco, employees must be agile and be able to adjust to change and sometimes work and push forward amidst ambiguity.

review_title: Cisco is a great place to be!
pros: At all levels of the organization, there is emphasis and value put on diversity in the workplace. Many leaders understand the beauty and strength of our differences, and are not interested in creating a cookie cutter employee. Many of the perks of being a Cisco employee highlight how much they want to take care of their employees, such as the onsite health and fitness centers, family events on campus, etc, but they go beyond these "nice to have" items and back up their words in the work. My opinion is appreciated most when it differs from those around me and offers a fresh perspective. We also have very strong communities to support each other and enable success of the individual.
cons: There are very few cons when it comes to working for Cisco. It certainly isn't like a startup environment and ideas can take longer to put into action because of the bureaucracy that comes with a company of over 70k employees, but you can learn to navigate these waters smoothly. There is vibrancy and learning at Cisco that you won't find elsewhere.

review_title: 3 Maternity Leaves Later... Still Going Strong
pros: Flexible schedule, meaningful work, competitive pay, career path
cons: Fast pace industry has employee health implications

review_title: Experience at Cisco as a woman
pros: Flexibility; supportive management; empowered to run own schedule
cons: often day job runs into the evenings trying to manage the work load

pros: Good Place to work, perfect work life balance
cons:
You will spent most time on legacy codes

pros: Flexible hours, including the ability to work from home Amazing, intelligent, creative people Cisco is trying to do good things in the world
cons: Cisco's first priority is its financial commitment to its shareholders. If a project / business unit is not profitable... they fire people ("limited restructuring" or "LR"). They don't VALUE each person and try to find new projects for talented, hard-working, dedicated employees. They just fire them. So consequently we don't feel appreciated. So we are all walking around waiting for the next LR, wondering who will be next... it's stressful and unmotivating. The only reason people stick around is to get the "package" when they are LRed.

pros: I can work from home
cons: Sexism (belief that women aren't as capable, often unrecognized by the men themselves until you show it to them, which can be detrimental to your career as well), lack of good mentoring, lack of advancement, lack of female leadership

pros: work life balance, respect and care for employees, innovative
cons: complex, bureacratic red tape, multiple databases

pros: Within my organization, inside Cisco - leadership continues to raise the awareness on I&C. Individuals are aligned to a mentor to assist in their role for today and the role they want tomorrow. Those that perform are able to turn mentoring relationships into sponsorship's. A mentor talks with you and a sponsor talks about you.
cons: Even though Cisco is moving the needle, diversity - on all levels - is still something that needs work.

review_title: Full time female staffer at Cisco UK
pros: Interesting work, great colleagues and a fantastic approach to flexible working. I've found the company are happy to support any combination of office location, (or multi-locations in my case), home working and flexible hours to make your life work. Basically, as long as you're professional about getting the work done and being responsive for your collegues, you can be very flexible about configuring your work day and location(s). Presumably there are some roles where Cisco can't be so flexible, but my experience in technical work is that there are few limitations.
cons: Some admin processes are cumbersome, although they've improved recently.

pros: Good infrastructure. Great peers. Good learning experience . A company where the higher management listens . Very approachable management.
cons: Salary and hikes/promotions are less for women workforce. Some policies are in paper.Work from option itself given as a big favor and counts it during appraisal . Women leadership is not much encouraged.In my BU I see a very few. Process sometimes complicates. HR not much helpful.

pros: There is never a dull moment, always working with cutting edge technology with awesome executive coverage. Cisco opens doors where others struggle. Lots of opportunity to work with the best and interesting new technology with tremendous scope for innovation. I have rarely found leaders who are so supportive of "trying" things, whether its in the technology space or who we handle customers or teams.
cons: We do lack diversity and most often than not I am the only female be it in meetings, workshops or even off-sites. We also work in predominantly male dominated society so sometimes getting people to take you seriously especially as a leader or a technocrat is extremely difficult.

pros: Cisco has some great values that help day to day motivation at work: 1) Respect for Individual 2) High Flexibility 3) Good help if asked for I have been with Cisco for six years now and the constant thing that kept me going is the above values that are practiced and valued.
cons: Learning is a self defined thing at Cisco, the way you manage your work, performance, life and learning in career are a matter of personal efficiency and not something some one else will steer for you or help

review_title: Cisco really is an amazing company to work for!
cons:
ltant in New Bedfont, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Having worked in Cisco for nearly 17 years, I can honestly say it is an amazing company to work for and I have had amazing opportunities to grow and develop my skills and feel respected and cared for as a female progressing my career. Fabulous benefits, wonderful flexible working, great working environment, amazing people and teams.
Cons
There are no cons for me!

pros: Work Life Balance Work from Home Option On Campus Child Care On Campus Health Clinic
cons: Everything depends on Upper Management

pros: Cisco offers a place for people of such diverse backgrounds. I joined later in my career; i hadn't previously worked in IT or for a global corporation but to my surprise, I fitted in. If you are prepared to work hard and are confident enough to come up with ideas, then you are given the opportunity to grow. In recent years I have developed a visual impairment and my Cisco managers have been fantastic at getting me the support I need.
cons: Over my 10 years at Cisco there has been a lot of reorganisation bringing changes to my role, team, managers. However, the rationale and objectives of the changes are always made clear. We do have to live and work wondering what is coming next.

pros: Cisco is a huge company, as such there are lots and lots of different initiatives and opportunities for employees, from volunteering to training courses, employees are really encouraged to take the lead and shape their career.
cons: The downsides are mainly due to the current uncertainty caused by unprecedented times, speed at which markets and technologies need to evolve, for such a large company tough actions have to be taken. Currently we are undergoing a transformation, but this causes frequent reductions in the workforce, change of strategy and its a struggle to feel part of the cisco family that it is often advertised.

pros: A variety of technology to choose from and work on. Flexibility and a sensitivity to employee's needs
cons: ->Senior execs being hired in come with lower and lower calibre. ->No pay for performance - ties back to senior execs being hired - no sense of rewarding desirable behaviors - only taking safe route and "peanut buttering" ->Going through lot of market change dynamics - some pressure being passed down all the way to engineer levels - hopefully the company will come through.

review_title: Great opportunities, flexible conditions, but beware your manager...
pros: If you find a great manager, you'll find a great place to work, supportive team, flexible conditions, remote working/telecommuting opportunities, ability to move around the organisation developing different experience and skills. Compensation is fair, decent recognition and reward program.
cons: Tighter budget and high compliance controls can leave a sour taste, teams are increasingly required to do more with less budget, many teams are over-worked. We no longer hire the top 10% of talent, no longer have the strong employer brand and culture we used to have.

pros: Flat, non hierarchical culture. Focus on outcomes - "what you deliver" rather than hours spent in the office. Flexible culture with high trust from management on working remotely, as long as you continue to deliver well. Very strong benefits, particularly healthcare, insurances and leave policies. Good work environment - relatively low politics and management at the Director and up levels is pretty high calibre
cons: Typical large company issues - bureacracy in getting things done, many people oly willing to work within the narrow silos of their jobs and not stretch beyond. Pay cycles are unpredictable and increase amounts can be below the market.

location: Feltham, South West England, England, England
pros: Incredible flexibility for remote-working, great working and supportive environment, many locations around the world which make if one has to move, for example, for family-related matters.
cons: Somewhat flat structure, hence challenging to create a career path

review_title: Flexible Part Time Working is not a Miracle
pros: - Flexible working hours and work from at home - You decide how and where you work; what counts for Cisco are the results - Great investment in people (benefits, company car, ongoing trainings) - Ability to change jobs/roles within the company - Strong Global Player in I have two kids at home and can still pursue my job as a marketing manager. With the full flexibility and freedom of choice on when and from where (home/office) you want to work this is a very valuable benefit.
cons: - Ongoing waves of headcount reductions have resulted in good people leaving the company and impacted mood of people at some times - Complexity, a lot of administration and tools

review_title: All the benefits and flexibility in the world but it can sometimes be slow process to climb corporate ladder
pros: very accommodating to working from home. very good salary and benefits. lots of extra curricular activities (like employee mentor programs, stretch assignments, employee organisations, fun fund days) and opportunities to take leadership outside of official role.
cons: slow process to go up grades (although can be manager specific). need to be someone who is okay with change and unknowns because reorganizations are common

pros: Cisco is a great place to work especially for women employees , the employee policies are very good .
cons: Opportunities are limited across zones change is difficult

pros: Flexible work hours, plenty of training classes offered by company
cons: Yearly routine lay off. Too much process oriented that leads to additional delay in completing project.

pros: Leaders truly care about employees and the whole employee experience at work. Cisco's cutting edge collaboration tools make meetings a breeze and enable employees to work from just about anywhere. The flexibility to get things done from wherever you are is a perk bar none!
cons: As a company and as individuals, the amount of giving back Cisco does is HUGE, but not publicized well enough to engender collective employee pride or talent attraction. The many ways Cisco uses its technology to change the world, provide disaster relief globally, and truly make a difference often happens in stealth mode. It goes unnoticed. A big miss. Need to redouble PR efforts in this front!

pros: Culture, people, flexibility, technology, direction
cons: Opportunities for advancement are minimal. Increases and options bleak at best.

pros: There are excellent abilities to do stretch assignments and training in this area. Work life balance is excellent! Being a program manager in a new area has been difficult to understand the company from a different aspect. The political climate in his area holds a lot of information close and does not share relevant Information to your job ; this makes it extremely difficult to learn and grow.
cons: Lack of clarity on goals and objectives and a disconnect from the greater mission and vision of Cisco at times.

pros: Great work-life balance and opportunities to challenge yourself
cons: Upper management is disconnected to to the detailed work below and make decisions without truly understanding the impact involved to get to the total numbers.

pros: Cisco consistently upholds the standard that our days start at 8 and we take weekends and holidays. I do end up working out of hours and on holidays but by choice and not requirement. My managers have consistently supported my professional development. I had the opportunity to attend the Simmons Leadership Institute and this made a huge impact on my professional and personal life.
cons: There is little awareness that men talk over women. I am often the only woman in the meeting and have never had a man say "wait, you just talked over her." I often have to wait until every man has finished talking before I can speak when I am running a meeting - when I am not running a meeting I often don't get to talk at all.

pros: Very friendly working environment, I learnt a lot during my internship.
cons: Writing user stories took a lot of time!

pros: Great company to work for-- offers great benefits, a collaborative culture, and the company really cares about their people. The finance team really encourages employees to move around within Cisco finance to gain a better knowledge of how things work.
cons: Although the finance senior leadership has created a culture to encourage movement within the finance department even if it is completely different from your background, some management are still hesitant to accept employees with a different background.

pros: Good work place Flixible timings Nice cafteria

pros: Work from home flexibility and great collaboration among working teams.
cons: Constant restructuring and layoffs makes for an uncomfortable environment and low morale

pros: Gym and health facility, large campus with 3 cafeterias and one specialty coffee shop, casual dress code, large parking lots with plenty of parking, new managers who care to succeed and improve, you are able to bring your laptop home and work from home if needed.
cons: Layoffs every year create very low morale especially during year end which is in July. When people do get laid off, those jobs go to people who are already working a full time job. You end up with people who are doing the job of 4 people which is unsustainable. It creates a bad reputation for that person and causes poor customer service because it is too much work for one person.

pros: Competitive peers, good training and learning opportunities

review_title: Bullying, harassment, swearing, and that's just from management.
pros: Great company name, good products, easy to get meetings, flexible working conditions.
cons: If your face doesn't fit, or your management don't like you, you're be forced out, one way or another, you're sworn at, belittled in front of colleagues and in some cases, clients. You get sent emails on the weekends telling you what you haven't done, or done well, should have done, or done better. Your colleagues turn a blind eye because they don't want to raise their head above the parapitt, Senior management turn a blind eye or point you at HR, who then do everything in their power to make it your fault, or turn the issue into something you caused, and then you're forced out. It happened to me, it's happened to someone I met at Cisco and it's happening right now to someone I've never met. I was sworn at on the phone, I was belittled in front of clients and I was treated like dirt in front of work mates. My weekly forecasting call was an hour of bullying, belittling, chastising and general abuse. The manager in question had done it before and was recorded by HR, but they ignored this and made it me with the problem. The fellow employee that backed up my claims of bullying has also since left. The fellow employee that refused to support me in the process is still there, and a friend of the bullying manager. The senior manager that turned a blind eye is friends on Facebook with the bullying manager.... go figure.. All in all, a hateful place to work, life is too short to work in such a toxic environment and for managers that have no idea how to lead, support, promote or manage in order to get the best from people.

pros: Brand name, First to Market, Learning Curve and Work Life Balance

pros: I've been working at Cisco for 8 years. As a woman, the work flexibility I have to manage my work along with my family needs has been a key reason that I love my job. As I am coming to the end of raising two children, I can look back and feel proud of what I was able to do for Cisco and for my family. The work is always challenging and I have been given almost endless opportunity to use my skills and experience to add value to Cisco. I have been consistently well rewarded for my work, and I have never felt that my gender was a hinderance in what is often considered a male dominated industry. In fact, there have been many opportunities presented because I am a woman, as Cisco takes it's commitment to diversity of all kinds very seriously and they put their money where their mouth is.
cons: As with any large company, there are some disconnects that exist in strategy and approach alignment, but I believe this is very difficult to completely overcome in any large company.

pros: Challenge environment to motivate your career development. Opportunity to work in a flexible environment and Remotely to facilitate to balance properly family and work. In the last Women of Impact event, it was the first time I felt, women was sharing in a open way their responsibilities and needs to balance family and work, considering Cisco Company is impacting very positive in the way of thinking about their Human Resources.
cons: The Environment of excellence produce high competition between Teams and Silos of knowledge.

review_title: Women at Cisco - how is it to work at Cisco
pros: Balanced work life, flexibility in hours and working from home
cons: Limited opportunity for promotion, still long ways for women to get considered for managerial jobs. Low rate of sponsorship vs men and getting support needed to move up.

review_title: Big Corporation lets you focus on personal development
pros: There are lots of resources and if you're willing to put in the work, you can find opportunities to learn and grown. The company is a tech giant, and is also focused on innovation and community engagement. There is a focus on developing women in leadership roles and connecting women within the organization
cons: Can be bureaucratic and hard to navigate. Duplication of effort is not abnormal because there are so many people working towards the same or similar goals. Not all managers are created equal.

review_title: Cisco is a great workplace for women
pros: Cisco is a great workplace for women. I feel that I have management support all the way to the top and great colleagues. We have regular events to mentor, develop and inspire women. I work with partners, so I know that is not always the case in the Silicon Valley, especially in engineering. Also I have great role models to look up to. In which other large tech company half of CEO reports are women, and not just in traditionally female functions like marketing? I can't think of any other.
cons: I do feel that Cisco can do better in the compensation area. Until recently I was paid less than my male colleagues even though I performed better. My current manager worked to bring me up the curve from where my first manager placed me, but it took a while.

pros: cool people, cool technology, cool benefits. Cisco has a lot going for it, including variety of career opportunities, mentors that are helpful and engaged, and programs to network across the company.
cons: it is a big company with all the pitfalls of a big company. anonymity, inaccessible leadership, procedural impediments, formalities that inhibit growth and leadership that abide by those formalities.

review_title: An inside out perspective on life at Cisco
pros: Working with the brightest and the best in the industry, dynamic fast paced environment, flexible working - work is what you do not a place you go.
cons: Need better comms when the inevitable restructures occur - it happens we know it happens so lets be grown up about it

review_title: Inspiring co-workers and great work life balance
pros: At Cisco I find myself surrounded by smart and motivated individuals who constantly challenge me to be innovative and to improve. This is especially true of the amazing women I work with who inspire me to challenge the status quo while at the same time continuing to evaluate and evolve my own perspective and actions. Additionally, the ability for me to define where, when and how I work is truly what enables me to be successful both at work and in managing the rest of my life. And the technology we use on a daily basis to do that is truly AMAZING!
cons: As in any big company - patience, persistence and perseverance are key character traits you must rely on daily.

review_title: More support required for female community
pros: Excellent company , fast paced, industry leader, flexibility
cons: Still outnumbered. 30-1 . Most teams are 90% Men. Especially Management Teams Now that Cisco is trying to have more diverse interview panels, we are bombarded with every interview. No thank you or acknowledgement just so someone can make a metric

pros: trying to think of some
cons: you are the only woman in 99% of all the meetings you in

review_title: Great place to work at!! Tech writer with Cisco for the last 10 years!!
pros: 1) Flexibility: Have work from home options and work hours that can be balanced between home and office. This allows me to spend time for self-care and family, apart from focusing on my career. 2) Beautiful campus and added facilities 3) Management is always ready to listen 4) Compensation and other benefits such as, leave of absence, etc
cons: The recent layoffs have triggered a fear of insecurity with the job. However, Cisco takes utmost care to ensure that the employees who are impacted are taken good care in terms of the benefits. This cannot be compared with the other organizations. Although these decisions are difficult for Cisco, it tries its level best to compensate in the best manner possible.

pros: Complete Employee Empowerment and excellent job rotation opportunities
cons: We get so used to working at Cisco, can never work in any other company

pros: The consideration and help - the global atmosphere (except the pressure for the figures)
cons: Feeling not to be understood sometimes around almost only men

pros: Cisco Systems has an incredibly open employee culture from the top down, meaning that senior people within the company are always open to speaking and providing mentor-ship with early in career individuals. The overall culture and benefits of the company are great. Autonomy and flexibility with working hours, opportunities for growth, great compensation, continually learning & wonderful coworkers and middle management.
cons: As a female who is early in my career, there is still the prevalence of a "boys club" and find that young males tend to find mentors in senior management/ leadership more easily then women.

pros: Flexibility, culture, collaboration in a virtual environment, ability to adapt to changing technology landscape
cons: Lots of changes lately impacting morale...

pros: People are great. Technology fantastic! Anything possible. If you want it to happen... make it so!
cons: Constant ongoing redundancy especially if your direct management isn't in the UK

pros: Cisco has a multitude of internal resources for women to learn. Cisco HR has become very aware of how many women they hire and managers advocate for equal treatment and opportunity for women. Although the balance is still mostly male, I constantly run into women in cybersecurity, and it's a refreshing change from my old employer, where I was the only woman.
cons: Global company = some early/late calls

pros: A wonderful company to work for, the best I have ever worked for.
cons: Nepotism is rife within this organisation, & HR is aware of it

pros: A good opportunity to work in current technologies. Basic facilities are good at the work place. Company offers a wide variety of sessions and trainings to attend and learn.
cons: Poor team structures. Should do much better job in building longterm sustaining teams with collective learning and winning. Some of the poeple who were technically strong and pillars of the team are let go in LRs instead of promoting them. A big negative to the company losing all that in-house expertise. If bussiness is not doing well, they can do better job in other teams in new projects as well. People with low technical standards compared to them, simply shout out in the meetngs, do not contribute anything technically to help the team accomplish their work are still with us as managers/leads. They come to work 3-4 hrs a day pretending they are busy with meetings and simply ask everyone what is ETA, pressurise with delegations. Culture of all engineers reporting to managers with so much of work details in mails, meetings, presentaion slides and managers simply sit in the meetings and project teams work as their work MUST change. Leads, managers, everyone should contribute to actual ground level work, should be technically strong enough to mentor others and should be ready to flex their muscles physically in the labs when needed. Otherwise, as long as I do not do it - everything is simple and easy to preach others. Resource estimations, work hours and deadlines will be unreal. They simply blame others instead of owning and taking responsibility of delays and failures.

location: Feltham, South West England, England, England
pros: Innovative company that trusts their employees and gives them space to shine. You get from Cisco what you put in. You will find great opportunities but they would be just handed to you, you need to build your network and go looking for it. If you do, there's a lot to gain! Cisco allows you to work from home or from any office you like (except for very few office-based positions), it offers great compensation and benefits, discounts, peer-to-peer reward scheme, amazing offices with good restaurants and lots of perks like massage chairs and nap pods, gym, allows time off for volunteering, good pension contribution. For the ladies, there's also a lot of investment from the company to bring more women into technology and to develop the next generation of female leaders. There's also a good maternity leave and there is even a nursery at the headquarters
cons: Flexible working has its pros and cons. Because people come and go from the office at any day or time they like and can work remotely, you may feel a bit isolated at times.

pros: I feel comfortable being female engineer here overall. There's Lean in circle, events to empower women in Tech and events to engage girls at schools and universities to choose Tech industry and continue work in the field after graduation, accordingly.
cons: For now few female managers and leaders (at my organization), and few female engineers. But I know company is aiming to accept more, diversity (overall, not gender-wise) is priority here

review_title: Women are replacing Men; Temporary Workers are replacing Women
pros: Cisco is committed to meeting its metric of diversity and inclusion.
cons: Tenure does not warrant raises.

review_title: Proud to be part of Cisco
pros: Strong collaboration, able to truly "own" your role with room to grow. Also provides great opportunities for volunteering and giving back - incredible company!
cons: Ambiguity with team structure / restructuring at times, like any large organization.

pros: Great benefits; flexible work schedule; mobility culture. Excellent pay scale for the area. Fantastic teammates -- everyone hired here is top notch.
cons: The company is so large that sometimes the messaging that comes from management is not embraced by the entire vertical and it leads to mixed messages to the employees. Constant pressure to "cut opex" which leads to layoffs.

pros: Being a women at Cisco you don't go unnoticed as they are not a lot of us, especially in sales jobs, so people easily remember you.
cons: In a male dominant environment, there is little to no empathy in general. It depends on the team, but it gets worse when you are pregnant and once your kid is here you still have to put in the same long hours.

ant communication Focus on the present and the future while learning from the past Work/Life balance is a priority Culture of trust, honesty and respect
Cons
With the rapid change is our environment it is sometimes difficult to keep up with all of the new technologies

pros: As with every company, you can have an amazing experience or an extremely poor experience, depending on who your manager is at Cisco. I've had two extremely poor experiences and two amazing experiences. Cisco is struggling with changing their culture amidst huge IT changes in the industry. Customers and partners are evolving and Cisco has to evolve to adapt. This leads to continual layoffs/restructuring, inability to retain good talent, and extremely poor management. If you have an amazing manager, you will have a great combination of work life balance. You may work 50+ hours, but still have the ability to attend your kids sports/school activities, field trips etc, and still be considered an effective employee. The benefits are great also, there are many opportunities for employees to reap financial benefits in the way of bonuses (if the company is doing well,) ESPP stock purchasing and 401K. The company will take care of you while you are working for them.
cons: If you have a poor manager, you will be micro managed, texted while you're on PTO, and harassed to the point where your only option is to find another position either within or outside of the company. Such is the case with any company, there are good and bad managers. Cisco seems to have more bad managers than good ones. They have some major middle management issues that they need to take care of. They've effectively gotten rid of 360 feedback which prevents employees from having the ability to rate their managers, but on a team of less than 5 people, it's easy for the manager to figure out who's providing "bad" feedback, so they can be targeted or managed out.

review_title: Pervasive Male Culture is Slowly Evolving
pros: Great company, great leadership and lots of potential. Individuals are truly regarded based on their merits and little or no weight is given to gender. Women occupy leadership places in all areas; not only those generally reserved for women (HR, Marketing) but also sales and engineering.
cons: That being said, it is a white, male, sales dominated company and that is a very powerful legacy that is hard to break away from. From the "play" events (Golf, Vegas etc), to the silly badge clips that only work with belt loops, everything still screams "we cater to men". It's not malicious and change is coming but it's hard and it will take time. Also, parental leave is pathetic. As a CA company it should follow CA law, instead the follow whatever minimum is required by law in your state which makes it very unfair for non-California moms. In most states fathers get no leave and need to use their vacation time.

pros: Reasonable flexibility on where to work, some very clever people
cons: Locker room humour, informal boys networks, always having your opinion compared to "my wife..." e.g. i wouldn't let my wife...

pros: Strong company with a great work environment, very talented people I get to work with on a regular basis across different groups and departments, and great partners and customers who make what I do on a daily basis matter. New leadership to virtual sales organization has brought some good change to processes and systems to help us do our jobs more effectively. In virtual sales, the training program sets you up to be successful in your role.
cons: Virtual Sales org is much more than a 9-5 job. Most people that are putting effort into their jobs spend a minimum of 10-15 hours a week working outside of the office. It is strongly encouraged (or required if you want to do well long term) you put in the hours at home. I work 55+ hours a week, myself and many of my coworkers have no problem with this. What is a problem is that we work 15 hours at home during the course of a week, but in exchange there is no flexibility in the 40 hours per week they require us to be in the office.

pros: Great Benefits Talented Team Strong Products Market Leader
cons: Work Life Balance Very High Goals Extremely Political Nepotism Poor Management Strategy In Our Segment New "Collaborative" Environment has us packed like sardines and is VERY loud Over the last 18 months there has been major changes in Cisco as a whole. Some of this change is for the good. Especially our moving to more of a licensing model. The main issue is that goals have shot through the roof and the culture has been hit drastically. Prior to these changes we had the freedom to work in an atmosphere that promoted and strong work/life balance and a culture that was second to none. Our team was one of the most successful in all of Cisco and you could not find a person on our team that was unhappy with the culture/environment. Now it's hard to find someone that wouldn't jump ship if the opportunity presented itself. As for goals, the first few years of my tenure with Cisco our uplifts year over year ranged from 12% - 20% which, dependent on territory, gave everyone the opportunity to be successful. My personal goals for the last couple years have exceeded 50% year over year growth and I know of teammates who's goals have exceeded 80%. When your OTE (On Target Earnings) are based on a 50/50 salary to commission structure, this kills your income. My understanding is one person on our entire team of 25 that is on target to hit goals this year.

pros: The people and the culture! Cisco looks after employees' wellness and work life balance. In my role, I am able to work with very diverse, fun and smart people on a daily basis. Access to fantastic technology also brings the already flexible work environment to the next level. review_title: Sr. Manager Strategy, Planning and Programs
pros: Great Company, many opportunities if you have the right skills
cons: For those of us that are impacted by a restructure, there is no real process to place us in other available positions

review_title: Some positives but also many negatives
pros: Possible to work from home. Good benefits - Free health insurance. Buy up to 5 days extra holidays. Good work life balance. Everyone I work with are genuine and nice people. Get to work with modern technologies, environments and programming languages. The products we are working on very new and so you do get to spend a good bit of time actually coding new features vs just bug fixing etc. Good hardware for work. Very good to the wider community and are continuously raising money for good causes.
cons: No career progression. Very possible to get stuck in same position / salary for years on end in this company. Seem to have no budget for career advancement at the moment. Very difficult to stay motivated. Good engineering practices are not always recognized. Management say they care about quality but only seem to reward engineers who produce at speed but cause many bugs in our products. Actions speak louder than words. No team structure. You don't know what you will be working on week to week. Very varied. Can be a good thing or a bad thing depending on the person. Not what I like in a work place environment. Very frugal in general with employees i.e Don't help pay for Christmas Party. We used to have release parties but since we are releasing on a continuous basis this has all dried up. Again no recognition to the dedication of employees. Since we develop communications applications there is a culture of always being online and it can be common to seeing people replying to messages at 11 - 12pm at night. Can be very difficult to switch off. Management don't directly encourage this but also don't try to curb this behavior. Canteen is expensive for what you get. Cisco didn't provide the catering contractor and canteen staff with the proper facilities so they have to make do with pre made factory food and microwaves. Food seems highly processed and as such the quality isn't very good. Vending machines have no healthy options. Senior Management are more obsessed with image i.e Winning Great Place To Work instead of actually improving the work environment for employees. I feel that management don't listen to employees concerns. I had many experiences of engineers on the team voicing common sense concerns about the direction of the product to management only to fall on deaf ears. Eventually the customer voiced the same concerns and so we ended up wasting countless engineering hours backtracking on previous work. This has happened on many occasions. Over the last number of years there has been annual redundancies with out fail. It has actually affected the Galway site a couple of times. One year a whole team was let go. This was without consideration to the performance of individual members of the team. So it doesn't matter how good you are you could still be let go at anytime.

pros: 1. People are great and highly collaborative. I can't speak for every single person at Cisco but I can say that almost everyone at Cisco is always willing to help a peer! 3. Great programs to get involved--Conexion, Connected Black Professionals, Men for Inclusion, Connected Asian Affinity Network, and Pride are just some of the excellent programs and groups we have. This is a really great way to network with people all over the company! 4. Great work/life balance. Need to work from home? Work with your manager and if they're okay, then life is made easy for you! 5. Exciting place to work in terms of the industry! Working in tech is fun and exciting!
cons: 1. There isn't much diversity in Engineering or IT but Cisco is actively working on attracting diverse talent 2. Cisco is HUGE and it is easy to get lost in a 73K+ employee company. review_title: Great place to work in sales
pros: Really enjoyed working in security sales at Cisco. Positive but intense work environment. Teams that want to do right by the customer.
cons: The security sales leadership turns over every 12-18 months. This creates direction instability that shows itself at every level of the organization. When the leadership is good, it's good. Every other turn they promote someone from a new acquisition (IronPort, Sourcefire) and it's a friggin mess.

review_title: Inconsistent Culture, But Opportunity for Work/Life Balance
pros: Generally, the people are friendly and smart. It's been that way since I started over a decade ago. The pay is good, benefits are good, and in many areas of the company, you can arrange your working time around your life/kids. The Hispanic/Latino group - Conexion - tries to create a sense of community, encouragement and support among the Latino employee base.
cons: There are a lot of sub-cultures within Cisco, making it very difficult to work cross-functionally. Some groups are punctual, data driven, their word is their bond. Others are undisciplined, political, unreliable. When John Chambers was CEO, we used to talk about the Cisco family, and our mission: changing the way the world lives, works, plays, and learns. More recently, it doesn't seem we talk about that anymore. There's less talk about the family, and we lay hundreds of people off every 6 months.

review_title: Good company that must prioritize hiring top talent and reducing layoffs
pros: Industry leader for 20+ years, Cisco manages to re-invent itself during market transitions, leaving competitors in the dust. Plenty of challenging work, you're surrounded by strong talent willing to collaborate in cross-functional projects to achieve goals. The complete compensation package & benefits seem better than industry average. Cisco manages finances as I do: Being frugal and debt free. The company has an enormous amount of cash available to survive tough times and take advantage of acquisition opportunities.
cons: More political and more turf wars than it used to be. Still a good place compared to other companies though. No job security, more layoffs than similar companies - that's the price you pay for being a large company that must move fast through market transitions. Cisco is quick to let go of investments that aren't paying off and lay off people to cut costs when the quarter didn't go as expected.

pros: Great focus on Diversity. ERO's are well funded. Diverse opinions are valued.
cons: Could use more Latino representation at the executive leadership and director level.

review_title: Not such a great employer anymore
pros: Flexibility with work schedule and working from home is the biggest reason why people remain in Cisco. Really good benefit package and you work with some great people and talent.
cons: Switching off from work when you finish whether it's the end of the day or during your time off. Management is frustrating, they just don't seem to see you as a person and recognize the employees that go over and above in their job. They complete leadership courses and you don't see any change in their management or leadership. The employees that are the loudest and boast about what they apparently do get the recognition. Employees feel they are on 12 month contract with no job security. Salaries are less than what you can get elsewhere. Lots of great people leaving and it's not acknowledged why we are losing good talent and will continue to do so.

review_title: Cisco's endless appetite for startups cannot satisfy its own lack of vision
pros: Good benefits, cares about sustainability, cares about security and often has training on new technologies.
cons: Only the top 5% of employees get to move onto hot products. When Cisco needs revenue, they buy a hot startup product. When the product is growing, staff will be added in India. If your product is not growing fast, work is moved to India. USA staff will be cut every quarter until the USA team is gone and the remaining India team is cut until the product is killed. Rinse repeat for every startup bought. Cisco is circling the same whole as Computer Associates, Wang, Stratus...

pros: Cisco is very well respected brand in the IT industry. Not only do you get to work alongside great minds and industry thought leaders. You get to do it in the service of public and private organizations. We get to be on the very leading edge, helping organizations of all kinds reimagine and reinvent themselves employing digital technology to adopt new business and operational models. Cisco will give you the training and experiences that will give you multidimensional career growth while at the same time encouraging balance with your personal life.
cons: Prepare to be disrupted. Cisco is a company built on employing disruptive technology to help organizations reinvent themselves. The culture here at Cisco is to disrupt and reinvent ourselves; both as an organization and as individuals. If you are not comfortable working outside your comfort zone, Cisco may not be the place for you.

pros: Cisco is a solid and reputable company that values its employees. Technology is always changing and Cisco continues to keep a pulse on the business and its employees. There are many opportunities for career and development growth as Cisco Management fully support this methodology.
