location: São Paulo, São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: Cisco really stimulates and empower employees for their personal and professional development. The company heavily invest in training to give you the knowledge and tools to enable you to excel in your role. It is a solid company with great compensation and benefits compared to other companies within the same market. Good work-life balance. Management stimulates and accepts open and honest feedback. Customer success at Cisco is the best place to be. A lot is happening and changing, there are many learning and career opportunities. The impact I make is clear, measurable and rewarded.
cons: Data accuracy might be an issue (multiple sources of information). Delivery processes getting in the way of things that needs to be done for our customers.

pros: It is a at the forefront of SaaS evolution. All other vendors know what it is and how important it is but Cisco has it very well defined on how to its done. Everyone from the individual contributor to the senior executives is involved and part of the evolution. Perfect job for anyone who wants to feel his/her contribution makes an impact no matter what the role or job function is.
cons: It is a constant evolving and growing pain. Some may like more predictability and certainty but since this is an ever evolving and growing field, they may find the changes too overwhelming.

pros: I love working here and the support you get from all levels of management can't be beat. People think sometimes that when you work for a large company like Cisco, you'll somehow get overlooked. But I can tell you that's not the case. You get to work with the smartest people in the industry who truly believe in educating and enabling their employees. Everyday, I feel like I've made an impact, and that my value is being recognized. I advocate everyday for my friends to work here because it is absolutely the best place to be. Customer Success is taking the industry by storm right now, and there is not a better company to be working with. Cisco has always been a thought leader, and they recognize how critical Customer Success is for our customers. I can't wait to see how this group grows and transforms within the coming months. It's one of the most rewarding careers being able to work so closely with customers to truly understand their business, and how we can help them reach their business outcomes. If you want to learn, grow and be surrounded by passionate, motivated people - this is where you'll find them!
cons: It's a newer team, so naturally there are still some things they are trying to work out in terms of what technology we align to and other little nuances... but it doesn't take away from the value you deliver as a CSM or the overall experience of working there. It's more of a growing pain than a con! :)

review_title: Diverse and great place to work
pros: Cisco is a great company, it empowers and give employees the freedom to deliver to their full potential. It is a company that is constantly looking for excellence. It is a great diverse place. As Hispanic/Latino, I feel my unique values are not only welcome but even encouraged. It is a true global company. I am part of Conexión, Cisco's Hispanic/Latino ERO, We help Cisco to hire and retain the best Latino talent as well as helping the Latino Community at Cisco and in our neighborhoods. As a large and successful corporation, benefits are very good and employees are given the necessary resources to succeed. We work on the newest technologies, with modern processes that help Cisco (and us as employees) to stay ahead of the curve!
cons: Change is always good, but sometimes there are collateral impacts of the way Corporate America is handled, basically with a clock that shakes every quarter. Cisco being a large corporation is no exempt from that, with constant role and leadership changes as well as more than desired limited restructurings. This might affect your career if you don't know how to deal with constant change.

review_title: Outstanding place to work - Surprised so few know about Cisco
pros: Remuneration is very strong and they don't expect you to compromise your life. In fact, they enable you to have a better work/ life balance by providing the equipment and ways of working so you can be highly effective from home. I work 4 days per week from home on average (I have the option to work fewer if I want to). Cisco offers all the benefits you'd expect including you birthday as an additional day off, a choice of high end Mac or PC, phone bill paid in full, 5 additional days off to volunteer for the organisation of your choice (this year I'm using mine to go on a long cycling trip for a charity started by one of my colleague's. You can also receive connected recognition, this is a cash reward of varying amounts you receive from colleagues who think you went above and beyond. I received one last month for £70 but the amounts can be over £100. Aside from all of this, the people are great and together we make a fun friendly culture. It's work hard, play hard and Cisco certainly rewards all those who do. A great choice of tech company whether you have technical skills or not.
cons: The business is focused on short-term financial performance. This can be frustrating when trying to deliver longer term projects.

pros: They pay well, especially for employees who live outside of Silicon Valley and have a lower cost of living. They encourage remote working, so you have a lot of flexibility. Well-known and respected in IT circles. Benefits are generous. Many people work there for 20+ years.
cons: The culture is very corporate, full of things that seem straight out of Dilbert. Jargon, corporate politics, SLOW pace and red tape much of the time. If you're not an engineer, it's hard to feel appreciated for what you contribute. The lay-offs seem haphazard. They say that it helps week out low-performers, but they give blanket percentages across the organization, so obviously many good employees are caught and it leaves the remaining teams to pick up work for several people. Doing this over and over is demoralizing. Many of my co-workers only stay because they don't think they can find a remote job that will pay as well. Not exactly inspiring.

pros: It's a large company, so the scenario in different business units and teams can be wildly different. In a long career at Cisco (1996-2015), I worked in many different teams. With only a small number of exceptions, the colleagues and teams I worked with were excellent, motivated and professional. When working onsite (San Jose), promotion path was good, career aspirations were well supported. Lots of money - good pay relative to industry, good benefits. Fascinating, hard work. Generally a lot more openness, and startup feel than you'd expect at such a large company.
cons: Management became a bit top- and middle- heavy. Large company problems, projects would be cancelled (usually justifiably!) later than they should have been. Some business functions that fell across Business Units would be hard to co-ordinate. Only ran into 2-3 bad apples in almost 20 years, which is great ratio, but it was impossible to get rid of them even though they were well identified as such. Standard big company demotivational stuff. But less than you'd expect at such a large company.

review_title: Great when and where you find the freedom to work
pros: Initially after we were acquired, we were hopeful about finally having the stability to continue working on our technology with the resources of a bigger company. Cisco was pretty good about leaving us alone for the first little bit, but the corporation has got to corporate at some point you know. The benefits were solid, fair and generously doled out on regular schedules. This is a great place to maintain and build with a moderate pace of progress professionally.
cons: Cisco as a company isn't really doing anything innovative, and really feels like a stagnant hardware company trying to pivot into software in many ways.

pros: Great company to work for.
cons: Things move slower than they should because of its size.

pros: - Generally good engineers - Depending on what group you are in, can be a fun place to work - Chance of exposure to different technologies as the company does encourage mobility. - Compensation is fair: base salary plus annual bonus (which is based on company and individual performance). Company also gives out RSUs.
cons: - Upper management often out of touch of the underlying problems, leading to either inaction or worse ill informed decisions - Company struggles to innovate due to very heavy processes that stifle putting ideas into action. Cisco, with their big wallets, can overcome this via acquisitions. - Acquisitions typically struggle to innovate and grow their products. Instead, becomes a sustaining shop. Overtime, their products either get eliminated or outsourced and the original group gets laid off. - Annual layoffs which nurture a sub-optimal culture. It does not matter if you are really good or not. if you happened to be on the wrong project, you can be impacted. - Annual peer ranking to feed into the annual layoffs. Everyone is aware of this process -which encourages less than ideal behavior - Raises are slim or too infrequent.

review_title: If you work hard you will get rewarded.
pros: I'm very passionate about security and I get to work for one of the work leaders in field. I feel like the work I do is actually making a difference in the world. I enjoy the work that I do on a daily basis. I'm very well paid. My base salary is very competitive. The bonus percentages are very high at Cisco. I've had double digit percentage raises and double digit percentage bonuses in the last year. I get to work from home multiple days per week. There are a lot of smart people who can do really cool things. My office gets free lunch, free coffee (good coffee too), free drinks (red bull) at the vending machines, all snacks at the vending machines only cost a quarter. I could wear a t-shirt, gym shorts and sandals to work at my office and nobody would care. Almost no dress code at all. The office is very nice, clean, etc. Good benefits like healthcare, vision, dental, etc. They also have stock options that are good.
cons: Politics regarding acquisitions and merging teams can get in the way of doing actual work or event prevent projects from being able to be completed at all. I can't bring my dog to work anymore. That's about it for complaints.

pros: The work life balance at Cisco is incredibly unique. All you need is your laptop and wifi and you can work wherever you'd like (in most cases, some functions do not have complete flexibility). I live thousands of miles from my family & friends, but Cisco encourages me to go home and visit whenever I'd like, without having to take any time off. I can only imagine how wonderful this flexibility will be when I'm a mother some day. I've had numerous coworkers stay home with a sick child or take some time out of the day to go pick up their kids from school. Cisco supports it all. It would be extremely difficult to leave and lose all this flexibility. I plan to stay here as long as possible.
cons: Nothing sticks out that is any different than working at any other company. Typical downsides of being in a business environment.

pros: Flexible work environment, decent benefits
cons: Limited opportunity for professional development and growth, questionable future

pros: -You have an opportunity to make a lot of money if you're in the right place at the right time. -There is always opportunity to move internally. I've seen people promote from sales to management, move to a product specialist role, move to the channels side or a strategic operation position, or just change sales job from territory to larger accounts. -Just about any hiring manager you reach out to will be open to talking with you. It's cultural to talk to anyone who reaches out and help each other. -Very generous benefits and PTO -There is no shortage of resources for sales to engage to help win deals. -Less pressure at the end of the month than many sales organizations, though of course there is still pressure and it's part of any sales job. There is a larger focus on annual quota than month to month though which is nice considering seasonality. -Breadth and depth of solutions we can sell is unmatched. -Sales tools / technology and integrations are very good and user friendly compared to some other companies.
cons: -There seems to be high turnover in management. Managers aren't necessarily leaving the company, though some are, but I've seen many moving internally. It's not uncommon to have a manager for one year only. That doesn't have to be a bad thing but it's something to be aware of if you really like your hiring manager and that's effecting your decision. -Like with any large company, it can be very time consuming to find the right person to help for a specific issue. There are always people to help and resources, but finding them is half the battle. You can't always get quick answers or results for your customers because of this. -Annual layoffs have a definite impact on morale. Loss of resources due to the layoff coupled with subpar communication can make it difficult to pull in the right resource at a certain time of the year and slow down your business and sales cycle. -Account list tends to change every year.

review_title: Had good experiences during internships, but full-time is a different story
pros: + Internships were enjoyable because I got to work on small but interesting projects in an easygoing environment. That said, compensation is very much below average compared to other tech companies in Silicon Valley. + Work/life balance is good. Rarely is anyone ever expected to work more than 40 hours per week. This might depend on your group though. + They are making a good effort to update their offices in San Jose from the old cubicle farms to the newer open-floor setups with free amenities (coffee/tea/espresso, snacks, etc.). + They do not skimp on developer machines and peripherals like monitors, headphones, etc.
cons: - Very bureaucratic, lots of reorgs and movement at the middle and upper levels (e.g. new directors, mid-level managers, upper-level managers). - The pay is below average in comparison to other tech companies in the Bay Area. Promotions/raises seem to be few and far between. It will soon be my third year here, and all of my developer peers have also complained about slow growth within the company. - Due to the bureaucratic nature of the company, communication among the many groups is slow and sporadic. - It may be different for other groups, but there seems to be a general lack of expertise when it comes to software development best practices: -- Everything is hacked together -- Quantity of features and speed of development > quality and stability -- There are no design/architecture discussions that include all of the developers ("design" of the product usually happens as informal conversations between mid-to-senior level developers, without including the newer/entry-level developers). These discussions are ad-hoc, informal, and often not even documented. -- No standards followed for releases/deployment -- Very little effort spent on documentation of anything -- We are one of the many groups that tries to follow Agile/Scrum, but since we don't follow a lot technical practices that actual make Agile work (e.g. unit tests, code reviews, decent documentation, reasonably-sized & well-defined user stories, etc.), it isn't working as it should. The end result is shoddy code and constantly accumulating technical debt. - People in non-technical roles (middle managers and product owners) push for features and user stories without really knowing what they want. User stories are often a terse title and an empty description (no behavioral/functional specifications, no summary, no consideration for inter-dependencies among other user stories). - Projects often lack clear direction. This point applies to my group and our project, but I think it might apply to other groups as well. There are many technical leaders in our group, but for our project, we lack a TRUE lead technical architect who: 1) has a clear vision of what the product should be like 2) plans architecture & development tasks for the group 3) mentors less experienced developers 4) maintains standards on code quality and development processes Bottom line: If you're looking for a place to hone your technical skills and grow as a developer, look elsewhere. Some of the other reviewers who mentioned a culture of complacency absolutely hit the nail on the head. I have observed first-hand many times where our group has accepted mediocre work or shortcuts without hesitation "if it gets the job done," creating more technical debt. When developers ask for time to address technical debt, we are rebuffed by managers who claim that it is "good enough" and that we should focus on pumping out more features. If you stay here too long, your skills as a software developer will only continue to rust.

lting Systems Engineer in Feltham, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Still has a good work/life balance - you control your diary and management generally back you up Good customer contacts - not many organisations that won't at least entertain Cisco Good perks - some of the benefits are very good
Cons
Terrible technology - constant failure to execute in cloud/software. Promises made and broken continuously. Backstabbing colleagues - I worked with one extremely nasty piece of work who'd constantly backstab people and put them down. When half the team issued a formal complaint he got a payrise and an award from management instead! Best they could do was apologise to us... No willingness to listen to problems - 6 months of dire morale and a collapsing team yet no one took any time to listen, understand or fix it. The team I was in lost 5 or more people in 6 months because of this. Not one of them got an exit interview. Petty politics - lots of power struggles and empire building at the expense of anyone's hopes and dreams. AMs and PSS treated like rockstars whilst SEs thought of as resources to book and use like meeting rooms. No sales apititude - most sales people happily admit they don't understand what they're selling. An embarassment that would be met with complete shame in any other line of work. The worst are the so-called sales experts. No career prospects - once upon a time you could look at the big pyramid that is Cisco and see how you could progress. Now there's nowhere to go other than to do the same job with the occaisional payrise to keep you in your place. LR used as a stick when people get old and/or expensive.

review_title: Great Flexibility, Great People; Focus on Weekly Commit destroying the culture
pros: The people are the gold in this company. Smart, innovative, hugely supportive, fun. It's inspiring to work in a culture of expected excellence where nobody is held above anyone else. The flat organisation means employees have huge autonomy -but also corresponding accountability. The flexible work conditions are the reason people stay in tough times - 'working from anywhere' is so much encouraged that there is an internal website to share photos of the craziest places you've logged in from. Very work/life friendly, with no excuses needed to take time for family whether it's children's school activities, elderly parents or sick pets. Disruption and innovation are core values and are celebrated.
cons: The pay hasn't kept pace with similar organisations. You can make up to twice the money at other large IT vendors for the same role. The move to a quarterly/monthly and now a weekly commit model has taken much of the joy out of the workplace and increased stress tenfold. People are incented to focus on the short term wins at the expense of a longer term strategic plan. Recent staff cuts have gone deep into the talent pool, sending some of the best and brightest contributors out to competitors. Hard to move ahead due to the flat organisational structure (=double edged sword)

lting Engineer
20 Mar 2017 - Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
-Work from home. -Flexibility in work hours -Tons on internal documents and repository given cisco is a pioneer in networking industry. -Good Support Documentation. -Better Technical Support than other vendors as per customer comments.
Cons
-Way too many frequent org. changes which makes you feel less motivated as this changes in no way benefits to a engineer but only management and business. - Salary in Advanced Services is average which according to me is poor standard when compared to other big IT companies. - Flexibility in work hours and work from home does not mean pay less. Actually you end up working more hours from home. - Advanced services always have budget issues and there are tons of people to compete for promotions. - Management need to make sure not to create same processes and giving it different names. It just confuses what model to follow. - Too many processes are created by Directors/Managers just for the heck of to show management is doing something better in terms of time management and fast learning for engineers to come up to speed. -You get trained but never implement all of what you learn and hence another waste of dollars on training. - Way too many people out there in the company wanting to prove themselves. -You get promotions based on amount of years spent at the company and not based on your achievements. - They will make you do the same work as the done by higher grade people and still less pay.

pros: Great people, great work, excellent learning, awesome workplace and good pay.

review_title: Many great facets, a few very frustrating ones
pros: Great people across the company. Chuck Robbins is a breath of fresh air. Dominant industry presence, but customers either love Cisco or hate them...not much in between. Great package of benefits.
cons: Being remote from SJC or RTP can make you invisible. Compensation growth is very limited. Sales reporting sucks, making commissions tracking very difficult, and if there's a mistake, good luck getting it corrected. When 'unknown' is the top selling partner in a region, you tend to question all the reporting. Politics, politics, politics! If you aren't a suck-up, you'll never advance. Intense focus on hitting Wall Street expectations for EPS has led to ridiculous T&E budgets. No way to do your job if you are grounded from being front of customers or partners.

review_title: Good place to work, but difficult to work with people
pros: Loads of facilities, HR policy is good
cons: Check out team culture before joining. Lot of old sharks in the company, so they would resist any change

pros: 1. Proper Work-life balance, flexible hours, work-from-home option. 2. Recently, good work is flowing in. 3. Very smart colleagues, very respectful and helping too. 4. Good culture and company values. 5. Good recreational facilities (Quiet rooms, gym, TT and foosball tables, carrom, Massage chairs, Nap rooms, etc.)
cons: 1. Slow growth professionally, too much hierarchy. 2. Removed bi-yearly appraisal, now its yearly. Only related to a particular Business Unit in which I work, Revenue going down (customers moving to cloud platform, so less income from costly hardware ), and so 3. Less hike/promotions. 4. Frequent layoffs, not dependent on performance. 5. Very less food options in cafeteria. (Above 3 does not apply to other Business Units)

pros: Good Benefits, lots of flexibility in the working environment. I worked for the company for 13 years with school age children. The flexibility that there technology and culture provides for working remotely made being a working mother so much easier. Interesting work, even though internally we might feel like we aren't very progressive, most of the company is way ahead of what is happening in most companies. Great work experience.
cons: While the culture is improving, it still has many challenges. Way too many people that are in leadership positions that shouldn't be. They think that bullying their employees is fine as long as they can effectively suck up to senior management. Lots of implicit bias in the organization, and women definitely suffer from the classic double-bind: if you are decisive you aren't likable, and it stalls your growth. Continual churn of executives creates whiplash in employees, as a new executives come in with new plans, throw the baby out with the bath water, and then move on when they figure out there ideas aren't so great after all. Worklife balance is only achievable if you know how to set boundaries.

pros: Big international company, well funded
cons: A lot of burocracy in everyday activity

pros: Work-life balance, virtually unlimited PTO, high pay, brand recognition.
cons: Lack of day-to-day company culture, most people work from home and are generally disconnected.

review_title: Talented People Lost in Political Quagmire
pros: Smart people, decent pay and benefits.
cons: Very siloed positions, most people are under-employed since very talented people are hired into job silos that limit the full expression or development of their skills. There are constant layoffs, accompanied by all of the unhealthy cultural by-products that come with layoffs: paranoia, lack of motivation, managers pitching smoke-and-mirror programs since you will never be held accountable to deliver based on the constant reorganizations and priority shifts, lack of trust. Very talented senior leaders who have the confidence to speak the truth, name the dysfunction for what it is, and try to be agents for change are always the ones to announce they are 'pursuing other opportunities' (aka, forced out), leaving the sub-par leaders to run the ship.

review_title: Great place to work, but going through an identity crisis
pros: Excellent benefits, flexible working from home using WebEx, and transitioning into a more competitive relevant company. It's also easy to find new opportunities and grow within the company. There are many folks, especially more middle-aged folks who've been with the company for multiple years and who maintain and excellent work/life balance.
cons: Cisco is massive and there'll be lots of big corporate headaches with communication. You'll find dozens of teams working on similar things, but no centralized approach. This is getting better with reorgs and aligning to the industry, but still a big issue.

pros: - The people! Great culture and very collaborative. - Work/Life balance - Great benefits (total package: vacation time from day one, health, dental, vision, life, etc. insurance coverage, employee discounts for lots of things, annual bonuses, & the list goes on :-).
cons: - Very challenging to get promoted to the next grade level just based on performance (even for top performers), which is what you're told will get you to the next grade level. - Salary low as compared to other Information Technology companies (though total compensation package is very good).

pros: C-level management has done great work to change the brand from a just networking company to a services company. Alot of work is required, change in mindset, but C-level execs can def. achieve it. Work is challenging and people are fun and friendly.

pros: You get the sense that cisco really cares about their employees and at the individual contributor level they will provide lots of flexibility (no strict 9-5 hours, possibility to work remote, etc) to ensure that employees feel comfortable and valued. cons: It will depend on your team assignment but the overall atmosphere at cisco is geared towards older and more established professionals. As a fresh grad straight out of college it can be a bit of a culture mismatch, but everyone is still incredibly nice and easy to work with.

cons: Company has been going through a transitional period for the past 18 months. This is something that has been very disruptive, with a reduction in workforce occurring approximately every 3-5 months. Additionally, for the past 10 years, the Company has been in a mode of buying promising Companies in order to acquire new technologies or solutions, and then after about 2 or 3 years, shifting a chunk of software development resources offshore or in some cases to Canada -something that may be a concern depending on job role and department.

review_title: rudderless & hopeless -- a colossal waste of motivated talent
pros: * Excellent technical talent * Many excellent leaders * Executive leadership cares about the quality of leadership & management (and appreciates the difference) * Deep security awareness * Ambitious people who want to make a difference * Strong compensation possible for the lucky
cons: * If you think of VSEM (vision, strategy, execution & measurement), the executive leadership seems to be focused on financial execution to the exclusion of all other concerns. Short of the obvious need to diversify from the embattled networking equipment space, we have yet to hear a cogent vision or strategy from the ELT. * Constant squeezing of all groups to protect the dividend, frustrating the need of Cisco's varied businesses to grow at different paces * Fancy lip-service towards innovation (complete with voting competitions, &c.) but no executive buy-in towards actual innovation within its existing businesses * Cisco is swinging towards being a software company, but has almost no-one who knows how to build viable software businesses -- Cisco risks becoming an also-ran low-margin services business if this continues * Consistent, persistent fear of being laid off to protect the dividend completely saps morale and undercuts HR's efforts to ensure Cisco is a good employer (the constant threat of financially-driven layoffs terrifies our H-1B holders) * Executive focus seems concentrated on the few lines of business that can compensate for the networking business's lagging margins... to the detriment of any future businesses that might develop * Acquiring new businesses then requiring them grow while undercutting their OPEX and forcing them to take on Cisco-internal systems/practices that don't work for the acquired business * Laying off the sales organizations of businesses that are meeting Cisco's top-line margin requirements

review_title: Been a great ride, but might be time for me to move on
pros: I have been at Cisco for almost 2 decades and have been blessed with the opportunity to perform 7 different roles over that time. There is almost always a way to reinvent or morph yourself given the wide range of opportunities. The compensation has been pretty fair for the past decade or so. It really helped that I've had some top-notch managers that have gone to bat for me with HR. My last two managers have been pretty awful, but *all* of the ones prior had my back and helped me grow my career... even if they knew it meant I'd move on to bigger and better things. I can't state that strongly enough. I have never been as happy with my immediate manager in any job as I have been at Cisco (save the past year or two). Cisco prides itself on hiring the right folks - as anyone subjected to the myriad of interviews can attest - and I have to say they generally hit home runs. 90%+ of the people I work with have been excellent, self-starting, and knew their stuff - or learned it on-the-job and jumped right in.
cons: I know that Stack Ranking gets a bum rap, but you know who really likes it?.. folks who rank well and bust their backsides to get there. With the move to "The People Deal" (still have no idea WTF that means), Stack Ranking went away - as did the RSUs. I get nearly 1/3 of my total compensation from RSUs, so these are the "golden handcuffs" that keep me here. No more RSUs, no more cuffs, perhaps time to look elsewhere. Why leave? I have been on the cutting edge of new markets for Cisco for be better part of the last decade. These are places where they make big bets, but quickly grow into a bureaucratic model that sells its soul to the first customer to sign a PO, then slowly drown and sink as that customer (or customers) weigh us down and not pivot with the rest of the market. As I look around the landscape and view Cisco's attempts to pivot to Cloud and recurring revenue models, it is very clear that they are not learning from these failures. They burn out or run off all of the folks who could help prevent the next failure, thus do not learn the lesson. Or, in other cases, they do not allow enough time to get things rolling. You basically have 3 years to be #1/2 in the market - or else. Reference the recent death of Intercloud as an example of what I mean. They committed $1 billion to the project, but had a massively flawed business model from the start. After all, who can compete with AWS when it comes to plain IaaS? They were far too late to bring the other table stakes bits that go along with that (VPNaaS, LBaaS, FWaaS, Big Data as a Service, etc). Many of those were just about to launch when they canned the entire engineering portion of the project. One of the major distractions - and reasons for the delay in getting that stuff in place - was being saddled with their two external partners. These partners contracted one thing, then asked for a wildly different deployment model or Roles and Responsibilities. These held back any further evolution and improvement of the platform. Don't get me wrong: We screwed up alot, too, but those early commitments killed our velocity and ability to pivot.

review_title: Stay clear of here if you are ambitious
pros: This company has a big name in tech so it is a resume builder for sure regardless of your personal experience within the company.
cons: If you are young in your career Cisco can be a nightmare. Managers have absolutely no idea what you do from day to day and seem to care little about that. You can go months without talking to your manager if you want. Managers couldn't care less about your professional development. Having sync up calls with your manager to discuss development is literally a joke because they will help you with nothing. Cisco is losing talent fast and a big reason is because they pay poor, the company is too bureaucratic for career growth, and management is completely lousy. In my four years at Cisco I've had 5 or 6 managers and I can only say that one of them was a good/great one. Oh and I almost forgot. If you are early in your career forget about proper training. Cisco is absolutely horrendous and training new talent for the work force. This is literally a sink or swim company. You come in on your first day after a couple years out of college and your manager is looking at you to close million dollar deals with no proper product, role, or field training. They'll just say figure it out or browse the companies 70k people to find someone who can give you advice. They don't even assign you a mentor. The ability for people to work from home has turned the office to a ghost town so if you enjoy he presence of other human being you better forget about it here.

review_title: Was once a great IT department, not anymore due to a corrupt CIO.
pros: You get to work with greatly talented people. Flexible work arrangements are good.
cons: The leadership team in IT is corrupt starting with the CIO. People are promoted for the most vague reasons. The claim they act with integrity till you find family relatives of the CIO working in her reporting chain. She actually continued to manage family members, who benefitted financially from outsourcing deals even after moving to her role as COO under new CEO. The new CIO is one of her watchdogs, who also is known to promote people based on racial agenda. He has no achievements and just a talking head. It is still Jacoby in the house with G keeping the status quo. They witch hunted many good people managers who were forced to leave.

pros: Excellent benefits (4% 401k match, ESPP options, $50,000 Lifetime Fertility coverage, paid volunteer hours, paid time off) and work from home whenever needed
cons: Meetings. Meetings. Meetings. With no agendas. No accountability. Work falls on the base level employees. Tons of middle management bloat - expect 6-7 layers of management above you if you are a worker bee. Communication is not direct - expect every announcement to be lengthy, full of fancy words that run around the point.

review_title: Was the greatest, now an offshoring machine
pros: They own many markets. They have the money and size to move the industry. The individual contributors and some technical managers are top notch. This company was a leader in culture, HR, valuing employees etc. I used to LOVE working for this company years ago. I had a great career here and appreciate it all but...
cons: Lost their culture. The scale used to be "we are in the top 5-10 percent" today top 50% seems acceptable. Constant reorganization, too many layers of unneeded management and only an echo of the past cultural values that were once so inspiring. The company became a financial spreadsheet driven organization sometime in the early to mid 2000's and once they started "rightsizing/downsizing/limited restructuring/reorganizing..." they got the taste and never looked back. Offshoring is constant (some of which is fine but they throw a lot of talent away in the States that could easily be retooled.
